story:
“The world is depressing enough. If you have the ability and the talent to bring hope and joy into someone’s life then you have the obligation to do that”
(An American in Paris the Musical). 

I watched from the balcony of the Palace Theatre in New York, as the character Adam 
Hochberg, a composer surrounded by a world still in turmoil after the devastations of WWII, discovers, after many dreary minor key trials, how his music can successfully bring people hope and joy. He speaks this quotation after the opening of his ballet when he sees the faces of the audience brighten for the first time since the war. If he has the ability to accomplish this, then it is his duty to the world to do so. Light in the Dark Theatre, as well, can bring hope and joy to our distressing world as we have been given the gift to accomplish this; so, it is our responsibility to do so. Adam Hochberg and the writers of An American in Paris were asking us to ‘step up’ – to inform people of the light in the world, inspire hope, and incite them into positive action. Therefore, Light in the Dark Theatre aspires to tell stories that leave an audience with a sense of hope – a sense that they can make a positive difference in this world. 

My name is Emily and I am the Founder and Artistic Director of Light in the Dark Theatre. I grew up in a very small rural Alberta town which did not offer a lot of  artistic opportunity. Luckily, I had a family who was willing to drive me multiple times a week to cities hours away in order to give me the opportunity to experience and partake in theatre. Not all children have this luxury so I want to bring theatre to them. Part of Light in the Dark Theatre's goals is to bring these stories of hope to rural communities in Alberta which have minimal arts options due to their physical location. We also want to provide these communities with artistic training opportunities in their own towns so that families do not have to drive hours from home for their children to learn about the performing arts. 

But we need your help to bring these stories of hope to rural communities in Alberta!

Where your money will be going:

  • Transportation - It takes a lot of funds to transport sets, props, costumes, and a cast to multiple locations.
  • Rehearsal Space - We need somewhere to rehearse our shows before we take them on the road, and renting a space to do so costs a lot. So your funds will help us pay for time in a rehearsal hall where we can take our shows from the script to the stage.
  • Advertisements - We need people to know about us and the stories of hope we are telling! We want to create a new website for our company as well as posters, business cards, and brochures so that these rural communities know about us and what we offer! 
  • People - We like to pay people for the hard work they do! For each show we produce, we need to pay actors, directors, designers,  and many other people who are already working for free to keep this company going. 
  • Rights and Licencing - We have to pay performance rights for each show we produce. This money goes to the playwrights who created the scripts we are performing. We also have fees such as SOCAN rights which allow us to play music in our shows.  

Light in the Dark Theatre's past shows: 

  • Dani Girl by Micheal Kooman and Christopher Dimond; performed in Rosebud, Alberta. 

  • Twisted Tales: Snow White by Adam Furfaro; performed in Peace River, Alberta 

  • Punch Up by Kat Sandler; performed in Rumsey, Alberta 

Light in the Dark Theatre's Upcoming Shows: 

  • Never Swim Alone by Daniel MacIvor; to be performed at the 2019 Edmonton Fringe Festival

We are hoping to produce another show this coming fall which will tour to multiple rural communities in Alberta, but we need your help to make this become a reality!

If you are able to donate and help us bring theatrical opportunities to rural Alberta communities please do, but we understand if you are unable to contribute financially at this time.

There are other ways you can help us:

Get the word out! Share this campaign link with others.

Share and Like our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/lightinthedarktheatre/

Follow us on Twitter: Light in the Dark Theatre

Follow us on Instagram at: Light in the Dark Theatre 

Tell a friend about our company!

Look for us at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival and see our production of Never Swim Alone by Daniel MacIvor

If you want Light in the Dark to come to your community, contact us at  lightinthedarktheatre@gmail.com

story:
Please note this production will no longer be going ahead, sadly.  Despite the venue being sorted, sufficient funds raised to pay the deposit; band and technical team booked; props and costumes sourced; rehearsals going well; the author's interest and even H.R.H. Prince Andrew's Support.

For all those who have supported our two crowdfunding campaigns, a big thank you.  I am currently in the process of refunding everyone, so please bear with me.

story:
Beautiful Joe will leap to the stage this May in his hometown of Meaford, Ontario in this celebrated theatrical adaptation by Canadian Playwright, Michael O'Brien.

Beautiful Joe is the true story of a mongrel dog who escapes a life of cruelty, abuse and torture.  After being rescued by Laura, his soon to be life-long human companion, Joe confronts his fears and through an incredible act of bravery, becomes Canada's first pet hero.  Canadian author Margaret Marshall Saunders wrote the story in 1893 following a visit to Meaford, Ontario, the home of the real Beautiful Joe.  Her story became the first Canadian novel to be printed in several different languages and sell over a million copies. 

In 2009, a group of volunteers from the Beautiful Joe Heritage Society, with the help of the Grey-Bruce Arts Collective commissioned acclaimed playwright, Michael O'Brien to adapt Marshall Saunders' novel for the stage.  O'Brien's adaptation truly captures the endearing human-like qualities of the animal characters, something that has set this novel apart from any other while at the same time introducing this century old story to a modern audience.   Many of the animal characters wear masks or are puppets, yet the magic of this story is in the depiction of Joe.  Roger Shank, director, does not put Joe in a mask so through the actor's human face,  Joe's feelings and thoughts to brought to the forefront, which mirrors the writing of Marshall Saunders.  

The Grey-Bruce Arts Collective, established in 2008 by Roger Shank, Jamie Robinson and Julie Miles, is focused on sharing and re-telling local tales in a theatrical setting as well as providing educational workshops in theatre and film.   In 2010, they presented the 100 Mile Playwright Festival, where the public reading of Beautiful Joe received much praise and acclaim. 

The Beautiful Joe Heritage Society was formed to preserve, honour, and showcase the life of their local canine hero Beautiful Joe.  The society continually updates Beautiful Joe Park in Meaford, maintain Paradise Island, a serene place in Beautiful Joe Park, where your animal companion can be remembered with a memorial plaque and/or tree, and they are working toward a Beautiful Joe Museum in Meaford.  

Since that time, a workshop production was held as part of the SpringWorks Festival in Stratford, Ontario.  Audiences young and old fell in love with Joe and the play was very well received. 

We are a group of professional, experienced theatre artists and dedicated volunteers with a mutual passion for theatre and our animal companions.  Animal cruelty is still on the rise and this play gives the animals a voice, the voice they don't have in real life.  We want to 'shout to the world' Joe's incredible story starting with the World Premiere, in Joe's hometown, Meaford, this May.   

With cautious canine steps, we know this is only the beginning.  Our plans include  an annual presentation of the play, so Joe can leap to the stage year after year delighting and inspiring audiences of all ages. 

Throw us bone and you will be giving a voice to all dogs, cats, birds, hamsters, snakes, every animal.  Through this public performance, Joe's message will touch the hearts of many young people  - even if we save one animal from a life of cruelty, we will consider it a success. 

We need to generate at least $45,000 to let the leash go on Beautiful Joe.  We have worked very hard in the past year to raise funds from various sources - which include the Ontario Arts Council, the Municipality of Meaford, the Meaford Hall and Culture Foundation, Muxlow Pharmacy and individual donations.  We are almost there, but we need an additional $5,000 to free Joe from his life on the page and have professional artists bring him to life onstage. 

For your generous donations, our perks include: 

-Memorial Plaque for your favourite animal companion to be eternally remembered in Beautiful Joe park beside our hero's resting place.  

-An overnight stay at a B&B in Meaford

-Tickets to a performance

-Tax Receipts 

If we don't reach our goal the acquired funds would be directed to marketing (to spread word) and maintaining professional production values.   We are puppy steps away from reaching our goal and with your contribution to Beautiful Joe, you will be investing in the health and welfare of all animals and the preservation of Joe's story for future generations.

Here is what people have to say about Beautiful Joe:

“Beautiful Joe is a lovely retelling of a story I fondly remembered from childhood. The company succeeds at the great challenge of combining human and animal characters in a way that makes both believable and relatable to adult and young audiences. The kids and grownups at the performance I saw were spellbound.”

ShiraGinsler,  Education and Editorial Coordinator, Stratford Festival

"As I watched and listened tothiscleveradaptation ofthe novel Beautiful Joe, I was transported to a world seen throughthe eyes of Joe... The reading by these very gifted actors seemed to take on more than the essence of the characters in the novel, but also captured a fragment of life in the 1800's. All-consuming and absorbing to experience. Well done!"

Vivian Baker, Board Member, Beautiful Joe Heritage Society


Other Ways You Can Help:

Spread the Word.  If contributing is not for you, then please consider sharing our story with your friends.  We have a Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/BeautifulJoebyGBAC

If you happen to be in the Grey-Bruce area, we would love for you to visit. Bring your dog to the park and enjoy what Meaford has to offer.  We are always looking for volunteers and if you could spare an hour or two, it would be much appreciated. 


The Beautiful Joe Team

Playwright: Michael O'Brien

Director: Roger Shank

Design Consultant: Tamara Marie Kucheran

Acting Company:  Ryan Boyko, Mackenzie Muldoon, Loretta Bailey, Brendan Rowland, Brett Brownlee, Wilex Lee, Mandy London

Stage Manager: Leslie Jost

Producer: Julie Miles

Chair of the Beautiful Joe Heritage Society: Evelyn Dean

Administrative Co-Ordinator: Tania Gurr

story:
What is Hybridge Arts Collective?

Hybridge Arts Collective was founded in 2010 by Britney Hines, Sam Tower, and Kelly Turner. The primary mission of Hybridge Arts is to produce new and emerging artists in Philadelphia and to educate developing artists in the essentials of self producing. 

To achieve this mission, we produce two performance platforms, Last Mondays and Blueprint Breakout Series.

Last Mondays, which returns to Philly in June and July, is a one-night-only forum designed to showcase artists' current work-in-progress. The line-up always includes performance makers of multiple artistic disciplines, allowing audiences and artists to engage with new forms. 

This October we continue Blueprint Breakout Series, a self-producing incubator program geared towards emerging artists with bold ideas for medium to full length works. Hybridge partners with an artist over 3 months as they create an original project. Over the course of the incubator, Hybridge mentors the artist on the essential skills of self-producing. The curriculum includes lessons and resources in marketing, fundraising, press relations, and technical production. The artist in residence concludes the incubator with two nights of performance in a Philadelphia venue.

Hybridge Arts will kick off its fourth season of year-round programming in February with ID:3, a triple bill of new performance works, presented at Christ Church Neighborhood House. ID:3 features three mid-length dance and theatre works; SBF: Single Black Female  by Britney Hines, Beast by Kelly Turner and THE TRAVELERS by Sam Tower. The evening’s performances tackle the complexity of personal and social identity in modern society.

(Image from MOSQUE by Jihad Milhem. Photo © Jacques-Jean Tiziou / www.jjtiziou.net )

The secondary mission of Hybridge Arts Collective is to present affordable and accessible performance art that pushes boundaries. We keep the ticket price at $5 for Last Mondays and Blueprint Breakout Series and the evening always includes a delicious home-cooked vegetarian meal.

As we continue to improve our performance quality and provide our artists with better resources, our production costs are inevitably going up. We want to keep our ticket prices as low as possible, so we can continue to provide the highest standard of work at the most affordable rate.

Where does the money go? 

This Indiegogo Campaign will raise funds for our fourth year of affordable performance by new and emerging artists.

We are fundraising for a total of $4000. 

The money raised in this campaign will help fund our operating expenses as they increase this year. In 2014, we will produce the two performance series our audiences have come to love, plus an additional triple bill platform!

These increased expenses include:

  • Space rental and co-working space
  • Stipend for Blueprint Breakout Artists 
  • Technical supplies 
  • Designer and Production Manager Stipends
  • Website service fees
  • Insurance
  • Food costs

 The Impact

Hybridge Arts Collective is one of the few organizations that is dedicated to serving new and emerging performance artists in Philadelphia. The majority of our artists have been presenting work professionally in Philadelphia for less than five years.

Last Mondays fosters a space where artists can meet creators from different disciplines, introduce their work to new audiences, and share a sense of community. Blueprint Breakout Series provides an emerging artist the chance to learn more about self-producing in Philadelphia through workshops and hands on experience. 

(Image of Last Mondays Performance Series at Broad Street Ministry)


Hybridge Arts Collective is committed to producing  “the most affordable art in Center City Philadelphia.” For only $5 a patron experiences an evening of unique performance art and enjoys a family-style dinner. Clearly, this is the best bargain in town and allows us to reach numerous parts of the community. 

This year, we were able to produce the work of 5 emerging artists through Blueprint Breakout Series and we served over 400 audience members. Over the course of next year, we want to reach even more audiences with a season that will feature up to 14 individual artists’ original work!

Check out some of the artists we have presented in Blueprint Breakout Series and Last Mondays:

Amelia Longo, Stuart Meyers, Jay Milhem, JD Stokely, Petra Floyd, Jenna Horton, Ezra Donner, Loren Groenendaal, Les “el malito” Rivera, Danse4Nia, Melissa Dunphy, Marcel Williams Foster, Nicole Bindler, Comedy Dreamz, Jaamil Kosoko, and so many more! 

Other Ways You Can Help! 

  • Please share this campaign with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, blogs, and any other social media platforms you may use. 
  • We also accept in-kind donations of technical equipment, meeting space (i.e. spare conference room/office we can hold our meetings in), rehearsal space, and food. Contact: brie@hybridgearts.org 
  • Visit our website and read our blog for updates on everything Hybridge Arts! 
  • If you are a new and emerging artist please apply to be a part of Last Mondays and Blueprint Breakout this year!

story:
STORY

Kim Tobin & Philip Lehl started STARK NAKED THEATRE because they believed there was a need for a professional theatre company in Houston dedicated to a simple mission with its primary objectives being to - create extraordinary professional theatre and pay  the professional artists who create those productions the wages they deserve in accordance to the training and expertise that would be afforded any expert in any field coming out of college, or an equitable training program with a highly specialized skill set.    The name Stark Naked is a reflection of our philosophy in all things -  being truthful or to be "naked" and honest in our artistic work and all things in our company.

Match Challenge

A group of regular Stark Naked Theatre donors have come together and made a $25,000 challenge for the Stark Naked Theatre to match!!  If we can raise $25k they will donate $25k making it a total of $50,000 toward paying artists for the remaining 3 shows of our 2014-2015 season.  As you know what we charge for admission to our performances only covers 1/3 of the production costs for the high caliber professional theatre Stark Naked is committed to bring to our audiences.  We depend on individual donors along with grants and corporate sponsors to support and fill in the remaining operating costs for our theatre.  
ALL FUNDS RAISED IN THIS CAMPAIGN GO DIRECTLY TO ARTISTS PAY.
We believe in full transparency at Stark Naked and our budget for artists (actors/designers/directors/crew) this year is $74,615.00.  That number only pays our union artists $250 a week and our non-union artists about $129 a week.  We still have quite a long way to go before we are able to pay our artists a living wage here at Stark Naked, but the progress we have made in our short life span as a company is because of all of you! Your passion and support for what we are doing is our inspiration!  We could not do it without your willingness to help fund and support the continuation of the extraordinary productions Stark Naked works diligently to bring to our audiences.  YOU MAKE THIS HAPPEN with your continual financial support of our efforts and we would cease to exist without you!

Our Achievements

This year we Kim Tobin-Lehl and Philip Lehl received Best Artistic Director's at The Houston Press Theatre Awards in August, 2014.  The home of Stark Naked Theatre also received "Best Gem of a Theatre" at the awards ceremony and Philip Lehl received the "Best Trooper" award for his amazing performance - stepping in at the last minute -  in the lead role of The Winter's Tale.  We also received seven other nominations, including all acting categories and directing.  We received the Houston Press MasterMind Award for 2013.  Also, in 2013 at the Houston Press Theatre Awards Stark Naked Theatre was awarded Best Play in the Houston Community for our production of God of Carnage by Yasmina Reza; as well as Best Supporting Actor - David Matranga in our production of Macbeth.  We also received  nominations for:  Best Season, Best Artistic Directors, Best Actress, Best Actor, and Best Supporting Actor.  Stark Naked also received Best Play in Houston from Broadway World last year for our Production of Body Awareness by Annie Baker.  In addition, for the outstanding quality of our work and contribution to the theatre scene in Houston, Stark Naked Theatre was invited to be a source theatre company for the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize.

Our Mission

To develop and support theatrical artists by providing competitive pay. To develop and promote an aesthetic of acting that is truthful by producing exciting, cutting-edge, live theatre.

Our Vision

Stark Naked Theatre Company will encourage artists to stay in Houston, to develop their craft and have life-long careers here.

Stark Naked Theatre Company aims to develop and educate the Houston audience’s understanding and attitude toward theater and acting from being one of pastime, to one of mainstay.

Stark Naked Theatre Company aims to be a nexus organization in Houston for artists, audiences, and arts administrators from across the city to forge a pipeline of tangible resources that will enrich theater companies at every level.

Stark Naked Theatre Company will be an incubator for new ideas that will lead to a richer, more diverse, financially stable community, which contributes to the overall quality of life in Houston.

Stark Naked Theatre Company will play a crucial role in maintaining and growing the vibrancy of our local economy through its arts education and training programs.

Stark Naked Theatre Company will promote an aesthetic of performance that is truthful and is based on specific acting theory for the edification of our audiences

What We Need & What You Get

We need $25,000 in order to get $25,000 and that is only a portion of what we need to fund the rest of our 2014-2015 season.  The 25k you donate in this campaign will go directly to artists pay.  For your donations you can get some pretty great gifts - check out the different perks at different giving levels!  The more you give the cooler the perks get!

      Risks & Challenges

      This season has some big challenges for Stark Naked!  We are doing four full productions for the first time and that means a spike in our operating budget.  We need you in order to make this growth happen for us!  We have some big productions on our list and in order for them to come into full fruition in the manner we envision them, they require adequate funding!  We count on our individual donors and corporate sponsors to keep us on their annual giving lists so that our dreams for our artists and the realizations of these productions can become reality!  Without this funding corners have to be cut!  

        Other Ways You Can Help

        If you can't donate at this time yourself, but still believe in Stark Naked Theatre there are ways you can always help!  The most important thing you can do is come to the theatre and see our shows!  You can also continue to spread the word about Stark Naked and if you are so inclined feel free to pass this campaign along to your friends who might want to support Stark Naked and donate based on our artistic principles and vision for theatre in Houston.

        SEE YOU AT THE THEATRE!

        Thank you,

        Kim Tobin-Lehl & Philip Lehl

        Co-Artistic Directors
story_txt:
STORY
Kim Tobin & Philip Lehl started STARK NAKED THEATRE because they believed there was a need for a professional theatre company in Houston dedicated to a simple mission with its primary objectives being to - create extraordinary professional theatre and pay  the professional artists who create those productions the wages they deserve in accordance to the training and expertise that would be afforded any expert in any field coming out of college, or an equitable training program with a highly specialized skill set.    The name Stark Naked is a reflection of our philosophy in all things -  being truthful or to be "naked" and honest in our artistic work and all things in our company.
Match Challenge

A group of regular Stark Naked Theatre donors have come together and made a $25,000 challenge for the Stark Naked Theatre to match!!  If we can raise $25k they will donate $25k making it a total of $50,000 toward paying artists for the remaining 3 shows of our 2014-2015 season.  As you know what we charge for admission to our performances only covers 1/3 of the production costs for the high caliber professional theatre Stark Naked is committed to bring to our audiences.  We depend on individual donors along with grants and corporate sponsors to support and fill in the remaining operating costs for our theatre.

story:
The Team 
Bernard Smith...................................................................Mackian Bauman
Jimmie Kulkland...............................................................James Clements
David Camper...................................................................Joe Pietropaolo
Braden Dunne...................................................................Jean-Luc McMurtry
Assistant Director / Stage Manager..............................Ana Schuler
Lighting Design.................................................................Elizabeth Stewart
Costume & Set Designs...................................................Lauren Barber
Sound Design...................................................................Jorge Morales
Poster Design...................................................................Jeremy Ehlinger
Written, produced and directed by Sam Hood Adrain


The Project 
Sources Of Light Other Than The Sun is an unnerving and unrelenting examination of five weeks in the trenches on The Western Front of WWI. The story concentrates on the lives of four young soldiers enduring all the horrors of modern warfare; a generation trying to make sense of the new and chaotic world that is forming around them. Examining the physical and emotional traumas experienced during the Great War, Sources Of Light… attempts to capture a snapshot of what life was for these men. Taking place in near-total darkness, the vita of its characters is brought to light.

Where is my money going? 
Our show has been accepted in the 2016 Thespis Festival in NYC, but in order to bring it to life, there are a number of things that we need. The goals of this campaign are two-fold:
The first is practical, it costs money to do a show. Your contributions will be used for:
  • Rehearsal space rental
  • Purchase of props and costumes
  • Printing of promotional material and programs
  • Other inherent costs of producing a play in New York City.
The second reason for this campaign is to raise money to compensate the artists involved in this project. Too often young artists are asked to donate their talents in the name of having a "learning experience". We want to pay our artists for their time and the use of their amazing talent. While we will of course not be providing them with a Broadway salary, a small stipend can go a long way in the life of a freelancer.
Your contributions are ESSENTIAL to the success of this show; and without you, we simply cannot make it happen. Even one dollar can make a difference!

Where is this happening? 

Sources Of Light Other Than The Sun will be presented at the Hudson Guild Theatre on West 26th street in New York City. There will be three performances in the first week of August. Tickets will be available both online and at the door. 

The dates and times are:

August 1st at 9:00pm

August 3r at 9:00pm

August 6th at 3:30pm

If I don't have any money, what can I do to help? 

If you can't help us out monetarily, we understand! There are still a plethora of other ways to get involved.You could:

  • Share our campaign on your social media accounts to help get the word out.
  • Volunteer to donate props or costumes
  • Come see and support our show!

story:
Circle's New Terrain...

Since 1990 Circle Modern Dance has been providing opportunities for area dance professionals, community members and underserved populations; connecting them to local audiences through innovative and engaging performances and dance education. 

We we create unexpected opportunities and powerful collaborations. Our motto is that "Every body is dancer, and every body has the right to dance."

CMD is thrilled to present New Terrain, a summer choreographic showcase and World Refugee Day event at The Standard on Jackson Avenue June 19th and 20th at 7:30pm. 

Please help us to fund our summer show and in return, you can receive tickets as perks. 

  • We are hoping to raise $850 to help us pay for a beautiful and exciting downtown Knoxville venue!
  • You can receive tickets to the show as well as seat cushions, class passes, private lessons and more! 
  • Every penny we raise will go toward paying for the venue as well as paying the choreographers and production crew. 

Searching for a place to call home...

We offer something that no other local organization does, and we need your support to share our work in an inspiring venue which we hope can become our new home for spring and summer shows. This performance is giving a voice to 11 local choreographers and also shares the stories of local refugees who have come to Knoxville in search of a place to call home. Circle has a long history of collaborating with social organizations in the creation of meaningful dance experiences. This time we are partnering with Bridge Refugee Services for World Refugee Day. Celebrations begin on Friday June 20th at 5pm. 

Please come see our show and share our campaign with your friends!

story:
Who Are We?

Since 1978 World Arts West (WAW) has presented the San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival, now a month-long celebration of classical and contemporary world dance and music.  Hailed by critics as "Powerful," "Transcendent," and "Exploding perceptions of ethnic dance," the Festival helps local artists sustain their cultural traditions while building bridges of cultural understanding.  


What are We Doing?

Preparation for the 2014 Festival will begin in January when performing artists from more than 91 groups will audition for an opportunity to perform in the 36th Annual San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival.  Over three days, exquisitely dressed dancers will vie before an expert panel and a packed audience in the 2000 seat Zellerbach Hall.  The panel of dance experts and the Festival's Artistic Directors will evaluate each performance based on several criteria, including choreography, dance technique of the performers and cultural authenticity.  Ultimately, approximately 30 groups will be chosen to perform in the Festival itself in June 2014.

Audience members at the Festival auditions enjoy not only a rich offering of world dance but also a peek behind the curtain--a chance to see the beginnings of creation of a dance festival.


All photos by RJ Muna                                

Why Indiegogo?

Do you believe cultural education should be part of every child's education? So do we!  Do you rue the day when dance and music disappeared from school curriculums?  So do we!  We want you to join with us in an effort to reintroduce dance, music and cross-cultural expression into the lives of Bay Area youth.  

Expanding the audience for world dance and assuring that audiences of any age, on any budget, can experience it is part of WAW's mission.  By pricing tickets for the Festival auditions as low as possible ($10) WAW tries to expand the number of people who can enjoy Festival-quality performances.  Nonetheless we know that any admission charge can be a barrier.  With this Indiegogo, we plan to eliminate that barrier for at least 1200 children.  We plan to raise funds to pay for their tickets so that they can attend free of charge.  If more than 1200 children attend the auditions, WAW will admit them as well--free of charge.

How will the money be used?

Festival auditions are very expensive to mount.  The money raised by this Indiegogo, even when added to the amount charged for adult tickets, will not cover audition expenses.  Among the expenses which this Indiegogo will support are:

  • Stage crew and sound engineering expenses
  • Documentation of the auditions for curatorial purposes
  • Lodging and travel for Audition Panelists
  • Marketing of Zellerbach Hall auditions.


Risks of this Indiegogo


Our audition venue has already been rented.  91 individual dancers and groups of dancers have completed applications for the January auditions which assures three days of extraordinary, culturally diverse dance.  WAW is now identifying audition panelists who, in collaboration with WAW's Artistic Directors, have the necessary expertise to select 30 individual performers or groups of performers from the 91 who audition.  In short, the auditions will go forward.  With your help, 1200 children will be able to attend them free of charge!


photo RJ Muna

story:
The Upstart Crows of Salem are a brand new, collaboratively run classical theatre company based in Salem, Massachusetts, just north of Boston. We’re a group of young actors and artists who banded together three months ago to create our own space to make theatre and explore the plays of Shakespeare, his contemporaries, and other non-realistic dramatists. We’re passionate about telling stories and persuading you, the audience, to enter into a different world by giving you what a night out at the theatre ought to be: an enjoyable evening’s entertainment. When you come to our show, we hope you’ll be fascinated and moved and challenged, but above all, we want you have fun! Come out and play with us.

The Upstart Crows are currently in rehearsal for our first production, William Shakespeare’s Love’s Labour's Lost, which runs June 6-8 at the Gazebo on Salem Common- and admission will be FREE! It’s a witty, fast-paced, hysterically funny romantic comedy that’s spiked with a streak of darkness and plays fast and loose with our usual idea of its genre. Set in the late 1920s, our production takes full advantage of the lush yet elegant backdrop of Salem Common and features original music composed by local musician Jasmine Meyers. On June 7, we’ll present a teaser excerpt from the play at the Salem Arts Festival. We can’t wait to work with the Arts Festival and bring our play into the middle of Salem to share with the city! The cast and crew are hard at work bringing Love’s Labour's to life, and many of us are doing double duty, working not only as actors but as directors, designers, business managers, dramaturgs, publicists, photographers- name the job, and you can bet one of us is onto it. And we’re learning as we go: none of us has ever run our own theatre company before. So far, every penny we’ve spent on the Upstart Crows and Love’s Labour's Lost has come out of our own pockets. Now we’re asking for your generous help to make sure that our production reaches the stage with all our bills paid. In addition to meeting the expenses of costumes, set, technical equipment, advertising, and much more, we offer our cast and crew members a small stipend of $50 per person. Every member of the company is working exceptionally hard, and as professional working artists who have chosen to pour their time, energy, and resources into this production, they deserve our heartfelt thanks. We only wish we could offer them more.

Your contribution will help us in so many ways. Here are just a few of the expenses you’ll be helping us to meet:

$15 pays for 7 paper lanterns to adorn our set

$25 pays for 50 beautiful posters to advertise our play around the local area

$35 pays for the fabric for the Princess of France’s evening dress

$50 pays a stipend to help reimburse a cast or crew member for their transportation expenses

$75 pays the required fee to the City of Salem for the use of Salem Common

$100 pays for all of our props and makeup

$150 pays for a portable toilet rental so that our audience can enjoy the second half of the show in comfort

Every cent of out $1500 target amount will be spent on this production of Love’s Labour's Lost. $1000 will cover stipends for every member of the cast and crew. The remaining $500 will be devoted to diverse production needs such as costumes, advertising, and port-o-pottie rental (we weren’t kidding when we said our needs were diverse). If we don’t meet our target goal, the show will still go on, with whatever sum we have raised- but we’d much prefer to go onstage fully funded, with your help. We’ve got some great Shakespeare-themed souvenirs lined up to thank you for your contributions (check them out below!) And each and every one of you will receive credit for your generosity in our program- unless you prefer to mysteriously veil your identity under the title “Anonymous.” Just let us know what you prefer.

By contributing to our campaign, you’re ensuring that the Upstart Crows kick off our first production standing on solid ground and enable us to invest in the future of our company. The less we as a company are forced to worry about money, the more we’re free to focus on creating the best show possible for our audiences. If we can meet all of our expenses for this production up front, any donations that we receive during the run of the show (admission to every performance is free, with donations gratefully accepted) will be invested in future productions. Summer street theatre in downtown Salem, full-length indoor productions of Shakespeare and other playwrights of his time, medieval mystery plays, a May Day festival, programs for kids…we’ve got so much to offer, so many stories to tell and dreams to make real. This is our beginning, and we want you to be a part of it.

If you really, truly can’t donate to our campaign (and believe us, we do understand), there’s still something important you can do. Share this page on social media, Like our Facebook page and visit our new blog! If you know someone in the Boston area who might enjoy our show, point them in our direction! Keep in touch, and we hope we’ll see your face out in the crowd one night.

$50 pays a stipend to help reimburse a cast or crew
member for their transportation expenses
$75 pays the required fee to the City of Salem for the
use of Salem Common
$100 pays for all of our props and makeup
$150 pays for a portable toilet rental so that our
audience can enjoy the second half of the show in comfort
Every cent of out $1500 target amount will be spent on
this production of Love’s Labour's Lost.
$1000 will cover stipends for every member of the cast and crew. The remaining
$500 will be devoted to diverse production needs such as costumes, advertising,
and port-o-pottie rental (we weren’t kidding when we said our needs were
diverse). If we don’t meet our target goal, the show will still go on, with
whatever sum we have raised- but we’d much prefer to go onstage fully funded,
with your help. We’ve got some great Shakespeare-themed souvenirs lined up to
thank you for your contributions (check them out below!) And each and every one
of you will receive credit for your generosity in our program- unless you
prefer to mysteriously veil your identity under the title “Anonymous.” Just let
us know what you prefer.
By contributing to our campaign, you’re ensuring that
the Upstart Crows kick off our first production standing on solid ground and
enable us to invest in the future of our company. The less we as a company are
forced to worry about money, the more we’re free to focus on creating the best
show possible for our audiences. If we can meet all of our expenses for this
production up front, any donations that we receive during the run of the show
(admission to every performance is free, with donations gratefully accepted)
will be invested in future productions. Summer street theatre in downtown
Salem, full-length indoor productions of Shakespeare and other playwrights of
his time, medieval mystery plays, a May Day festival, programs for kids…we’ve
got so much to offer, so many stories to tell and dreams to make real. This is
our beginning, and we want you to be a part of it.
If you really, truly can’t donate to our campaign (and
believe us, we do understand), there’s still something important you can do. Share
this page on social media, Like our Facebook page and visit our new blog! If
you know someone in the Boston area who might enjoy our show, point them in our
direction! Keep in touch, and we hope we’ll see your face out in the crowd one
night.

story:
Brief Summary 

If ever I have poured my heart into a project, it is this one.

I am guessing that if you are on this page you already know a little bit about me, Sabrina, but here is some more info to round out the picture.

I founded Fée Fatale in 2010 to create unexpected theatrical experiences by collaborating with artists from all disciplines. For my non-french-speaking friends, that’s pronounced ‘fay.’ I liked the idea of reclaiming a word with negative connotations FÉE (or fey) and pairing it with FATALE to redefine an image of feminine as powerful.

I come from a background of traditional theatre training (Carnegie-Mellon University / 11 years in NYC) but very unconventional creation experience (bluemouth inc.) From the traditional, I continue to seek unity of action, but believe that there are many ways to create a beginning, middle and end, many definitions of the word story, and many media through which to achieve dramatic tension. Collaborations with musicians, dancers, visual artists, actors and multi-disciplinary artists reveal that while the vocabulary is different the search is much the same. 

I began working on Blindsided in 2012. I spent a year writing it with Matt Holland as script consultant, and another year shooting video and developing the interaction between video and live performance with Matt Holland, Paolo Santos, Lucie Bélanger, Jacques Poulin-Dénis and Marilène Bastien. The show previewed in Montreal in December of 2013. In order for the piece to have a life beyond that 3-day run in Montreal, it needs to be seen by a broader audience, specifically one that includes potential presenters. 

Summerworks will provide us with just that opportunity.

What We Need

(3) projectors $1,800
(2) screens $200
U-Haul to / from Toronto $300
Additional sound recording $300
Additional cinematography $400
Stage Manager $1,000
Video Programmer $1,000

The Team:

Writing / Performance: Sabrina Reeves

Direction: Matt Holland

Cinematography: Paolo Santos

Video Installation: Lucie Bélanger

Sound Design: Jacques Poulin-Denis

Set/Costume Design: Marilène Bastien

Stage Management: Lisa Humber

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can't contribute, that's OK. You can help out by spreading the word about the campaign and the show. And if you are in TO, please come see us!

Thank you for your support.

story:
HEY THERE, Indiegogo!

I'm Apphia Campbell, founder of the Shanghai-based Play the Spotlight Theatre and writer and performer of the one-woman show Black Is the Color of My Voice. After producing three successful runs of Black Is the Color in both Shanghai and New York City, the PtS team and I are now looking for your help to take our work to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe this August!

Thanks for checking out our funding page and considering supporting Black Is the Color. Every donation counts towards making this very expensive dream a financial reality for Play the Spotlight, and we very dearly appreciate any and all help you can send our way!

THE STORY

Black Is the Color of My Voice follows the life of Mena Bordeaux, a successful jazz singer seeking redemption after the untimely death of her father. During a three-day period of isolation without cigarettes, alcohol, or access to the outside world, Mena reflects on the journey that took her from a young piano prodigy destined for a life in the service of the church to a renowned jazz vocalist at the forefront of the Civil Rights Movement.

INSPIRATION

About five years ago I began learning about the life of legendary jazz singer Nina Simone. Deeply affected by her music, I was particularly drawn to a specific time in her life in which she underwent a period of isolated spiritual cleansing in Liberia. I was very interested in that idea--what kind of experience would that woman have in thatenvironment, cut off from the outside world, making peace with her past? I created the character of Mena Bordeaux to explore that environment, a physical space and narrative structure reflecting a mediation between the past and present, the living and the dead. Black Is the Color of My Voice is the result of that exploration.

CRITICAL RECEPTION

So far, Black Is the Color of My Voice has had three successful runs--two in Shanghai and one at New York City's Midtown International Theatre Festival. We have had several sold-out shows, and the the response by both media and audience members has been truly extraordinary.

Here are a few things people have been saying:

  • "Black is the Color of My Voice shines, bringing a little bit of American soul to Shanghai theatre."      -TimeOut Shanghai
  • "Campbell transfixed, she charmed, she entertained and ultimately moved a packed theater with her touching portrayal of a jazz musician reeling and reminiscing in the aftermath of her father's death."      -SmartShanghai.com
  • "Memories of her life's most decisive moments and choices are evoked, flashbacks solely carried by Apphia's expressional performance and powerful singing voice, which do justice to her source of inspiration."     -Shanghaiist

WHY EDINBURGH?

While Shanghai's burgeoning theatre scene is a great place to develop and try new ideas within a supportive community, it's a very difficult city to produce or perform theatre on an international level. The Edinburgh Fringe is the world's largest arts festival and is one of the best places on Earth for small, independent work to be discovered. We've shown Shanghai what Black Is the Color has to offer and have been rewarded for our efforts--now it's time to take it to the next level.

WHERE YOUR MONEY GOES

Despite being called a one-woman show, it will take a whole group of talented people working together to make Black Is the Color of My Voice an Edinburgh success. Your financial backing will go a long way to help fund Play the Spotlight's three-person performer/producer/director team as we travel to Edinburgh and back, secure music licensing, distribute promotional materials, create merchandise, handle marketing and PR, and pay for a performance space while not going hungry, homeless, or crazy. Hopefully.

Risks and challenges

A dramatic one-woman show will need as much help as it can get in the comedy-centric atmosphere of the Festival Fringe. Once on the ground in Edinburgh, the 3-person PTS team needs a solid marketing foothold to gain a competitive edge.

Our number one priority is to have most of the production legwork in place before we ever leave Shanghai, leaving as few loose ends to tie up as possible so we can begin producing on Day 1. That said, this is theatre. Should challenges arise, and we certainly expect them to, we solemnly pledge to:

-Be prepared: Like I said, our first goal is to have things ready to go when we hit the ground. We will spend the months leading up to the festival preparing our marketing strategy and contacting the best people to help us with our show's particular needs.

-Listen to feedback: Luckily for us, we have a friendly network of friends and supporters who are smarter than we are and know more about Fringe success than we do. We respect that, and will heed their advice accordingly.

-Take deep, calming breaths: Three people living in close quarters for a month while pulling double-duty on marketing/performance shifts will naturally lead to tension. A level head is necessary at all times.

story:
Historic Interpretations, Inc. brings history to life!  With your help, we can bring our new version of the classic English Christmas Play, Saint George and the Dragon, to the Raleigh stage in time for Christmas!

Our new version is a charming retelling of the greatest of the mummer's plays, the folk plays of the Middle Ages.  The audience will travel back in time to the Christmas celebrations of long-ago, which begin with a parade of knights, princesses, kings, queens, and, of course, a dragon.  They'll witness miraculous medical practitioners who believe they can cure all ailments, and see Father Christmas preside over exaggerated sword and shield battles, Christmas Carols, madrigal songs, court dances, and the heroic, and romantic escapades, of England's great hero, Saint George. 

A composite version drawn from surviving manuscripts and woven together from bits of old text, folk legends, and medieval Christmas plays, the entire story is all told in the traditional rhymed dialogue used in the ancient plays, but with updated language for modern audiences.  So, join in making Saint George and the Dragon part of Raleigh's annual holiday traditions!

What We Need & What You Get

Producing a stage production can be expensive.  We have invested a substantial amount in rehearsal space, venue costs, marketing, and other production costs such as costumes, sets, and props.  We need you to help us cover these costs by sponsoring our production.

Sponsors can choose from an array of 'perks' including tickets to the show, program advertising, website listings, and tickets to our Mardi Gras Masquerade Ball on February 9th, 2013.

Our production is set to open at Burning Coal Theatre at the Murphey School on December 20th, 2012.  We hope you'll be able to join us.

The Impact

Your contribution will allow us to provide the highest production values possible as we prepare this show to become an annual holiday production in Raleigh, NC.  Your contribution will not only sponsor this year's production, but your investment will help us create lasting materials such as sets and costumes which can be used in the production for years and years to come.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

You can help spread the word about our campaign through social media and e-mail using the Indiegogo share tools.

Buy tickets to the show through our online ticket broker:
www.brownpapertickets.com/event/266532

Use our facebook event page to invite your friends to the show!
www.facebook.com/events/548385111843049/

For more information about our upcoming season of theatrical productions, please visit www.historystage.org.  For more information about our organization, Historic Interpretations, Inc., please visit www.historicinterpretations.org.

story:
The Freight Project 2015
Hello!
I am Rachael Shane and I am revving up for our 6th year of new work development at The Freight Project! 
The Freight Project is a developmental incubator which brings artists who work in different disciplines together to work in the same upstate new york town for one week. Each artist is provided food, housing, transportation and space to do with what they will. 
This week has supported 17 different projects get off their feet over the past 5 years and has created a pop up community of artists in upstate New York. 
We are lucky enough to be given space as part of the compound at Hubbard Hall. Hubbard Hall is a turn of the Century Open house where I grew up doing theater as a little kid. There is a black box theater, a dance studio, a music studio, and an ornate opera house/music hall.  There is a sophisticated community which is supportive of new work development and this creates the perfect environment for building new projects outside of New york City. 
As a New York based artist working in several different disciplines I started the Freight Project to build bridges between disciplines as well as create a immersive work environment in a beautiful and natural environment. New York City is bustling and stimulating in a way that can be both inspirational and overwhelming. New projects can get lost before they are realized because of three very difficult factors, time space and money. The Freight ventures to erase these factors and create a supportive an productive environment in the rolling hills of upstate New York. 
Help us make this possible. We are completely supported by our community. We are generously donated rehearsal space and housing, which leaves only the cost of transportation, production costs, and food. 
FOOD COSTS
$2000 we support all local farms a businesses!
TRANSPORTATION
$2050 Car rental/ buss tickets / Gas
INSURANCE 
$500
PROMOTIONAL MATERIALS
$450 programs/ posters/ adds
PRODUCTION COSTS
$1,000 Production /overhead/misc.

Thank you so much for reading and thank you for your support!

story:
"For this is the way of the world. Trying to cling to our goodness even as it’s being wrenched away from us. Trying to reclaim our goodness though all the cruelty of the world grows thickly over it." 

Short Summary

We are seeking $3000 to help make Splendour Without Diminishment a reality in the 2015 Chicago Fringe Festival. Splendour is a collaboration between playwright Matt Beard, director Sammy Zeisel, and a veritable cadre of talented actors and designers*

The play follows a Chicago woman who is mysteriously coming into contact with a refugee's story. Through poetry, movement, and interrogation the play raises questions about violence around the world, our complicity in it, and seeks to measure the lengths of human cruelty and kindness. 

*Starring: 

Beth Hyland, Enid Munoz, Abby Pajakowski, Ella Pennington, Brooklyn Smith, Alejandra Vivanco

Stage Manager: Megan Chaney

Set Design: Greg Culley

Sound Design/Composer: Patrick Budde

Producer/Marketing: Graham Emmons

Choreographer: Kat Scott

What We Need & What You Get

Putting on a play is expensive! We need money to book rehearsal space, pay for props, costumes, scenery, and provide small stipends to 11 professional theatre artists. Here's how it breaks down: 

  • Rehearsal Rental: $900
  • Set Budget: $250
  • Props/Costumes: $150
  • Administrative costs: $100
  • Fringe Festival Production Fee: $400
  • Artist Stipends: $1200

The Impact

Our project aims to start conversations as the audience leaves the theatre and raise questions about war, violence, and our complicity in global conflict as people who are, ourselves, far away from war torn places. 

Your support will help us reach a bigger audience, put on a better show, and make a bigger impact.

Risks & Challenges

Theatre isn't funded by ticket sales. Almost all theatre companies are non-profits and seek the help of grants for their production. This is why we need your help. We actually cannot do this without the generous support of viewers like you. 

I can't donate right now... Can I still help out?

Yes! Thanks for asking :) The best way to help out is to spread the word about the campaign. Post to facebook or send an email. And, of course, be sure to come to the show in September. Tickets are available here: 

https://www.vendini.com/ticket-software.html?t=tix&w=a910c7b7a7aaa988b2cb942a739f20cc

story:
The students of the University of San Diego's Producing & Directing class present:

 A NIGHT OF SCENES: S(he) loves me, S(he) loves me not  

in the Vassiliadis Black Box Theater on Monday, December 7th!  

Scenes from the following seven plays will be directed, produced, and performed by students: 

• August: Osage County by Tracy Letts 
• Cat on a Hot Tin Roof by Tennessee Williams
• Our Town by Thornton Wilder 
• Picnic by William Inge 
• The Aliens by Annie Baker 
• The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds by Paul Zindel
• The Great God Pan by Amy Herzog 

The purpose is to give real-life, hands-on directorial experience as each of the students audition, cast, hire crew and designers, and raise funds to put this production on.  Your support will not only fund a great night of classic scenes, but will also help students in their learning process.

what we need: 

As this production is patterned after the post-school theatre experience, we must raise the funds to cover the expenses of production ourselves without direct donations from the University.  Your donation will go to:

  • Costumes and sets for each of the eight scenes
  • Printing of programs, posters, and advertising
  • Any props, lighting, and sound needs

how you can help:

  • Donations of any size are welcome and greatly appreciated!
  • Please share this page!  
  • Don't forget to come and see the performance on December 7th!

Join us in bringing captivating & enchanting theatre to life! 
THANK YOU!

 A NIGHT OF SCENES: S(he) loves me, S(he) loves me not  
in the Vassiliadis Black Box Theater on Monday, December 7th!  Scenes from the following seven plays will be directed, produced, and performed by students: 
• August: Osage County by Tracy Letts • Cat on a Hot Tin Roof by Tennessee Williams• Our Town by Thornton Wilder • Picnic by William Inge • The Aliens by Annie Baker • The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds by Paul Zindel• The Great God Pan by Amy Herzog The purpose is to give real-life, hands-on directorial experience as each of the students audition, cast, hire crew and designers, and raise funds to put this production on.  Your support will not only fund a great night of classic scenes, but will also help students in their learning process.   what we need:  As this production is patterned after the post-school theatre experience, we must raise the funds to cover the expenses of production ourselves without direct donations from the University.  Your donation will go to:  Costumes and sets for each of the eight scenes Printing of programs, posters, and advertising Any props, lighting, and sound needs    how you can help:



Donations of any size are welcome and greatly appreciated!


Please share this page!  


Don't forget to come and see the performance on December 7th!


Join us in bringing captivating & enchanting theatre to life! THANK YOU!

story:
Short Summary

We are proud to present THE TWO-CHARACTER PLAY, one of Tennesse Williams' later, lesser-known works. 

Featuring: ROBIN JONES and SAM READ

Directed by: L. ZANE JONES

This bold, dangerous drama follows the journey of Clare and Felice, sibling actors with a questionable grasp on reality. Trapped in a theatre on the day of a performance, they find themselves abandoned by their theatre troupe and forced to perform in front of a hostile audience.  As they get lost in the play, they begin to rewrite the script in an attempt to face their demons and make sense of their lives.

CIVIC REP is a creative collective formed to make theater that is honest, intimate and immediate.

Civic Rep is: THEA COOPER, ANGIE HARRISON, ROBIN JONES, L.ZANE JONES, SAM READ


What We Need & What You Get

One of the biggest expenses when producing theater is REAL ESTATE! 

We are fundraising to cover the cost of the theater rental. 

Every penny you contribute will be used to pay for our time in the beautiful, intimate NEW CITY THEATER space on 18th and Union Street in Seattle.


The Impact

With your help - last January, our inaugural production of A STREETCAR NAMED DESIRE was a huge success, critically and at the box office as well. We sold out every performance during the run! And we couldn't have done it without your support. 

Let's do it again with this daring and exciting play! We appreciate so much any contribution you can make. 

CIVIC REP at New City Theater: THE TWO-CHARACTER PLAY

Previews: July 8, 9

Opens: July 10

Closes: August 1

story:
Who are we?

  • Down to Clown is a fledgling production company of artists looking to explore reclamation and agency through various disciplines. We're developing To Hell in a Handbasket, which explores these very themes, at the Kraine Theatre in July.

Time and Place

  • July 17th, 18th, 27th at 9 pm
  • July 28th at 10:30 pm

What We Need & What You Get

In order to make this workshop the best it can be, we are looking to raise $750. This will go be used for:
The Show!
(design, insurance, and rental fees)
$500 
Marketing and Promotion
(getting the word out!)
$250

The Impact

Your contribution helps support:

  • Down to Clown Productions, a group of like-minded young artists interested in exploring the dichotomy of agency and deference in today's society.
  • The development of an exciting new piece of theatre!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share and come to see us at the Kraine!

story:
University of the Arts is proud to present the first of the Dance Study Cycles as a new addition to the Continuing Studies program. Eleven students from the School of Dance at UArts have been hand chosen through a selective screening process for this exciting new program. Over three weeks these students will work towards preparing themselves to enter the ever expanding realm of contemporary dance by gaining a more international perspective.

Two weeks will be spent  studying at the University, under the guidance of world recognized artistic mentors including Sidra Bell/Sidra Bell Dance New York,Donna Faye Burchfield, Sara Procopio, Meredith Glisson, Jonathan Royse Windham, Rashaun Mitchell, Michelle Mola & Zack Winokur/The Troupe, and additional guest artists. The schedule includes daily studio practice, research and creation of choreographic work, conversations with artists, lectures, video viewings, studio showings and a culminating public performance.

One week will be spent in Avignon, France, at Festival d'Avignon. The students will be attending two performances daily and engaging with artists about their works and visions. 

Six students accepted to the 2013 Dance Study Cycles are seeking supplementary funding to cover travel expenses for the week in Avignon, France, a cost of approximately $3,000. This amount will cover air + land travel, lodging in Avignon, tickets to 2 shows per evening for 6 nights at the Festival d'Avignon, International Medical insurance, and two dinners in France. 

Please help these students reach their goal by donation and by sharing this campaign with as many supporters of dance as possible. All contributions are greatly appreciated!

The students in order of appearance: Shari Williams, Caitlin Dagle, Stephanie Carlos, Kianna Moye, Teddy Tedholm, Savannah Cobb.

Video editing: Teddy Tedholm

Voice and text: Kianna Moye

story:
Watch this video about ENVOY and Ensemble Atria:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u5OuANrE-kU
 
A brand new theatre company that is dedicated to creating art that inspires the heart needs your help.  Ensemble Atria (non-profit pending) is putting on a production of Envoy by Belinda Bremner for the Midtown International Theatre Festival.
 
Envoy captures a frightening moment when a group of young Americans traveling internationally volunteering for a Peace-Corps-type organization are captured and held hostage by the locals. Held for ransom, these young people come to terms with questions about how they've lived their lives and how to face the possible end of their lives with honor and dignity.
 
Belinda Bremner is a Chicago-based Jeff award winning actress and playwright. This Midtown production will mark the play's New York premiere. 
 
Victoria Rae Sook is Ensemble Atria's founder and Artistic Director.  She is also directing and performing in Envoy.  Victoria is an AEA, SAG-AFTRA New-York-based actress, dancer, singer, director, and playwright (www.victoriaraesook.com). 
 
Christopher Tefft is Envoy's producer.  He is an EMC New-York-based actor, singer, and producer (www.ChristopherTefft.net).  
 
Dianna Blaylock is Ensemble Atria's Pubicity Director and Industry Coordinator.  She is also performing in and Stage Managing Envoy.  Dianna is a SAG-AFTRA New-York-based actress (http://diannablaylock.wix.com/diannablaylock).
 
 
Full Envoy Cast List:
 
Peter- Brandon A. Wright

Andre- Siddiq Saunderson

Tom- JD Scalzo 

Matt- Carl Zurhorst 

Jacob- Colin Friend

Nat- Rebecca Vineyard

Simone- Coya Pruden

Chrissy- Dianna Blaylock 

Seanna- Camara McLaughlin

Judith- Ashley Farley

Pippa- Alicia Dawn Bullen* 

Jamie- Victoria Rae Sook*

 

(* denotes AEA member)

 
Envoy is performing as an AEA showcase in the Midtown International Theatre Festival on the Main Stage on the following dates: 
 
Wednesday, July 17th at 6pm
Sunday, July 21st at 2pm
Thursday, July 25th at 8pm
Saturday, July 27th at 5:30pm
Sunday, August 4th at 8pm
 
Tickets on Sale NOW : https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/cal/27845

story:
Who is Science Fiction Theatre Company?

Science Fiction Theatre Company's mission is to bring the genre of science fiction to the stage in the form of established, original and adapted works. We seek to build a community of like-minded individuals who look at fiction in terms of the possibilities. We seek to ask the question 'What is reality'. To further express what we are looking to achieve we refer to the following quote by the great author Philip K. Dick...

All of our work "starts with the basic assumption that there cannot be one, single, objective reality. Everything is a matter of perception. The ground is liable to shift under your feet. A protagonist may find himself living out another person's dream...that actually makes better sense than the real world, or he may cross into a different universe completely."

What is Solace?

If you could bring them back, wouldn’t you? The answer is obvious for Julia, whose husband is lost in space during a recent mission. Everyone from her boss to her own mother tells Julia that she needs to accept her loss and move on. But Julia knows in her heart that her husband is still out there, and that she's the only one who can find him.

Armed with her brilliant mind and a sarcastic GPS, Julia sets out to accomplish the impossible.

Solace is a new work written by A. Vincent Ularich and directed by Anna Trachtman. It follows Julia as she tries to convince the world that it’s not too late and get her husband back. Thomas, her husband, went missing while on a one man mission and is presumed dead. Being the brilliant person she is Julia builds a spaceship, “perfects” AI, and goes off to find him; but not before dealing with her over shadowing mother, her stressed out boss, and new friend. It’s an out-of-this-world drama about the motivations and perseverance of the human heart.

We’ve been working on this show for a while now. The first reading of the original draft was year ago. Since then the script has gone through several rewrites.  A staged reading of the first act was done for three nights last November . The main goal of the reading was to work shop the script and get some feedback. It was huge success! The biggest question asked: “when can we see the rest?” Well we’re finally ready to show the world what we've got! With a full cast and crew, a finale draft, and whole lot of passion we couldn’t be more excited.

We need your help though. Producing theatre isn’t cheap.  On top of paying everyone for their hard work, we need to pay for supplies, props, costumes, and rent for the actual theater. We have two full sets to construct; a living room and a space ship. A cast of six and a crew of seven and everyone is working overtime shoulder the weight. It really does take a village… errr a mission control to run a show.

We greatly appreciate any support you can give us, and in that way you’re joining our team. So help us send Julia to space!

What we need

Supplies (We’re building a spaceship!)

The set really is its own character. The lights, the sounds, the very look of the stage bring the show to life. We’re looking at $1200 for building supplies, lights, props, and costumes. The majority of these funds, $600, will go towards set construction.  

We need $300 for lighting and sound. It’s a tech heavy show with spaceships being launched, meteor showers, and sarcastic AIs.

Another $300 for costumes and props, because sometimes the clothes really do make the astronaut.

Stipends (It takes a village… errr a mission control)

It’s hard work and long hours to pull off something like this and we want to make sure everyone get paid. $1200 in stipends are going out to the cast and crew. Along with big big "thank you"s for making this all possible.

We need another $900 for renting the theater. For supporting us we are offering some pretty awesome perks. You should check them out!

Our Past Productions

This will be Science Fiction Theatre Company’s fourth production.

Dark Matters followed a woman and her family coping with the idea that she may have been the victim of an alien abduction.

On Ego was the story of routine teleportation gone wrong resulting in two versions of the protagonist. He had to make the ultimate sacrifice to allow his other self to live on.

Our last show Man in the Couch was about a soldier being teleported into a woman’s living room. Only problem is now he’s fused with her couch.

If you haven’t caught on yet we like SciFi. Especially shows that have those make it or break it moments.  Like teleporting a person into a couch. In front of the audience. And making it look believable.  We’re New England’s only exclusively science fiction theatre company and we’re proud to say it!

Other Ways you can help

If you can’t give to this fundraiser, there are still plenty of other ways you can help support us. Share this page with other people. Just tell people that we exist, word of mouth is still such a crucial way of getting the word out. And come see our show! Buying a ticket is actually a fantastic way to support us, a show isn’t really a show until it has an audience.

Opens May 10th and runs till May 25th.

Visit us at http://www.sciencefictiontheatrecompany.com/

story:
Tabitha Taboo

"A delectable mixture of frisky frolics and whimsicality, with a dash of European retro chic. Add to that a little B movie charm and a sprinkle of What The Butler Saw and you’ll find the main characteristics of her mise en scene.

In 2011 Tabitha stole the hearts of judges at London Burlesque Festival, taking away the award for Best New Striptease. She has since gone on to titillate and tease adoring audiences across the UK and Europe, returning to the festival’s World Burlesque Games Opening Ceremonies in 2012 as a special guest performer.

Allow yourself to be entranced by Tabitha as she takes you on a thrilling journey full of mischief and pleasure."

www.tabithataboo.com


The Show!

My stateside debut will take place at the The New York Burlesque Festival's Premiere Party on Friday 27th September. The festival goes on for 4 glittering days across several venues in the city. I'll perform alongside a variety of well respected names on the Burlesque scene in what I'm sure will be the highlight of my Burlesque career to date!

http://www.thenewyorkburlesquefestival.com/ 

 

The revealing truth...

In 2010 my life in Burlesque began, and it has taken me on an incredible adventure so far. The creative people I get to meet and work with never cease to amaze and inspire me, and there's nothing I'd rather do than this.

It's a dream job, but it still takes blood, sweat and tears to create an act that's just right. A hell of a lot of time and funds go into the lead up to those five glorious minutes on stage! But it's so worth it when you're presented with amazing opportunities.

I have just been invited to perform at this year's New York Burlesque Festival which, I'm not afraid to admit, is an absolute dream of mine. It is an unpaid performance (with the exception of a $25 honorarium, which might help with my transport from the airport!) but an unmissable opportunity nonetheless.

This trip will be purely for business, and as much as I would love to go and see the sights, that's something that will have to wait until another day when I can take a holiday!

I'm striving to make my appearance at The New York Burlesque Festival happen, but the truth is that I can't do it without your help.

I'll be keeping a diary of the events leading up to and during the festival so you can keep track of what's going on, I'll update you on my Facebook page: www.facebook.com/tabithataboo  and in the Tales of Taboo section on my website: www.tabithataboo.com so stay tuned!

 

Tit for tat...

My purpose here is not to raise the entire amount I need for the trip, but just enough to cover my flight and therefore ease some of the financial pressure. The minimum I am allowed to pitch for is £500 and so that will be the amount I will aim for. The flight will cost just over £480 and so the remaining £20 would be put towards getting my prop shipped over to NYC. If I do exceed my goal, then I shall lavish myself with Champagne and eat only the finest caviar for lunch!

Now, rarely do you get something for nothing...which is why in return for your contribution I'll be offering a variety of goodies, including exclusive signed and kissed pin up photos of yours truly, limited edition Tabitha Taboo artwork, and tickets to see a special one-off act performed in the heart of London's Soho! Just choose the reward you like the most, make your contribution, and hey presto...I'll be a few steps closer to showing NYC a little Taboo!

Important note: Whilst every contribution is gratefully accepted, please be aware that if you choose to pay by credit card, a large percentage of your contribution will be taken by fees. However, debit card is absolutely fine :)

 

And if you can't contribute...

Or there's nothing that tickles your fancy, don't worry, just help me by sharing this page, especially if there are Burlesque lovers amongst your friends. Every little will help me on my way.

And finally, wish me luck! :)

Tabitha Taboo x x x

Just choose the reward you like the most, make your contribution, and hey presto...I'll be a few steps closer to showing NYC a little Taboo!
Important note: Whilst every contribution is gratefully accepted, please be aware that if you choose to pay by credit card, a large percentage of your contribution will be taken by fees. However, debit card is absolutely fine :)



 
And if you can't contribute...



Or there's nothing that tickles your fancy, don't worry, just help me by sharing this page, especially if there are Burlesque lovers amongst your friends. Every little will help me on my way.
And finally, wish me luck! :)
Tabitha Taboo x x x

story:
WHO IS BALLET EAST?

Rodolfo Méndez founded Ballet East Dance Company in 1978 to bring dance to the historically underserved East Side where he was reared. He envisioned a modern dance company that would

·Aim for a high degree of artistry in modern dance with a strong base in ballet fundamentals,

·Encourage the development of individual dancers, and

·Champion original choreography.

Mr. Méndez also envisioned a dance company that would serve as a focal point for community pride and as an instrument for community development. In 1989, the Austin City Council asked Ballet East to work with the Austin Independent School District to develop a program for students at risk of dropping out of school. Dare to Dance concentrated on middle school, where the decision to drop out is often made, The program

·Offers high-level instruction and opportunities to perform, and

·Builds a network of support under each student.

Ballet East expanded its Dare to Dance after-school program with additional funding (Glimmer of Hope Foundation and Holly Neighborhood Assistance) to 60 students at Sánchez and Metz Elementary Schools (baile folklórico) and 60 students at Méndez Middle School, Dove Springs and Metz Recreational Centers (theater dance) and added hip-hop classes in addition to the long-standing folklórico classes at Martin Middle School. A total of 125 students are now enrolled in Dare to Dance programs in East Side schools.

Our Goal

  • Our after school outreach programming for Ballet Folklorico in East Austin Schools took a hit this year by losing it's funding source after thriving for years in serving youth with limited resources.

  • The outreach program has generally operated on a $10,000 annual budget, which is used to purchase costumes, dance shoes, food, and cover transportation expenses for the students.  All monetary donations, no matter the amount, will go directly to the Ballet Folklorico outreach program.  

  • As a community effort, the parents of the Ballet Folklorcio students have decided to have a fundraiser by selling tickets at a $7 dollars donation request, in exchange for a spaghetti luncheon to benefit the program for this fiscal year.  They too are being proactive in finding support for the continuance of this program, because they understand the impact we have made in their childrens' lives.  This Indiegogo campaign is Ballet East's effort to raise funds side by side, with our parents.

HOW YOU CAN HELP

Your tax-deductible monetary contribution will help us continue to provide this FREE after school program which has been in high demand for years, in East Austin schools.

  • The rewards are endless - with your contribution, you are helping us build bridges of success for our youth, who are challenged by limited resources.
  • The empowering feeling you feel in your gift will give the same gift of empowerment to the students, when they perform as they have done so annually for festival celebrations such as Cinco De Mayo and Diez y Siez...continuing the culture of Mexican Folkloric dance and keeping it alive in Austin.
  • Ballet East was established in 1978, and has been known to have stellar outreach programming.  Join us as we continue our mission in "bringing arts to the community, and the community to the arts".

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Make some noise about our campaign - get the word out, and forward this message.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

As a community effort, the parents of the Ballet Folklorcio students have decided to have a fundraiser by selling tickets at a $7 dollars donation request, in exchange for a spaghetti luncheon to benefit the program for this fiscal year.  They too are being proactive in finding support for the continuance of this program, because they understand the impact we have made in their childrens' lives.  This Indiegogo campaign is Ballet East's effort to raise funds side by side, with our parents.
