The rewards are endless - with your contribution, you are helping us build bridges of success for our youth, who are challenged by limited resources.
The empowering feeling you feel in your gift will give the same gift of empowerment to the students, when they perform as they have done so annually for festival celebrations such as Cinco De Mayo and Diez y Siez...continuing the culture of Mexican Folkloric dance and keeping it alive in Austin.
Ballet East was established in 1978, and has been known to have stellar outreach programming.  Join us as we continue our mission in "bringing arts to the community, and the community to the arts".



Other Ways You Can Help

Make some noise about our campaign - get the word out, and forward this message.
Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
THE PROJECT:

      If you gaze long enough into the abyss, the abyss will gaze back into you.’ (Nietzsche)

We, Hungry Bird Theater, gaze into the abyss of a story of epic proportions!  Edna and Vinnie, two down-and-out showbiz con artists, have survived mass-scale environmental catastrophe and now journey through the dry, devastated, burned landscape of what they hope is Nevada.  Edna is eighteen months pregnant and holding that baby inside her until they reach safety.  Vinnie is convinced that even the apocalypse can’t obliterate Las Vegas, so that’s where they’re headed… 

We created this show, titled “Get No Place Fast,” last year, and first performed it at San Francisco’s FuryFactory Festival in 2014.  This summer we will take it to the next level of development before we bring it to the San Francisco Fringe!

Hungry Bird’s mission statement proposes that a story is ‘a wild, living thing.’  Our process is based on integrity of investigation rather than aimed at knowable results.  We propose that this story ‘gazes back at us;’ therefore our creative process hinges on a cycle of generating material, then listening to how it resounds.  We move forward based on that knowledge rather than on our individual artistic agendas.

On a macro level, we believe that today’s world needs theater –that amidst an environment of screens and special effects, the dialogue between actors and a live audience is powerful, precious, and electric (in a way that doesn’t need to be plugged into the wall).  Media that comes to us through screens can be edited, but live performance exists only in the moment that it is played before people.  Herein lies its power to create community and dialogue around who we are, what we value, and where our world is headed.

                                  Help us bring this work out into the world!


WHAT THE MONEY GOES TOWARDS:

Our ONLY income for this project is festival ticket sales.  Even if we sell out every night, we will not cover our costs.  If this campaign is a success, then we will be able to financially break even.

We are donating our time for this project ---However we have a few other costs….

They include:

      *Festival Fees

      *Set Creation and Transportation to our Performance Venue

      *Costumes

      *Travel Costs from Blue Lake (location of our rehearsal residency) to San Francisco

      *Paying a Stage Manager

      *Marketing Materials

                                                Support us in making this play!


You can find out even more about us at www.hungrybirdtheater.com or on our Facebook page!

story:
BJM – Les Ballets Jazz de Montréal présentent une nouvelle oeuvre : Mono Lisa –chorégraphie du talentueux Itzik Galili

BJM – Les Ballets Jazz de Montréal present a new duet: Mono Lisa- choreography of the talented Itzik Galili

C’est la première fois que la compagnie fait appel au support du public pour compléter le financement d’une création. Ce projet est un échange important pour BJM afin de créer des liens durables avec les spectateurs et les faire participer à notre démarche artistique.

Cette nouvelle chorégraphie qui aura sa Première Montréalaise le 2 décembre 2015 à la Place des Arts dans le cadre de la saison 2015-2016 de Danse Danse est un ajout important au répertoire de la compagnie. Elle fait partie du récent fil conducteur des programmes du répertoire de la compagnie qui peut se résumer en un seul mot : énergie !

BJM est une compagnie de répertoire de ballet contemporain de renommée internationale qui propose une danse hybride alliant l'esthétique du ballet classique à plusieurs autres styles de danse. BJM demeure une compagnie de danse parmi les plus en vue du Canada. Avec plus de 2000 spectacles donnés dans 66 pays et une assistance de deux millions de spectateurs à ce jour, BJM est une véritable ambassadrice de la culture québécoise et canadienne dans le monde.

*********************************************

It is the first time that the company asks for the support of the public to complete the financing of a creation. This project is an important exchange for BJM in order to create lasting connections with spectators and get them to participate in our artistic approach.

This new choreography, which will have its Montreal Premiere on December 2nd 2015 at Place des Arts during the 2015-2016 season of Danse Danse, is important addition to the company repertoire. It is also part of the recent underlying theme of BJM programs that can be defined on one word: energy!

BJM is an internationally renowned contemporary ballet company that presents a hybrid form of dance that combines the aesthetics of classical ballet and embraces many other different styles of dance. BJM is one of Canada’s most popular dance companies. It has presented more than 2,000 performances in 66 countries to more than two million spectators to date, and is a veritable ambassador of Quebec and Canadian culture worldwide.

** La pièce que vous allez aider à financer // The choreography you will help fund

Photo: Alan Kohl | Artistes: Céline Cassone et Mark Caserta

Itzik Galili, « Le mouvement est mon langage, ma manière de communiquer. C’est un langage sans parole, ce qui le rend d’autant plus éloquent. »

“Movement is my language, my means of communicating; a wordless language which makes it all the more eloquent,” Itzik Galili

Duo, 8 minutes 

Le duo Mono Lisa, chorégraphié par Itzik Galili, est dansé sur une trame sonore faite des cliquetis d’une machine à écrire. L’œuvre s’ouvre sur plusieurs rangées de spots lumineux qui jettent une lumière vive sur le plateau sombre et recréent l’atmosphère d’une usine. Dans cet étrange environnement, imprégné de sons et de visions de fer et d’acier, un couple de danseurs vêtus de costumes couleur rouille virevolte, s’enroule et s’enlace en d’extraordinaires circonvolutions rapides défiant la gravité. Ce pas de deux aux mouvements acrobatiques époustouflants est exécuté avec une maîtrise absolue.

« L'art de Galili repose sur sa capacité de jouer de finesse avec l’abstraction et la narration, créant des œuvres qui nous marquent profondément. Il est à ce jour l’un des seuls chorégraphes travaillant aux Pays-Bas qui puisse établir ce fragile équilibre entre humour, violence, lyrisme, sexualité et élégance. » Michael A. Kros, Ballettanz International, mars 2007

****************************************

Duet, 8 minutes 

Mono Lisa, choreographed by Itzik Galili, is danced to sounds based on the noises of a typewriter. It opens on several rows of spots, casting a bold light on the dark stage, creating the atmosphere of a factory plant. In these bizarre spatial surroundings, filled with sounds and visions of iron and steel, a couple of dancers in rust-colored costumes twist and turn, twine and entwine in extraordinary convolutions and rapidity, with the partners always defying gravity. The incredible acrobatics are executed with breathtaking control.

 “Galili’s art lies in his capacity to balance abstration and narration with finesse, creating works that impress themselves strongly upon us. He is one of the only a few choreographers working in the Netherlands today who can structure a fragile equilibrium between humour, aggression, lyricism, sex and elegance,” Michael A. Kros, Ballettanz International, March 2007.

** L'impact// The Impact

Ajouter ce duo à notre répertoire est essentiel pour la compagnie pour offrir des soirées mémorables aux spectateurs. On se met en question, on s’évalue et surtout, on essaye de surpasser les limites et de pousser la barre toujours plus loin. L'exécution de ce ballet est pour les artistes-interprètes, autant  un défi artistique que physique.

Nous voulons montrer plusieurs signatures et couleurs lors d’une représentation pour exposer le public à une variété de styles de danse mais également pour permettre aux artistes de s’enrichir de leurs rencontres avec différents chorégraphes. Travailler avec des talents comme Itzik Galili est la preuve de la richesse et de la qualité que nous voulons apporter à chaque représentation. 

******************************

Adding this duet to our repertoire is essential for the company to offer to the spectators memorable evenings. We evaluate and question ourselves but most importantly we try go beyond the limits and push the bar even higher. Artists are challenged on an artistic level and physical level when executing the piece.

We want to show several signatures and colours during our representations to expose the public to a variety of dance styles. It is also a way to allow the artists to grow from these encounters with different choreographers. Working with talents like Itzik Galili is proof of the richness and quality we want to bring to each presentation. 

** D’autres façons d’aider @BJMDANSE// Other ways to support @BJMDANSE

N’oubliez pas de partager ce projet et de faire découvrir BJM dans votre communauté. Ce sont le support et l’intérêt des spectateurs qui contribuent à enrichir notre offre culturelle.

***********************************

Don’t forget to share this project at to help discover BJM in your community. The support and the interest of the public is the contribution that allows our cultural offer to grow and develop. 

** Les détails du financement// The details of the financing

Nous avons besoin de 15000$ pour compléter le financement de ce duo qui sera présenté à Montréal le 2 décembre à la Place des Arts. Cette somme servira à payer une partie de :

-la rémunération des artistes

-le cachet et droits du chorégraphe  

-les frais de location des salles de répétition

-la confection et la conception des costumes

-les outils de communications, comme images et vidéos, pour promouvoir ce duo

** Détails des récompenses:

*Le CD Rouge a été fait exclusivement par les Frères Grand pour la chorégraphie ROUGE. 

*Le Livre BJM est une publication pour célébrer le 40e anniversaire de BJM.

*Pour les contributions de 1000$ et  2500$, les donateurs aurons accès aux présentations de Mono Lisa après la première Montréalaise le 2 décembre: BJM aura des représentations le 3, 4 et 5 Décembre 2015 à la Place des Arts. Nous serons aussi dans d'autres villes autour du monde: New York, Philadelphie, Banff, Victoria, Nanaimo, San Sebastian, Cannes, Rennes. 

********************************************

We need $15000 to complete the financing of this duet that will be presented in Montreal December 2nd at la Place des Arts. This amount will help to pay for a part of:

-The remuneration for the artists

-the fees and rights of the choreographer

-the studio rentals

-the costume making and conception

-and all the marketing expenses 

** Details of for the contributors: 

*The CD Rouge was made exclusively by the Grand Brothers for the choreography ROUGE.  

*The book BJM is a publication to celebrate BJM's 40th anniversary. 

*Contributions of $1000 and $2500 will have access to a representation of Mono Lisa after December 2nd 2015: BJM will have presentations on December 3rd,4th and 5th at Place des Arts in Montreal. It will also have presentations on other cities around the world: New York, Philadelphia, Banff, Victoria, Nanaimo, San Sebastian, Cannes, Rennes. 

Photo: Alan Kohl | Artistes: Céline Cassone et Mark Caserta

story:
MASSIVE SAVINGS AVAILABLE - UP TO £250 OFF ORIGINAL PRICE

The Contemptible Case of Charles Peace

Who are we and what are we doing?

Broken Stereo are a new Theatre Company led by Artistic Director Daniel James Thompson. Committed to telling stories in unusual ways, Broken Stereo creates worlds that envelope and immerse audiences through interactive experiences.

We are extremely excited to say that we have been selected to be part of Basic Space Festival 2016 to present our professional debut production The Contemptible Case of Charles Peace.

This means that we are incredibly lucky to be getting FREE SPACE for our first show which is an incredibly rare and exciting opportunity. However we still need to raise money to make the show as incredibly detailed and exciting as possible.

We are hoping to receive some funding from private and public funders, as well as chucking in some of our own pennies, that will help cover the core costs of making the show happen.

However, the more money we have to play with, the better experience we can offer to all you love audience that come and experience the piece.

So what actually is the show?

Great question! The Contemptible Case of Charles Peace is an interactive theatre gaming experience that throws the audience straight into the middle of their own crime/thriller adventure. Working with two detectives they must try and solve a case that has spanned over two decades. 

By solving clues, cracking codes, and unlocking padlocks, they must piece together as much information as they can, as one piece of missed information might just be the difference between life and death...

What do we actually need?

Our core funding should be able to cover a lot of costs such as paying our fabulous actors, and stage crew who will help the show run smoothly. We will also be able to cover the costs of some of the game design and sets and props etc. 

However when making a show like this where the audience are free to roam around and actively encouraged to interact with the set, the more detailed and extensive their surroundings, the more they can become immersed in the experience and the more fun they can have!  Some extra money to spend will also mean that we can afford to make the set and props a bit more durable and less likely to break under the inevitable wear and tear that will before them during the run of the show. And if a cheap lock breaks halfway through, that means that future audiences can't gain the full experience and that makes them sad, and us sad and then everyone is crying and it just really doesn't end well at all.

Why do we deserve your money?

Other than the fact that you can get some really cool perks in exchange for your donations (I mean, who doesn't like a party?!) there are a few reasons why we would be so incredibly grateful to have your support...

As a young company we are trying hard to learn what makes us special and unique. Broken Stereo are working with a form of theatre gaming that we feel is rare to find anywhere else. We want to be pioneers who can keep working with this level of interaction and the excitement that it can bring to an audience.

At the heart of what we do is storytelling and entertaining. We want to create experiences that can thrill and shock and astound. We want to offer platforms where audiences can get lost in a world and have fun exploring and playing.

We are at the start of a long uphill climb, but we are excited and dedicated to making work that can reach and entertain the masses.

Why is no one else making work similar?

Quite simply this kind of work is risky and expensive. London is becoming populated with Escape the Room Games (Which are all amazing!) and these work because they have a set space where they can be constantly supervised by cameras and given hints in the right direction. However adding a live theatrical element to this and allowing audiences a greater level of free reign means that the risks of the show not working, or things being missed are infinitely higher.

In all honesty we might put the show on and realise that it just doesn't work in the way we think it might. We might allow audiences in and find that they don't understand, or it is too easy, or they just hate the whole thing. We might not even manage to reach our funding and have to pull the show together through begging, borrowing and stealing.

But that is exciting and we are ready to take on all challenges that come our way. 

What other ways can I help?

We understand that money can be tight this time of year as we all feel the Christmas pinch. And although we would be so happy to receive any amount of money that you can spare, there are other non financial ways in which you can help us out.

Please follow us on twitter, facebook and check out our website.

Sharing these and this campaign with all your friends and family will really help us get our name out there, and get us seen by as many people as possible.

Thank you in advance for any help that you can offer us. We love you all dearly and hope to pay back your kindness with a really incredible show in February!

Much love,

Broken Stereo x

story:
The Poetry Brothel has, from it's origins in NYC back in 2008, now become a global phenomenon. This Bloomsday (16 June) will see it’s launch in Dublin on a very special evening.  Timed and themed to coincide with Nighttown (Joyce’s evocation of Dublin’s Edwardian red-light district, The Monto)  

My name is John Farrell, a well known Irish actor-writer- broadcaster with deep connections to Mr. Joyce having staged the city-wide enactment of the Wandering Rocks chapter during the Joyce Centenary.

I am joined by Poet-Musician, Andre K’por, and Body Painter Caitriona Giblin to bring together all the great young star’s of Dublin poetry and burlesque scenes to make this celebration of Joyce’s novel and Dublin itself an event that will be remembered for many years to come.

To achieve that, though, we need your support and assistance.

 With over 30 performers, poets and musicians taking part the potential box office may not add up to much when split between them 

In the hopes of making this a crossover showcase that will permanently change the face of Irish Poetry we have encountered some real overheads that we will need to finance.  These include printing and advertising costs, a replenishment of petty cash, set dressing and fabrication, misc. transport and the video crew to make a lasting record of the event.

If you can contribute we have some seriously good perks for you to consider.

If we don’t meet our goal here it would seriously eat into performer fees and/or the pockets of our three organizers. 


We believe the emergence of the authentic inner-city and working class voices we will be showcasing greatly enhance the stature of Irish poetry both at home and abroad.  And we hope to make a video that can be widely distributed to show people what is happening over here and to build ever larger audiences for our poets.

Andre K’por is himself a leading light of the spoken word movement and has organzed many poetry events throughout the city.  He is considered one of the key figures in getting the word out about e emerging talents. Since he has the respect and trust of the entire community, he is the ideal person to have go scout out for talent.

John Farrell has a long and notable career staging big events as well as a distinguished run in media and journalism .  Perhaps, most notably, John organized a city wide staging of The Wandering Rocks chapter of Ulysses in the year of the Joyce Centenary that took place over 5 square miles and featured nearly 150 “performers”. 


While the risks involved are mostly financial, the challenge for us is to ensure we reach into all section's of Dublin's  variegated communities while keeping cover charges affordable to everyone in that cross-section.

The second challenge arises after the event itself as we pull together a short documentary that we hope can inspire more young people to participate in creative expression.

If you can't contribute you can still spread the word about our campaign (Explore the Indiegogo  share tools)!

story:
Short Summary

I am a dance artist who, after gaining extensive performance experience with Hofesh Shechter Company, Carte Blanche and Punchdrunk, is now trying to make the transition from performer to choreographer. I have been given a seed commission from The Place to make a new dance work as part of their inaugural Hot House project, whilst gaining support from the Northern School of Contemporary Dance and Dance In Devon. 

Loosely based on The Southern Reach Trilogy, Jeff VanderMeer's 'Mycological masterpiece,' Bloom explores human beings' fear of the unknown. It examines how a group of strangers communicate with each other in dangerous situations amid a constantly changing physical landscape. Bloom will be previewed at The Place for Touchwood on the 18th September, then on the 24th at The Riley Theatre in Leeds as part of Northern Connections. I am excited to explore these ideas and see them come to fruition  on stage while making sure that Bloom has a strong future.

What We Need & What You Get

I am in need of funds in order to help pay my dancers. I want to work with two established dance artists for a one month creation period, and make sure that they are paid fairly for their skill, expertise and inspiration that they bring into the studio. 

The perks that you will get for helping me are aimed at giving  you an insight into the process of making Bloom, through images, video, open rehearsals and even tickets to one of our previews in London or Leeds.

The Impact

Your donation will help me to set up an inspiring team of dancers, who through their experience and creativity will help ensure a piece of the highest quality.

Risks & Challenges

Whatever I make will go towards paying the dancers, and I am willing to put my own funds into the project to supplement that if necessary.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with friends and family. Spread the word, any help is hugely appreciated.

story:
The Great and Terrible Doctor Faustus

Adapted and Directed by Alex Benjamin

The world-renowned Doctor of Illusion J. Faustus is coming to Cahn Auditorium for a three-night-only run of masterful illusions, including his Most Mind-Bending Magic Act Yet: the Vanishing Cabinet! The absinthe is bubbling, Peggy Lee is wafting from the phonograph, and film noir is casting its shadow over every cinema in town. Step right up, pick a card, and your journey will unfold through the smoky, glamorous world Faustus has created for himself. Ask and you shall receive, the saying goes—and we are asking for your financial support as we welcome a cast of nine undergraduate actors to Cahn Auditorium, a building full of over one dozen sensuous environments for audiences to explore. 

Witness the miraculous spectacle with your own two eyes in Cahn Auditorium for only $7 presale and $10 at the door, on the following dates:
  • Monday Dec. 1 at 7:30pm
  • Tuesday Dec. 2 at 7:30pm
  • Wednesday Dec. 3 at 7:30pm

The Illusionists

Cast

Zach Nicol, Alex Quinones, Kelly Engler, Mary Iris Loncto, Shae Spence, Kori Alston, Elena Besser, Tatyana Aravena, Collin Quinn Rice

Production Team

  • Producer: Samantha Mueller
    • Asst. Producers: Emma Horvath, Noah LaPook
  • Director: Alex Benjamin
    • Asst. Directors: Emily Baldwin, Meredith Shadle
  • Choreographer: Katherine Scott
  • Production Stage Manager: Mallory Harrington
    • Stage Managers: Jason Clark, Eloia Peterson
    • Asst. Stage Manager: Hannah Knott
  • Music Director: Wesley Levers

ARTISTIC

  • Lead Set Designer: Bryan Matias
    • Set Designers: Emily Koller, Axel Mark, Dinnie Jay
  • Technical Director: Alex Shaffer
  • Lead Lighting Designer: Gracie Schwartzenberger
    • Lighting Designers: Gus Berrizbeitia, Michael Chinn
    • Asst. Lighting Designer: Lauren Stremmel
  • Master Electrician: Megan Wines
  • Sound Designer: Michael Rogerson
    • Assistant Sound Designers: Juliet Roll, Ari Shapiro, Daniel Shuffield
  • Sound Engineer: Grover Hollway
  • Costume Designer: Jared Sprowls
    • Assistant Costume Designer: Abigail Vass, Faye Yang
  • Props Designer: Ford Altenbern
    • Props Team: Daniel Bar-Lavi, Chris Porter
  • Hair and Makeup Designer: Quinn Hegarty
  • Lady Faustus: Maggie Monahan

PUBLICITY

  • Director of Special Events: Sam Garrott
  • Director of Publicity: Allison Towbes
    • Publicity Team:Kelly Eichenholz
  • Graphic Designer: Emily Fishkin
  • Photographer: Justin Barbin

FUNDRAISING

  • Grant Writer: Caitlin Medina

Sit and Spin Productions

Sit & Spin Productions is a student theatre board on the Northwestern University Evanston campus. Composed exclusively of undergraduate students, Sit & Spin exists to expand the definition of theatre at Northwestern by giving artists opportunities to explore unconventional, risk-taking works. We promote new approaches to existing material, adapted or original work, and site-specific theatre. We are dedicated to providing administrative, artistic, and production support for all aspects of our season. For more information please visit sitandspin.info.

How Your Donation Helps

Just as J. Faustus transforms the world around him with his magic, we plan to transform every inch of Cahn Auditorium into a film noir-era world complete with a jazz lounge, a collection of glamorous celebrities, and of course, a Vanishing Cabinet. Every small donation helps us to acquire bits of this bygone era, including:


• Set: We plan to immerse our audiences in the world of the play throughout their entire experience. That means our scenic team has to transform not only the stage, but the entire 4-story building of Cahn Auditorium into a mysterious, glamorous, and gritty world in which to tell our story.

• Sound: All 5 senses will help transport audience members back to the 1940s, and we hope to feature period-accurate records and live music throughout the building.

• Costumes: What would a high-class magic show be without elegant evening wear for its guests? Period costumes for our actors are essential in setting the mood and tone of the evening.

• Publicity: We hope to pique the interest of many members of our Evanston and Chicago communities, and to do bring our production to their attention, we need to fund special events, poster printing, and more.


    Other Ways You Can Help

     You can support our show in a variety of ways:

    • Share the indiegogo link on social networking sites and with family and friends

    • Come see the show! We'd love to have as many people as possible visit our mystical world.


    For more information, please visit http://nustudenttheatre.org/wiki/index.php?title=The_Great_and_Terrible_Doctor_Faustus

story:
As MTM's 2015 season comes to a close, we are bringing Madison its first ever Festival of New Musicals! We're holding the shows at very fun locations that will encourage people of all income levels to come experience the weird stuff.

If you're so inclined, we'd like to ask for your help. Due to the location of two out of three of our readings (Library and Wisconsin Public Television Studios), we are not allowed to charge for tickets or ask for donations on site. We're cool with this, as it means more people can come see us, and we'll get great exposure. But if you're willing, a donation towards this project would go a long way.

Our three readings are ALICE (a contemporary take on Alice in Wonderland), BIG MONEY (a story about a game show contestant who knows the secret to winning) and NIGHTMARE ALLEY (the story of a con man infiltrating a side show, told through a series of living tarot cards.) You can read more about them here: http://www.mtmadison.com/festival-of-new-musica...

Any amount you can contribute is tax deductible and helps us to continue bringing the weird stuff to Madison!

story:
Destyne Miller and Worn Out Soles

As a graduate of THE Grambling State University's theatre department, I have always had the dream of putting on my own productions.  In 2009, I had the chance to produce The Serial Killer, a play I wrote that tackled the issue of HIV and AIDs in the African-American community.  I received my first taste of success with that show.  Now after 6 years, a child and 5 years of teaching theatre to middle school students, I am ready to get back on track to accomplishing my goals.

One thing I pride myself on is writing and producing shows that mean something.  I don't want to just entertain people but I want to inspire them.  I want to inspire them to think, to change, to become better people and in return, make the world a better place.  Worn Out Soles was written with this in mind.  This play tackles the ugly side of human interaction: the way we judge those that are different from us and less fortunate than we may be.  After watching the show, I want my audience to feel something, be it guilt, shame, sympathy or empathy.  I just want them to feel.  Worn Out Soles has the potential to tap into that hardened place in the hearts of many and allow them to see people in a different and more human way.

With your help, this goal of my can be easily achieved.  You have the opportunity to be a part of something that is special and very close to my heart.  As a contributor you can help this single mom get on the right path to accomplishing every goal I have set for myself.  

What We Need & What You Get

I am asking for your help in producing the show.  I am looking to produce a 3-night show running September 4-6, 2015 at the FrenetiCore Theatre in Houtson, TX.  The breakdown of the costs are below:
  • Venue for 3 nights of production - $1,150
  • Rehearsal space the week of the show - $310
  • Videographer - $650
  • Stage Crew - $600
  • Make-up, costumes & simple set - $290
I am asking for you to contributing to my goal of $3,000.   With your help, this production can and will be very successful. 

There are some very unique perks that come with your contribution.  Your name can appear in the playbill as a contributor.  You could receive a poster, an autographed playbill, a t-shirt and/or a  ticket to show.  You even have the opportunity to attend a private viewing of the show complete with food, beverages

and a Q&A with the actors.  Check out the perks and decide what you would like to contribute!! 

Are you business owner?  Check out the business options in the perks section.  There are perks created just for you.  With your contribution you could have an ad in the playbill and possibly your logo on all promotional materials as well as promotions on our social media page.  Your help could result in a win-win for the both of us.

If we exceed our goal any extra money could towards a few things:  food for cast and crew on show days, stipends for the cast, and possibly taking the show on the road.

If my goal is not met, any help will go towards making sure this show gets up and running.  No matter what, this show will see the stage!  Just make sure that you are a part of it!

Passion that Impacts

As a child, I always wanted to become famous.  I wanted to see my name in the bright lights and be known worldwide.  As an adult, I want to create meaningful art.  I want to change the world, even if its just one person's world.  

When I produced The Serial Killer at Grambling, I knew I had found my calling.  The audience left having conversations.  They left feeling like they knew the characters personally.  They left being more aware.  My unique talent to create believable and relatable characters while taking on difficult subjects makes my plays a necessity for society.   

The success I had will only be greater.  If you believe in artistry that is life-changing, please help contribute and be a part of this journey.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute it's totally okay.  You can still help by sharing the link to this campaign and spread the word to anyone you may know.  If a rumor can travel around the world at warped speed, then surely a dream can, also!
story_txt:
Destyne Miller and Worn Out Soles
 As a graduate of THE Grambling State University's theatre department, I have always had the dream of putting on my own productions.  In 2009, I had the chance to produce The Serial Killer, a play I wrote that tackled the issue of HIV and AIDs in the African-American community.  I received my first taste of success with that show.  Now after 6 years, a child and 5 years of teaching theatre to middle school students, I am ready to get back on track to accomplishing my goals.
One thing I pride myself on is writing and producing shows that mean something.  I don't want to just entertain people but I want to inspire them.  I want to inspire them to think, to change, to become better people and in return, make the world a better place.  Worn Out Soles was written with this in mind.  This play tackles the ugly side of human interaction: the way we judge those that are different from us and less fortunate than we may be.  After watching the show, I want my audience to feel something, be it guilt, shame, sympathy or empathy.  I just want them to feel.  Worn Out Soles has the potential to tap into that hardened place in the hearts of many and allow them to see people in a different and more human way.
With your help, this goal of my can be easily achieved.  You have the opportunity to be a part of something that is special and very close to my heart.  As a contributor you can help this single mom get on the right path to accomplishing every goal I have set for myself.     What We Need & What You Get
I am asking for your help in producing the show.  I am looking to produce a 3-night show running September 4-6, 2015 at the FrenetiCore Theatre in Houtson, TX.  The breakdown of the costs are below:


Venue for 3 nights of production - $1,150
Rehearsal space the week of the show - $310
Videographer - $650
Stage Crew - $600
Make-up, costumes & simple set - $290

I am asking for you to contributing to my goal of $3,000.   With your help, this production can and will be very successful. 
 There are some very unique perks that come with your contribution.  Your name can appear in the playbill as a contributor.  You could receive a poster, an autographed playbill, a t-shirt and/or a  ticket to show.  You even have the opportunity to attend a private viewing of the show complete with food, beverages

If my goal is not met, any help will go towards making sure this show gets up and running.  No matter what, this show will see the stage!  Just make sure that you are a part of it!   Passion that Impacts As a child, I always wanted to become famous.  I wanted to see my name in the bright lights and be known worldwide.  As an adult, I want to create meaningful art.  I want to change the world, even if its just one person's world.  When I produced The Serial Killer at Grambling, I knew I had found my calling.  The audience left having conversations.  They left feeling like they knew the characters personally.  They left being more aware.  My unique talent to create believable and relatable characters while taking on difficult subjects makes my plays a necessity for society.   
The success I had will only be greater.  If you believe in artistry that is life-changing, please help contribute and be a part of this journey.

story:
We're in the early phases of production.  And now, we just need to finish the fundraising...

This is the inaugural production of our new theater company:

Collider Theater

We plan to tell stories celebrating the collision of cultures in America – not points where cultures connect, but where they bang into each other and create sparks.  Our theater company will produce new works, stage classic plays and commission devised theater works.


A Little History

“Love, Sex and Death in the Amazon” was written after an intense period of my life, in an effort to reach some kind of – closure?  reconciliation?  - and also, to explore the ways that Brazil and its people have influenced me.  The story in a nutshell:

When Walter’s Brazilian partner passes away from leukemia, he knows that his mother-in-law will be a handful. But when they travel to the Amazon to perform Umbanda rituals to put Marcos’ spirit to rest, they get far more than they bargained for - eccentric birders, botched religious rituals, bisexual tour guides, vindictive cross-dressing spirits, poisonous spiders, and loads of maternal drama. “Love, Sex and Death in the Amazon” is a story about learning how to let go when the past refuses to leave.

Collider Theater has fiscal sponsorship through The Field, a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit arts organization.  Any donations made to our production are tax deductible.


How Much Money Are We Talking About Here?

We've managed to fund most of our produciton budget, but we still need to raise $10,000 to reach our production goals.  We're on a shoestring budget, but shoestrings aren't cheap in NYC.  Whatever amount you can donate, you will be making a vital contribution towards making our theater a reality!

Our current production budget breaks down as follows:

  • Theatre and rehearsal space rental - $12,000
  • Rehearsal space rental:  $1,500
  • Actors, director, and designer fees - $13,900
  • Production personnel - $3,500
  • Production materials/rentals - $4,500
  • Marketing/PR - $1,500
  • Additional expenses - $1,400
  • Current budget total - $38,300

So we're close!  Whatever amount you're able to donate would be very helpful and much appreciated.

Artist Bios

Robert Murphy is a playwright and composer.  He worked as a sound designer for many Off-Broadway venues.  His play "Love, Sex and Death in the Amazon" was a semifinalist for the O'Neill National Playwrights Conference in 2014.  His other plays include "Total Maternal Love" and "The Life and Far Too Many Loves of Miss Lola Montez, Countess of Landsfeld – A True Story!"  Robert has degrees from Yale School of Drama and the University of Iowa. 

Jean Randich (Director/Writer) has been directing emerging work and new looks at classic plays and musical theater for over twenty years.  Recent work includes: Six Characters in Search of an Author (Nevada Conservatory Theatre), Antigone by Sophocles (NAATCO); The Floating Box, an opera by Hwang/Filloux (Asia Society); Drawn to Death by Art Spiegelman and Phillip Johnston (St. Ann’s, NYC); Girl Under Grain by Karen Hartman (Winner: Best Drama, NY International Fringe Festival 2000); J.P. Morgan Saves the Nation by Jeffrey M. Jones and Jonathan Larson (En Garde Arts).  Measure for Measure (NYU); Dog and Wolf by Catherine Filloux (59 E 59 Theaters); Leah’s Train by Karen Hartman (NAATCO, TBG Theater); and Cabaret (Abe Burrows Theatre).  She has also directed in Germany and Norway, and served as the American Juror at the 15th session of the Cairo International Festival of Experimental Theater.  Ms. Randich is Professor of Drama at Bennington College, as well as a Faculty Member at NYU Tisch.  She received a Masters in Creative Writing from Brown University and an MFA in Directing from the Yale School of Drama.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the resources to contribute, perhaps you can help us by spreading the word to friends, by email, Facebook or word-of-mouth? 


Thank you for your time and generosity.

Robert Murphy
Jean Randich
Artistic Directors, Collider Theater


Robert Murphy is a sponsored artist with Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for Robert Murphy are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or fax: 212-255-2053 or for our national charities registration, see details. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
Our Story

Comprised of an up-and-coming group of actors, writers, directors, and producers, F*It Club is
committed to providing equal opportunity for all of its members. We hope to build both a home
and a community for artists to share, grow, and create.

 

Our film and theatre production company was founded with the goal to provide access and
opportunity to those who have been unable to successfully navigate the "system" due to lack
of funding or positioning. We say "f* it" to waiting for opportunity to knock. We are seizing
opportunity and making it ours. We want to make work and we want to make it NOW.

The Impact

The concept of The Spring Fling is simple: to present 8 one-act plays about relationships in New York by up-and-coming New York playwrights, set in a non-traditional theatre space. The goal is that by producing a piece about a bar actually at a bar, or a piece set in an office in an real office space (or in this case, a theatre space with accessible components such as a bar and office area), we can make these authors' work more immediate, accessible, and surprising, and provide an innovative and memorable theatre-going experience that will attract a generation of audience members in New York that is generally underrepresented (20-30 somethings). The authors we have confirmed are Brooke Berman, Bekah Brunstetter, Ashlin Halfnight, Greg Keller, Caroline V. McGraw, Isaac Oliver, Mark Schultz, and Anna Ziegler.

What We Need & What You Get

Your generous donations will go towards an number of costs, big and small, when it comes to our spring production.  The donations will go towards theater rental, rehearsal space, insurance expenses, costumes, designer fees, union fees, scenic expenses, and marketing.   Just to give you an idea of costs, $20 can pay for 1 hr of rehearsal space and $300 can pay for all of our programs. Truly, every single dollar helps and is so deeply appreciated!


 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out on F*it Club and unleash a chain reaction by promoting this page to your social network. Leave Comments on this page, because that affects our GoGoFactor, the score IndieGogo uses to decide how hard to promote us.

story:
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

About San Diego State University’s Filipino Organization: Andres Bonifacio Samahan

We are the Filipino-American students of San Diego State University's ANDRES BONIFACIO SAMAHAN who dedicate several months of hard work for two of the most memorable nights of our college experience: FILIPINO CULTURE NIGHT on March 15 & 16, 2013!

The members of Andres Bonifacio Samahan not only write the play, choreograph our own cultural dances but even raise most of the funds on our own. Our goal is to educate others about the struggles and experiences of Filipino-Americans and to promote cultural awareness about our heritage. This completely student-ran production is our gift back to the community and for that very reason, the students voluntarily prepare for this whole theatrical show solely due to their vision in the progression of our culture.

  

Filipino Culture Night is one of the very few occasions in which we are able to express ourselves and hold onto our culture. It is our way of sending a message to the public and to allow others to gain insight of what current struggles we are facing in the lives of today's generation. “Samahan” is the action of coming together and uniting for one purpose. So, come with us on this never-ending, yet thrilling quest to re-discovering our roots!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Our Story

Our vision for this FCN theme is to be focused on the function of the Filipino Family Dynamic*

Each character in our play is based on people that we have known in our lifetime which is why this production is closer to our hearts than ever. Each expression and every single trait of our characters are real and we need all the help we can get to bring these characters to life on stage

In our Filipino Culture Night, we will address problems such as: the lack of conversation in a family household, family relationships, drug abuse, gambling and excessive alcoholic intake, early teenage pregnancy, questioning one’s sexual orientation, domestic violence, violence against women and those with severe disabilities.

On a more personal level, this may be one of the few if not one of our last chances in passing the message along to our own family. Our hope is that the actions which will be projected through the play will resonate in the minds of those present and hopefully have families begin some form of dialogue with one another. Please help us in having our voices heard.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

What We Need

Every year, this production alone costs more than $15,000+.

The theater (San Diego Joan Kroc Theater) at which we are performing costs: ~ $8,000

This estimated total will allow Samahan to utilize the theater for 3 days of tech rehearsal and 2 nights of performing the live theater production.

Although we are all young college students who have had some experience in the performing arts, we still wish to at least have all the quirks that any other theatre production would have such as:

  • Costumes & Props:  for all the actors/actresses and cultural dancers/performers =$700
  • Scenic Design: an actual set for actors/actresses to maneuver around and utilize = $1,000
  • Videographer: to film all that we have absorbed so that future generations will benefit = $400

For the past twenty-eight years that we put on this production, we have always wished for the general admission to be absolutely free of charge. However, the amount of money we raise is still not enough to cover the venue and other additional fees. It hurts us to ask for extra help to subsidize the cost, but we promise you, this is something that you won't regret investing yourself into. We are young students who wish to hold onto our roots. We want to understand ourselves. We need for others to understand us. Intindihin Mo Ako. "Understand Me."

Tickets

  • Pre-Sale Tickets $3 
  • At the Door Tickets $5

If we are still unable to raise the $15,000+ then all the funds raised will go directly back into the organization and to next year’s production to give them a head start.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

What YOU Get

With the funds raised you will get a very special spot in our program! Whatever sponsor you choose to be, you will be greatly appreciated and will go down in Samahan history much like our infamous Philippine Heroes! If you donate a certain amount, you’ll be known as the:

Lapu-Lapu Sonsor($10-49) = YOU will be appointed as the fiercest datu who has ever lived, much like the warrior chieftain who defeated Ferdinand Magellan at the Battle of Mactan in Cebu!

General Antonio Luna Sponsor ($50-299) = YOU are out right courageous for fighting along Samahan’s side in spreading our message! Hmm...sounds familiar.  Are you the Filipino general who led us in the Philippine-American War?

Apolinario Mabini Sponsor ($150-299) = Ang galing naman!  YOU are smart in supporting such a cause! You must be the “Brains of the Philippine Revolution” aren’t you?

Emilio Aguinaldo Sponsor  ($300-599) = YOU seem to fight what you believe in! Are you following in the footsteps of an admirable general who aided the Philippines in their independence? Maybe you should consider running in the next Philippine Presidential Election! Depending on which perk you've claimed (to the right side of page) you are guarenteed an x number of FREE TICKETS!

*Andres Bonifacio* Sponsor ($600 and above) = YOU will be revered as one of the most  highest and most venerable person in Andres Bonifacio Samahan. You’re strong heart is very much like those who fought alongside the Katipunan in their wish to free the Philippines from colonization. You should be declared a national hero! Depending on which perk you've claimed (to the right side of page) you are guarenteed an x number of FREE TICKETS!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Other Ways You Can Help Andres Bonifacio Samahan

Even if some of you are unable to contribute fiscally, please help Samahan promote our Filipino Cultural Night on the web! And if you live in San Diego, spread the word around town! Help us light up the world with our flier (coming soon*).

Our website is http://www.sdsuabsamahan.com/fcn.html

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For More Information

To learn more about the Director coordinating Filipino Culture Night, please visit:

http://www.sdsuabsamahan.com/fcn-coordinator.html

To contact the Filipino Culture Night Coordinator Jessica Mercado:

e-mail: fcn2013samahan@gmail.com

Even if some of you are unable to contribute fiscally, please help Samahan promote our Filipino Cultural Night on the web! And if you live in San Diego, spread the word around town! Help us light up the world with our flier (coming soon*).
Our website is http://www.sdsuabsamahan.com/fcn.html
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
For More Information
To learn more about the Director coordinating Filipino Culture Night, please visit:
http://www.sdsuabsamahan.com/fcn-coordinator.html

To contact the Filipino Culture Night Coordinator Jessica Mercado:
e-mail: fcn2013samahan@gmail.com

story:
The History

THEATER IN ASYLUM suspends beliefs and moralities through visceral, emotional and thrilling dance- theater to rigorously investigate our world and to believe again more wholly. We seek to create a world where theater experience is accessible, supported, and instrumental as a vibrant medium to explore and promote empathy. In the company’s first two years, it created five original stories for theater and produced cabarets which in total presented 37 new works by over a hundred young artists.

The Project

For its third season, THEATER IN ASYLUM was awarded a yearlong residency at Horse Trade Theater Group in the heart of the East Village theater scene. We will begin with a cycle of revolution (Revolution in 1), continue to the battle of two iconic artists (¡Olé!) and conclude with a Shakespearean whirlwind (Coriolanus) that pits populism versus elitism in post-war Rome. Through workshops, cabarets, and main-stage productions, with faces new and old, we will examine what has led us to become a nation ever at war: with other nations, with other people, with our lovers, and with ourselves.
 

The Shows

Revolution in 1

Revolution in 1 kicks off our season with the Horse Trade Theatre Group in October. Conceived and written by TIA's own Katie Palmer, Revolution in 1 explores the relationship between the two definitions of the word revolution: revolt and revolve. How and why do individuals take a stand? What are the eventual, and potentially inevitable, out-comes of this constant cycle of revolution?

Tickets on sale now at smarttix.com!

The Battlegrounds Project

The Project series is presented in cabaret style evenings that unify performances under a single theme for the night. This Fall, theater artists, musicians and poets create work that asks, where do our battles happen today? What and where are our battlegrounds?

¡Olé!

Lorca: poet, romantic, believer. 
Dalí: painter, modernist, scientist.
Their affair began in college and ended with Dalí’s flight to Paris as Spain descended into civil war. ¡Olé! brings two titans to life to battle again with paint, poetry and flamenco dance.

five IN ASYLUM

The five IN ASYLUM series unifies five performances under five form-based rules. Although the content is unrestrained, all five pieces have five formal elements in common. Talkbacks with the creators follow each piece, giving the audience a chance to ask and answer questions.

Coriolanus

A war hero returns to find his country consumed by rampant political turmoil. Pitting populism against elitism, this modern-day adaptation of Shakespeare’s Coriolanus recounts the tragedy of a man at the mercy of media, politics and Twitter.

Why we need your help:

This year more than ever we need your support. With Horse Trade, we have the opportunity to reach a larger audience and make our mark on the downtown theater scene. With three mainstage productions, this is our biggest and most ambitious season yet.

The Breakdown

As a young theater company, we rely on individual supporters like you to help us reach the next level. This year, we are looking to secure a little over 50% of our entire year's budget from individual donors. The rest will come from small fundraisers and grants.

For Revolution in 1, we hope to allot $2,000 of money raised through this campaign to pay for rehearsal space, set, costumes, props, and small stipends for our tireless design team and actors.

For ¡Olé!, we will set aside $4,000 of the money raised to compensate a professional flamenco dancer, pay for a dance platform for her to perform on; period costumes; set, rehearsal space; and stipends for the cast and crew.

For Coriolanus, we will use the remaining funds to pay for costumes for 13 cast members, an intricate set with television screens, and stipends for the cast and crew.

What You Get

Every donation comes with a great perk, from a digital hug to a season magnet to a dinner with the artistic directors. Plus, get an inside look at our rehearsals, set and costume designs, and research through emails and on our blog.

 

Be a part of this pivotal year: help us take THEATER IN ASYLUM to the next level and donate today. Be it $5 or $500, your donations are extremely appreciated. Remember, all donations are tax deductible!

Thank you so much for your support. We couldn’t do it with out you.

story:
Hi everyone,

My name is Tommy Oliver and I am currently raising money for my One Act Theatrical Production of The Reality of Truth. These last few months I have been developing my play, and finally finished it in its entirety. I have gone through a long journey with this play, and I feel so much love and respect for the many people who have helped me with its development. The play is written, casted, and ready to go all we need now is a little help from you! 

As you know times are tough, and it isn't cheap to rent Theatres these days let alone market yourself in the big LA. However, my goal with the help of friends and family, and anyone willing to support is to raise $1200 dollars to purchase three weekends at The Raven Theatre in North Hollywood, where my cast and crew will put up a production of my play The Reality of Truth. Like I said before I know times are tough and if any of you know me like I'm sure you do I hate asking for money, but at the moment I have no other option because our payment deadline is November 8th. I whole heartedly believe in my play, and I think it could be a huge step for my career; all I need is just a little help.  

In short, I am asking you to please help support me and a group of wonderful actors to perform my play. Any amount of money you can donate will be much appreciated, and I will forever cherish, and remember your support of me in my time of need. I can't promise that I will be able to reimburse you, but I can promise that I will always be there to support all of you because I never forget a helping hand. Also, as an added bonus if I go over my goal I am going to create programs and every person who donates will be given special thanks on the back of each program for their support. To sum up, I want to thank you for taking time out of your day to read this, and also thank you so much for donating to my cause. I love you all, and I will always remember this!  

 

Performance dates:

Friday November 30th through Sunday December 2nd, Friday December 7th through Sunday December 9th, and Friday December 14 through Sunday December 16th. 

 

Sincerely, 

Tommy Oliver

story:
OF A MONSTROUS CHILD: A GAGA MUSICAL

written and directed by Alistair Newton | production design by Matt Jackson 

choreography by Sky Fairchild-Waller |  musical direction by Dan Rutzen

lighting and projection design by Trevor Schwellnus | sound design by Lyon Smith  

stage management by Aislinn Ritchie

starring Bruce Dow as Leigh Bowery and Kimberly Persona as Lady Gaga
with Tyson James, Kyle Travis Young, and Chy Ryan Spain

Performance legend Leigh Bowery hosts an irreverent musical cabaret devoted to one of our most enigmatic and polarizing pop stars, Lady Gaga. Featuring a collection of the art world’s greatest icons, this “dance floor dialectic” celebrates the place where high culture hooks up with low art. Brought to you by queer trailblazers Ecce Homo (Alistair Newton and Matt Jackson).

Ecce Homo Theatre is raising funds to co-produce the World Premiere of Alistair Newton’s Of a Monstrous Child: a gaga musical as a part of the 2012/13 season at Buddies in Bad Times Theatre.

Buddies in Bad Times Theatre was established in 1979, and is a professional Canadian theatre company dedicated to the development and presentation of queer theatre. Over the course of its history, it has evolved into the largest facility-based queer theatre company in the world and has made an unparalleled contribution to the recognition and acceptance of queer lives in Canada.

Of a Monstrous Child has received funding from the Ontario Arts Council, the Toronto Arts Council, and the Canada Council for the Arts.  A workshop production was presented at Buddies as a part of the 2011 Rhubarb Festival.  

www.buddiesinbadtimes.com

Impact of Support

If you assist with the creation of this project, you will be supporting a unique and ambitious work of interdisciplinary queer theatre which investigates the religious dimension of pop stardom and poses questions about authenticity, appropriation, and the redeeming power of the creative act. 

Ecce Homo and Buddies in Bad Times have already raised close to $100 000 towards the production of this project.  This piece has the potential to connect new and diverse audiences and represents the apex of Ecce Homo’s goal of marrying “high art” to popular culture.  Ecce Homo has created work in  festivals such as SummerWorks, Next Stage, and Rhubarb over the past eight years and Of a Monstrous Child is a crucial opportunity for the company to have its work produced on the mainstage of a seminal institution for queer performance.  This significant benchmark represents the next step in Ecce Homo’s evolution as a professional not-for-profit theatre company. 

The scope of this project is highly unusual in the world of independent theatre in Toronto and we need your help to ensure the project is realized to its full potential.

Production costs to be covered by this campaign include:

  • Payment of Artist fees
  • Production costs (sets, props, and costumes)
  • Audio/video equipment
  • Hiring of an Associate Set and Costume Designer

We sincerely appreciate your support for this project as well as your support of contemporary independent Canadian Theatre.

About Ecce Homo Theatre

Ecce Homo Theatre was founded in 2005 by director/playwright Alistair Newton, production designer Matt Jackson and Austrian installation artist Edith Artner when the three were attending the University of Victoria in British Columbia. Now based in Toronto Ontario, Ecce Homo has a mandate to produce stylized theatrical works with strong socio-political content which synthesize text, music, dance, and design; to yield a total theatrical experience. Ecce Homo strives to equally balance politics and entertainment, to challenge audiences visually, intellectually, and emotionally; to produce work on big themes for troubled times. 

 

www.eccehomotheatre.com

story:
The Who and the What?

 

NorteSur Artistic Productions in association with the Quixotic Arts Collective is pleased to announce its involvement in the 2012 Hamilton Fringe Festival. We will be producing a play from one of the best in British theatre. On July 19-29th, 2012 the stage is set and lights are shining on Betrayal by Nobel Laureate Harold Pinter.

 

Since its creation in the 1970â€™s, this play has enjoyed critical success around the world, it has been converted into a film staring Ben Kinsley and Jeremy Irons and it has come to be regarded as one of Pinterâ€™s seminal works.Loosely autobiographical in nature, this play uses sharp and economical dialogue, Pinterâ€™s classic pauses, and highly manipulative uses of memory to explore the many dimensions of betrayal, betraying and being betrayed. What results is a poignant and raw examination of human relationships and the subtle and crippling effects that often result when people are asked to negotiate between their sense of right and wrong and their self-interest.

 

This play has a reverse chronology, it mostly moves backward in time exposing us to selected moments in the lives of the characters as they navigate through a 7-year affair. Face-saving, deceit, and strong sense of fatalism are intensified through characters that never say what they mean. 

 

Why this play?

We love this play.

 

In September 2011, we put on a workshop production of this play to prepare for the Fringe Festival. It was an absolute hit! People responded positively, many of them saying that they enjoyed how real the characters were, and how authentically they reacted.At the end of the day Betrayal is about people being people. The characters are cryptic, self-interested, and though their intentions might not be to harm, their choices often do. 

 

A great deal of this play is subtext. If you enjoy this play, youâ€™ll enjoy discussing it with friends even more. Even the basic plot points can be interpreted in different ways. This truly is a play where one could see numerous productions throughout the years and see a completely different play every time.

 

This play deals with real issues. People betray each other every day and in many different ways. It is easy to hate the characters because we see people we know in them. It is also easy to secretly relate to them because most of us have been a Jerry, or a Robert or Emma at some point.   

 

Wait a minute, Harold Who?

Right! I might have gotten a bit of a head of myself. Harold Pinter has been described as one of the most influential British writers of the second half of the 20th century. He is also the most copied.


Though the list of awards is long, what is truly remarkable about Pinter is that you know youâ€™re watching Pinter. Our author has one of the most unique voices in modern theatre and one of the most unique writing styles. His voice is also one of the most intelligent and subtle.


In a career that spanned over 50 years, Pinter received more than 50 awards for his writing. These included the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2005 and the French LÃ©gion dâ€™honneur in 2007. His most famous plays are The Birthday Party (1957), The Homecoming (1964), which some of you might remember from the Stratford Festivals 2011 season, and Betrayal (1978).

 

Great! Iâ€™m interested. How can I help?

1.    Support the project financially. We are aiming to cover our costs through fund-raising initiatives like this one. These costs include, wages, set, prop purchases, and costs associated with the rehearsal space. The space is provided through the Hamilton Fringe Festival and the rights have already been acquired through DPS. 

2.    Tell people about the show. Spread the word on sites like Twitter or Facebook, through your email or blog and through word of mouth.

 

What do you get? 

We believe that our sponsors are as important as the creative process itself. You are the enablers that allow the cultural dialogue to proceed. In recognition of the important role patrons play in the creation of any artistic endeavour, we are offering some perks that we think will make sponsorship as mutually beneficial as possible. Take a look to the side.


Where is the money going?

You deserve to know where your money will be spent and that it will be spent effectively.The money raised on Indiegogo will help us pay for the production of this show. It will be used specifically to pay for the rehearsal space and construction materials for the set. Our goal is to raise $3,000 during this Indiegogo campaign. In conjunction with this campaign we are also producing a benefit concert, selling sponsorships on the ground and approaching large sponsors. If we have to weâ€™ll even have a bake sale, though weâ€™re trying to avoid that one. Our cookies arenâ€™t very good.

 

What happens if you donâ€™t raise enough money?

There are many ways to raise money and we are currently exploring small tribute shows and every other method we can think of. The reality is that we could create this show with less money. We could avoid paying actors, skimp out on our design concept, or avoid advertising in the conventional media. We could also rehearse in our living rooms! The difference lies in quality. We are dedicated, and we expect the people we work with to be dedicated. That means paying them. By raising the appropriate amount of money we can hire better people and have a better show.

What happens if you raise more than the target amount?

Well, to be honest, weâ€™ll probably go out and celebrate! Weâ€™ll bake cookies and have our friends over for cookies and orange juice. Then, weâ€™ll put any extra money that we make straight into the show. Our goal is to make this production as good as possible.

story:
*The above image is from Lyric Opera Northwest's La Boheme, March 2011


A passionate woman full of fire.  A love that extends beyond death.  Jealous rivals and sinister plots. Lyric Opera Northwest is proud to combine these elements with Pucciniâ€™s poignant score in Tosca, coming to Seattle in May of 2012.


Greetings opera and LONW fans! Battling an era of financial duress that has hit the arts particularly hard, LONW needs help in producing Tosca. With higher theater rent than ever ($4500 just for securing the dates!), principalsâ€™ salaries to arrange, and a full orchestra ($12,500!) to finance, LONW is capable of once again putting together a rousing production, but not without help in getting it all off the ground.


We ask, therefore, that friends, families, and supporters, through large donations or small, help open the door for local artists to evolve their craft onstage, and to provide the audience with another entrancing operatic experience.  Knowing that money is tight everywhere, we wish only to remind you that $20 from enough people can bring about the same miracles as $1000 from one person, and it is with this in mind that we ask for your support.


Where the money would go:

Specifically, the money would go toward covering the $4,500 down payment for the show dates at the Moore Theatre. Our goal on IndieGoGo is only $1,000, but we are hoping that you, our dear supporters, will donate on this site past $1,000. It is imperative that we reach our goal for the show to go on, but it would be great to reach even further!


LONW history:

Carmen (2005)

Madame Butterfly (2006)

Traviata (2007)

Hansel and Gretel (2008)

Le Nozze di Figaro (2009)

Cavalleria Rusticana/ Pagliacci (2009)

Oliver! (2010)

A Night in New York (concert fundraiser) (2011)

La Boheme (2011)

The Messiah (sing-along fundraiser) (2011)

LONW provides opportunities for local artists to participate in spectacular performance experiences with professional directors, conductors, and musicians, all brought together for a large and lively audience.

Help make Tosca happen, and be a part of it today!
story_txt:
*The above image is from Lyric Opera Northwest's La Boheme, March 2011

A passionate woman full of fire.  A love that extends beyond death.  Jealous rivals and sinister plots. Lyric Opera
Northwest is proud to combine these elements with Pucciniâ€™s poignant score in Tosca, coming to Seattle in May of 2012.



Greetings opera and LONW fans! Battling an era of financial duress
that has hit the arts particularly hard, LONW needs help in producing Tosca. With higher theater rent than
ever ($4500 just for securing the dates!), principalsâ€™ salaries to arrange, and
a full orchestra ($12,500!) to finance, LONW is capable of once again putting
together a rousing production, but not without help in getting it all off the
ground. 


We ask, therefore, that friends, families, and supporters, through
large donations or small, help open the door for local artists to evolve their
craft onstage, and to provide the audience with another entrancing operatic
experience.  Knowing that money is tight
everywhere, we wish only to remind you that $20 from enough people can bring
about the same miracles as $1000 from one person, and it is with this in mind
that we ask for your support. 


Where the money would go:

Specifically, the money would go toward covering the $4,500 down
payment for the show dates at the Moore Theatre. Our goal on IndieGoGo is
only $1,000, but we are hoping that you, our dear supporters, will donate on
this site past $1,000. It is imperative that we reach our goal for the show to go on, but it
would be great to reach even further!

story:
Our Story

Who Am I?:

UC San Francisco-UC Berkeley Medical Anthropology PhD student with a multi-disciplinary background conducting my dissertation research, while combining it with my fascination with theatre.

What Am I Doing?:

Conducting dissertation research about women's decision-making process regarding sterilization in Brazil, as it relates to ideas about gender, sexuality, sex, reproduction, race and aesthetics.  But beyond writing articles and an ethnographic book about my year-long research findings, as is traditional, I will use theatre as a way to involve various communities in learning about and conveying the complex decision-making process women faced in the management of their fertility.

Where Am I Doing This?:

The bulk of the research will take place in Salvador, Bahia in the Northeast of Brazil.  Because this is anthropological research, the research will take place in women's homes, during health fairs, during visits to buy contraceptives and other aspects of daily life as well as in libraries to collect archival data.  The theatre production will take place both in Brazil (Salvador) and in the United States (San Francisco, California).  More funding makes it possible to have more performances in different locations.

When Am I Doing This?:

This project is projected to take place over the next two years.  One year and a half will take place in Brazil while the latter half of the second year will take place in the United States.  The first year will be spent collecting the necessary data to use in creating the theatrical production.  The first six months after the completion of research will be spent developing the theatrical production and performing it at the end of the six month period.  The same will happen with the last six months in the United States (the six months may be less time, more like 15 weeks, similar to the semester system of most universities).

How Am I Doing This?:

Data collection will be done through anthropological research methods, using semi-structured formal and informal interviews and participant observation to collect life histories and interviews from women (50 above the age of 18) and other influential people in their decision-making process (25 health professionals, local activists, NGO employees and family members).  Interviews and life histories will be transcribed for use in the theatrical production.

The theatrical production will be created through devised theatre (form of theatre where the script originates from collaborative work by a group of people, usually including the performers) using the anthropological and archival data collected.  Members of the various communities in Salvador, Bahia (and bay area residents when in the U.S.) and research participants will be recruited to participate in exploring the collected data, creating the script and performing the work.  The framework/basis for recruitment for participation in this part of the project will draw from Margaret Wilkerson's UC Berkeley Black Theater Workshop and Abdias do Nascimento's Teatro Experimental do Negro projects, which worked to introduce black students to theatre through producing it (Wilkerson), use theatre as a means to improve the quality of life of African Brazilians and serve as a forum for educating African Brazilians (Nascimento).  Thus emphasis for recruitment in the theatrical aspect of this project will be among non-professional (actors/performers), under-privileged, under-served and populations of color.    

The Impact

The desired impacts of this project are the following:

-To contribute new knowledge about sterilization, reproduction, sexuality, gender, race and aesthetics among women in Brazil.

-To provide women an opportunity to discuss their life histories and factors affecting their decisions about fertility.

-To provide an alternative and interactive way for members of the community (in particular, those that often do not have access to the results of such studies/research) to experience, learn from and impact research about them and their communities.

-To increase opportunities for exposure to theatre for communities that traditionally are excluded from access.

-To use alternative methods to present research and reach a more broad and diverse audience.


I was inspired to approach my research in this way after taking the black theater workshop class at UC Berkeley under Dr. Amma Ghartey-Tagoe Kootin.  Dr. Kootin's approach facilitated learning of her research material by both the performers and audience, inspired discussion and insights about the work and other issues raised by the performance and sparked reflection and dialogue.  With this work, I want to move and inspire people to tell theirs and others' stories through theatre.  Through my research and presenting it in this way, I also hope to encourage people to think more profoundly and differently about the entangled relationship between fertility, race, gender, sexuality, aesthetics and social movements as the issues concerning population and its link to the environment (climate change) resurface along with other underlying issues from the past (eugenics, genocide, racism, forced sterilizations, etc.).   


What We Need & What You Get

My goal is to raise $40,000 to cover the following costs:

Phase I (Research)

Costs for this phase include my travel to the research sites, visa fees, lodging, food and transportation within Brazil, access fees to archival materials, purchasing of books and other materials (photocopies, sound and video recording devices), payment for transcribers and research assistants and reimbursements for research participants (as part of ethical research, researchers try to minimize costs of participation in the research project through reimbursement when possible).  This is estimated to be $20,000-$22,000.


Phase II (Theatrical Production)

Costs for this phase include paying for theatre space in both Brazil and the United States, acquisition of props and costumes, local travel fees for performers/collaborators (as many will be from under-served communities), reimbursement of other expenses, fee payment for professional assistance (some may be needed for things like choreography, acting, etc), advertisement costs, videographers and photographers to document the process and final production and up-front costs to keep the performances free or low-cost.  It is desired to give a small and symbolic stipend to performers for their participation.  The cost of this is estimated to be $20,000.


All money raised will be used towards realizing this project.  Any amount truly will help to get my research project started and set the groundwork for future funding of the theatrical piece.  


If you prefer, you may a send a personal check.  Please message me for the address.


See the perks wall for what you get.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the news to your family, friends, colleagues and co-workers!  Post on your blog, website, twitter, facebook and any other social media you use!

I've been to Brazil before and made contacts but any extra contacts you have that would assist me in my research and in reducing costs, please pass them along.  Any suggestions as well are welcomed and encouraged.  You can send me a message here or post in the comments section.
