story:
We are somebodies dance theater.

 

We are a contemporary dance company that believes in asking questions, researching the ways that our bodies both affect and are affected by the world around us, and taking artistic risks to challenge the ways in which we and our audiences think and behave. We believe in dance and its capacity to create change, to reveal truths, and to bring people together.

 

somebodies dance theater was founded by Gina Bolles Sorensen and Kyle Sorensen in 2008, and has already earned a reputation for inventive, playful, and intelligent choreography. Based in San Diego, CA, and declared “two dance artists to watch, closely” by sandiego.com, Gina and Kyle enlist a new roster of collaborators for each project, including dancers, composers, and visual artists. somebodies dance theater has presented work throughout San Diego, as well as in concerts and festivals in Washington, Oregon, Texas, and Tijuana, Mexico. But we’ve yet to perform on the East Coast …

 

Why Is NEW YORK so Important?

 

The opportunity to perform in New York is a major milestone for any dance company. The Dance Gallery Festival in October 2011 will be somebodies dance theater’s NEW YORK DEBUT! We have been selected to perform a signature duet, “Paperdoll,” in the “Best of the Dance Gallery Festival.” This is a tightly curated evening concert highlighting select works in celebration of the Dance Gallery Festival’s 5-year anniversary. We have been offered the incredible honor of performing in the Ailey Theater in NYC!

 

Let’s Break It Down:

 

A cross-country trip is indeed a financial feat. Here are our planned expenses:

-Two round-trip flights from San Diego to New York

-Accommodations for 4 nights

-Metro passes for ground transportation

 

Here’s Where You Come In:

 

In order for our New York debut to become a reality, we need your support! This is an outstanding opportunity for us to share our work with an entirely new audience, as well as a terrific opportunity to see what our cross-country peers are making for the stage. Thank you for helping us to meet our goal! You are an important part of helping the vision we have for our company’s future come to life!

 

As an expression of our gratitude, please accept the perks detailed to the right!

 

For more information about somebodies dance theater, including photos, videos, events, and bios, head to www.somebodiesdancetheater.com. And please share this campaign with everyone you know who supports the arts!



Photos: Sue Brenner

story:
Shakespeare the Dead is a Pipeline Theatre Company production written by company member, Alex Mills, directed by Tom Costello. It was accepted to Theater for the New City’s 2010 Dream Up Festival this August, and will be the first show in Pipeline’s second season.

The play begins with a comedic look at a film set for a horror film, but slowly descends into a surreal horror of it’s own when the usual suspects of a production team are joined by a stranger.

Pipeline is ecstatic to be doing the show, but to ensure it’s success they need to secure a bit more funds! Help us do what we do in bringing audiences joy, thought, exhilaration, and in this case, a little terror!

“The Pipeline Theatre Company is a promising new group…The
enthusiasm of these emerging artists is palpable and they have a clear
love for, as well as a credible grasp of, the theatrical milieu…
This is definitely a company to watch.”
-Review of Psycho Beach Party, Pipeline Theatre Company’s last production.
April 12, 2010. Queer New York, by David Pasteelnick
http://queernewyorkblog.blogspot.com/2010/04/re...

Learn more at www.pipelinetheatre.org
OR
Buy tickets here: https://www.ovationtix.com/trs/pr/758455

Cast: Willy Appelman, Seth Clayton, Kate Eastman, Jessica Frey, Daniel Johnsen, Alex Mills, Mike Piazza, Mike Steinmetz, Gil Zabarsky

Production Team: Tom Costello, Kellie Mecleary, Allison Smith, Megan Linde, Eric Southern, Eric Krueger, Zealan Salemi, Jenny Donheiser, Nicole Spiezio, Charley Layton, David Hoffman, Stiven Luka, Steve Girard

All videos posted on our main page were made in part by Steve Girard

Check out Greg the Intern’s blog: http://gregtheintern.blogspot.com/

story:
Girl In Red Productions, founded by actress Gillian Alexy, is thrilled to announce it’s inaugural project – Fever! A Date with Tennessee Williams - three one act plays by one of the greatest playwrights in American history.

"Cavalier For Milady" - a poetic farce that explores repression and indulgence.

"Green Eyes" - the reunion of two newlyweds, separated by the Vietnam War, in steamy New Orleans.

"The One Exception" - confronts two extreme sides of the artist's psyche; the lost soul and the ruthless survivor.

These three one acts address the same raw subject matter as Williams' better-known plays. Written in the late years of his life, these plays have rarely been produced. We want to make them available to a New York audience with performances scheduled to happen in April, 2013.

Girl In Red Productions, along with actress Natalie Engelbert, are committed to bringing these plays to the stage while also providing a spotlight for a highly talented and eager group of artists.

The team so far....

Artistic director & Actress - Natalie Engelbert

Producer & Actress - Gillian Alexy

Consultant & Actress - Jenna Ciralli

Actor - Reid Prebenda

In order to continue to assemble our team and give this production the attention it deserves we have certain financial goals to meet. From theatre rental and rehearsal space, expenses to insurance, advertising and production design fees, there are a myriad of financial responsibilities.

So we humbly ask for your help.

This is where your donations will go:  

$5,000 - Theater Rental - 2 week run

$1,350 - Rights to three plays – 8 performances

$2750 - 50% of Key personel Stipends, upfront**

$550 - Set Design/Props materials

$800 - Rehearsal space  - 6 weeks

$500 - Publicity 

$400 - Liability Insurance

$200 - Costumes

$300 - Administrative/Marketing Materials

$150 - Lobby Refreshments

 

                              Total - $12,000

**The balance of the key personel's stipends will come from ticket sales

We truly value any financial contribution you can make.

Word of mouth, sharing on Facebook, and using the Indiegogo.com share tools are all wonderful ways you can also contribute.

IMPORTANT! We are going "all or nothing" on Indiegogo. This means that we HAVE to raise the full $12,000 or we don’t receive all of the funds.

YOU are the true producers of this event.

Our relationship begins at this moment and we so look forward to giving back to you on the stage!

With gratitude and warm holiday wishes,

Gillian, Natalie, Jenna & Reid

 

Check out Girl In Red Productions' Facebook page here!

story:
Keeping Live Theatre ALIVE

Since the ongoing COVID-19 crisis began at the start of 2020, the Social Distancing Players have been producing online shows for unemployed actors from theatre and renaissance festivals, joined by enthusiastic patrons who want to get in on the fun and help support us until our industry is back up and running. Titus Andronicus: Ya Know — For Kids!, is the 9th show in our series, and our 8th original work with audience interaction, and we hope that you'll be a part of it!

Each show is fully funded by Indiegogo campaigns - that is, by folks like you helping to keep live theatre alive. The hoped-for minimum goal for each show is at least $100 per professional actor - and so we're hoping to raise a minimum of $700 for this show. The proceeds will be evenly distributed amongst the performers, and after each actor gets at least $100, then we can put some money towards the next show.

The Impact

The Social Distancing Theatre project is here to not just keep performers semi-quasi-gainfully employed, but to keep us connected with our audiences. You're missing the shows just as much as we miss performing them for you live and in-person. The money raised goes to help each performer do the little things: like pay their bills. So every bit you give helps a whole lot.

Perks

We're not asking you to give just because you're nice (although we're sure that you are!) - we want you to get something in return, beyond the quality entertainment that we're bringing.

For $10, you get a backstage pass! You get to hang out with the actors after the show during the cast party!

For $30, you ALSO get a signed copy of the performance script! This will be mailed to you in early November.

For $50, you can ALSO have a part of in the show! See your name in lights and tell your friends that they HAVE to watch the show! First come, first served on this perk.

For $100 or more, you get all of the above PLUS a personalized sonnet written just for you! Shakespeare wrote sonnets, and so does the guy who plays him at renaissance faires!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help. We need you to tune in on Wednesday, October 28th at 7:05 pm EDT and watch the show! And share the show with your friends! And share this link to get your friends, family - even enemies! - just everyone you know to potentially contribute. 

After all, we're all in this together.

Thanks.

Since the ongoing COVID-19 crisis began at the start of 2020, the Social Distancing Players have been producing online shows for unemployed actors from theatre and renaissance festivals, joined by enthusiastic patrons who want to get in on the fun and help support us until our industry is back up and running. Titus Andronicus: Ya Know — For Kids!, is the 9th show in our series, and our 8th original work with audience interaction, and we hope that you'll be a part of it!
Each show is fully funded by Indiegogo campaigns - that is, by folks like you helping to keep live theatre alive. The hoped-for minimum goal for each show is at least $100 per professional actor - and so we're hoping to raise a minimum of $700 for this show. The proceeds will be evenly distributed amongst the performers, and after each actor gets at least $100, then we can put some money towards the next show.
The Impact
The Social Distancing Theatre project is here to not just keep performers semi-quasi-gainfully employed, but to keep us connected with our audiences. You're missing the shows just as much as we miss performing them for you live and in-person. The money raised goes to help each performer do the little things: like pay their bills. So every bit you give helps a whole lot.
Perks
We're not asking you to give just because you're nice (although we're sure that you are!) - we want you to get something in return, beyond the quality entertainment that we're bringing.
For $10, you get a backstage pass! You get to hang out with the actors after the show during the cast party!
For $30, you ALSO get a signed copy of the performance script! This will be mailed to you in early November.
For $50, you can ALSO have a part of in the show! See your name in lights and tell your friends that they HAVE to watch the show! First come, first served on this perk.
For $100 or more, you get all of the above PLUS a personalized sonnet written just for you! Shakespeare wrote sonnets, and so does the guy who plays him at renaissance faires!
Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help. We need you to tune in on Wednesday, October 28th at 7:05 pm EDT and watch the show! And share the show with your friends! And share this link to get your friends, family - even enemies! - just everyone you know to potentially contribute. 
After all, we're all in this together.
Thanks.

story:
Help us "SOW" our roots!

Hello everyone!

We are Los Angeles-based MaiM Theatre company (run by director Nathan Singh and playwright Julie Taiwo Oni), and we are gearing up to present a production of our new play SOWN in collaboration with Son of Semele Ensemble this summer (August - September 2019).

The Story:

Jones and Zora, young Black homeowners, find themselves at odds with their middle-class community when they decide to confront a strict American-only policy by planting a native African violet. While they initially defend this blatant infiltration of a monolithic landscape, a cycle of push-back and copy-cats eventually entangles them in madness. They must decide if they wish to stand up for the roots they’ve sown, or tear them down to maintain the status quo. This story explores the nightmare of contemporary segregation by placing its audience into a middle-class living-room-turned-battlefield.

The Team:

We've got two phenomenal LA actors, Joshua Michael Moore and Victoria Allen, for the roles of Jones and Zora, and we've been fortunate enough to have them onboard throughout the script development process as well. Julie has also been conducting research with the AVSA (African Violet Society of America)'s Thousand Oaks chapter and a local florist for both script development and design and character inspiration. We're rounding out our team with some other local artists of color to make a community invested in authentic storytelling of the marginalized.

 

Why This Piece Now:

We're living at a tense moment in current America. Families are being torn apart, citizens are killing and hurting each other, and in particular, people of color face serious obstacles in the effort to better ourselves among the chaos. Tackling these issues is at the heart of MaiM Theatre Company's mission.

We believe that storytelling, and theatre specifically, is a vital cultural practice that has the power to both reflect society's struggles and humanize the supposed other to show our commonalities. SOWN's setting is in the not-too-distant future, and its chaos is something that we imagine could become our reality if we don't wake up to the rampant fear of otherness across the country and recognize what joins us as human beings. 

We see SOWN as not just a play, but a conversation and a source for engagement. To that end, the production itself will include much community involvement, from post-show conversations on cultural ownership, assimilation, and the American Dream with the team, to dialogues on black botany and its rarity within the culture and what that means in our current state, to engagement with the plant life of Los Angeles.

The joy of theatre is that it takes a community to make it work, and we are hoping that our community will join us in supporting this piece of provocation and hope for betterment. We are intent on compensating the amazing artists who are helping us put this piece together, and we need your support!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help sowing our roots!

Our goal is $3900, and every dollar raised will go toward the artists involved in the production, from actors to designers to our floral consultant. We feel that artists, particularly those of color, are too often encouraged to work for free, and we refuse to continue this cycle. Each and every piece of the theatrical mosaic is essential, and MaiM is adamant that everyone who helps in our root-sowing receive what they deserve.

For our lovely donors, you are also an essential part of the community, and your generosity will not go unnoticed. We will have various perks for you, from public gratitude to posters to a personally-designed floral arrangement to VIP treatment.

 

The Impact

We are hoping that MaiM will inspire a much-needed conversation about embracement of diversity and providing opportunities for all types of people to live comfortably here and be proud to call America home. 

MaiM has done two workshop festival productions and a variety of readings over the years, starting with our first project BUNK in 2014 at Son of Semele. This project dealt with a story that placed the Nigerian immigrant community in conversation with Black America through the collaborative (and actual) process of building an entire bunk bed onstage, and included post-show dialogues on the story process and engagement with both communities in Los Angeles. 

After BUNK, Julie worked with guest director Terrence Colby Clemons to craft DENIM, a piece set in Bakersfield, California in 1994 just after the end of apartheid in South Africa, which captures the interactions between a young Black South African woman and a White American man. We collaborated with a South African script consultant, and preparation included a team visit to the actual location of the story in Bakersfield, Julie's hometown.

Most recently, Nathan and Julie organized a reading of Julie's play CHISEL at Pepperdine University last summer for Albinism Awareness Day. CHISEL is another play that deals with Julie's mission of placing America in conversation with Africa, and its specific premise is based in the rampant killings and attacks on albinos in Tanzania. The result was a HowlRound piece Julie wrote on her endless search for an actor with albinism and the need for authentic casting in contemporary theatre.

With some strong successes under our belt, this is our first fully independent production, so community support is even more necessary. If you've seen our work, then you know that we are committed to provocative theatre and supporting the ostracized. We hope you'll join us in this mission!

Check out our Facebook page for more info. and updates: https://www.facebook.com/maimtheatrecompany/

Also explore Julie's VoyageLA interview in which she discusses MaiM: http://voyagela.com/interview/meet-julie-taiwo-...

 

Other Ways You Can Get Involved

By spreading the word about our project and Indiegogo campaign, you will also be helping us tremendously. Tell everyone about us! This play is important to us and hopefully it will be important to you, as well.

We have an additional live storytelling fundraiser hosted by Julie and her sister Jessica for their series called GRIOTS. More info. can be found on her website: https://www.julietaiwooni.com/griots-losangeles

Also look for updates on the Son of Semele website: http://www.sonofsemele.org/

Thanks so much for your collaboration!

xo Julie and Nathan

story:
Help us raise $8000 towards Broken Seeds (Still Grow)!

We, Nadhi Thekkek (Artistic Director of Nava Dance Theatre) and Rupy C. Tut (visual artist), are working together to create Broken Seeds (Still Grow), a multimedia dance theatre production inspired by real-life stories from the 1947 Partition of British India. These stories of displacement are crucial to preserve, understand, and share; they give us a glimpse into our individual pasts, and we believe they can help us understand our collective future.  

We are asking you to help us raise $8000 towards the creation of this work. Your contribution will primarily allow us to explore the use of:

  • Projection/Visual Design
  • Lighting Design
  • Soundscape
  • Dramaturge

While the movement vocabulary is made up of the classical Indian dance form of bharatanatyam, and the visual art consists of traditional Indian miniature painting, we aim to thoughtfully integrate the new elements funded by this campaign to not only bring these important stories to new audiences, but also to engage our existing audiences in new ways.

ALSO, your contribution will have double the impact. Broken Seeds (Still Grow) has received a competitive matching grant; this means that whatever we raise here will be matched dollar-for-dollar by the East Bay Community Foundation to support other parts of this production. We need to make the match by August, and we really need your help to do that.

Broken Seeds (Still Grow) will premiere November 16-19, 2017 at The Flight Deck in Oakland, California. Our aim is to reach as many people as we can throughout the creative process through our website, social media, and finally the performances. We hope to motivate these viewers to personally reflect on their own experiences and ultimately find ways to facilitate tolerance in their own communities.

 

Who We Are

We encourage you to visit our websites (Nadhi’s here and Rupy’s here,) to get a fuller picture of our individual artistic journeys. But we could not make this production happen without the other collaborators and performers. The music is composed by world renowned flutist, GS Rajan. Rajan sir has an incredible ability to strategically weave emotion expressed through dance into his music. For more information, visit his website. Here is a snippet of work Nadhi has created with him in the past. 

Aside from Nadhi, the other Nava Dance Theatre dancers are Shruthi Abhishek, Tanu Sreedharan, Vertika Srivastava, Sri Thina Subramaniam, Lalli Venkat, and others. These dancers are freelance artists based in the Bay Area, who have received training from a number of different teachers. Many of them have lived, learned, and toured all over the world and we are fortunate to be working with all of them in this work. For more information on each dancer, visit www.navadance.org.

The musicians consist of US-based artists, Sindhu Natarajan (vocal), GS Rajan (flute), Santosh Chandru (percussion), Preethi Ramaprasad (cymbals), and Chris Evans (cello), 3 of whom are from the Bay Area. Nadhi has met and/or worked with each of these musicians throughout the course of her dance journey, and we couldn’t be more excited to be working with all of them on the same project!

What We Need

As we explore new ways to integrate various artistic elements, we want to work with experienced collaborators who have worked with visual media, dance, and theatre many times in the past. Your contribution will support these areas of work:

Projectionist: We are working with an amazing projectionist and visual content developer to help us design an implement exactly how dance and artwork will interact throughout the work.  Your funds would support his time, the additional rehearsal time needed to build the visuals in the space, and any equipment we would need to rent to execute our combined vision.

Lighting Designer: Our lighting designer has worked with Nava Dance Theatre in 2013 and in 2014 as a part of The Cloud Messenger. He is an extremely thoughtful soul whose goal is to highlight the hand gestures and facial expressions in ways that don’t distract from their potential impact. Your funds would support his time and any equipment he would need to rent to for the cues we want to build.

Sound Engineer: We have 5 wonderful musicians playing in this show, and to make that work with some of the video and sound we are designing, we have a dedicated sound engineer who has worked within the scope of live music for bharatanatyam before. He is hardworking, positive, and committed - we are so excited to work with our sound person again.

Dramaturge: Since we are telling a number of different stories, we feel that it is important to storyboard and discuss the direction of these pieces with a creative consultant. The collaborator we are working with has worked on dance theatre pieces inspired by diaspora, displacement, and lack of homeland in the past, and we feel this collaborator's viewpoints would be essential in developing the arc of this work.

Additionally, your funds will support documentation, which includes film and photography to preserve and share the work once the show is over. Lastly, since these funds are raised through CounterPulse, our fiscal sponsor, a small portion (10%) of what is raised here goes to them to help them continue to support our work.

We have been awarded funds through the Zellerbach Family Foundation and CA$H Grants to support a majority of the artist fees for dancers and musicians. Additional expenses such as studio time, music composition, and costumes will be covered through ticket sales.

What You Get

Virtual shout-outs, recognition on our website or our program, beautiful fine arts prints created by Rupy from her Marble Garden Collection, tickets to the show, artist meet-and-greet, and sponsorship credit to major parts of the production. The perks are endless. (You can also donate a perk of your own!)

Background and Impact 

The 1947 Partition was one of the most formative events in the recent South Asian history, creating over 15 million refugees and resulted in the death of over one million people. The regions of Punjab and Bengal were physically divided between the newly created Pakistan and India. Despite coping with hardship, conflict, or a divisive history, many who left their ancestral home have created new lives, found peace, and have even thrived. Their journeys inspired the title, “Broken Seeds Still Grow.” Using these interviews we can contextualize the experiences of our ancestors to help us find our way today. By supporting this project, you not only support the creation of this work but you also give audiences an opportunity to engage, understand, and share the real-life stories from the 1947 Partition Archive that we feature. 

Post 9/11 and more recently after the last presidential election, the political climate as facilitated hateful rhetoric towards cultural or religious minority groups. This has corresponded to an increase in the number of hate crimes specifically towards those of either South Asian or Middle Eastern descent, or anyone perceived to be Muslim. We want the voices of these struggles to be heard.  We believe this project can create a unique space for a larger discourse on how both internal personal prejudices and openly hateful rhetoric can affect the community at large. 

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest challenge is integrating dance and visual art. However, we have set ourselves up to make interesting interactions between the art forms, given that we are working with consultants and experts who have done this before. Before we even discussed this project, we had already started discussing how art and dance could interact, purely based on our genuine interest in each others work. We don't see it as daunting, we see this collaboration as an exciting way to intersect two traditional forms to tell contemporary stories. Oh and we meet in person weekly (often more than once a week) and we text and phone about this project constantly. And we voluntarily hang out on weekends.

One of our other challenges is that our music composer is based in Atlanta.  But, we meet for week-long residencies twice throughout the year to develop the music. This was similar to our approach when we were composing for The Cloud Messenger, so we are confident in our ability to complete the score for this project. We have budgeted appropriately for travel to accommodate this challenge. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We hope you can contribute to this project, and if you are not in a position to contribute financially right now, then we hope you can contribute by making noise about the project via facebook, instagram, snapchat - whatever platform you use. E-mail, text, phone calls – any of it works for us! Use the share options made available to you from the indiegogo campaign page, and let us know if you have any questions on how to spread the word.

We are counting on your support. Please consider contributing or sharing!

story:
What is Lighthouse Triptych?

Hi! We are: Stephanie Lane (choreographer, performer, adapter), Mark Van Hare (composer, sound-designer), Jamie Watkins (director), Kyle Gerry (performer), and Mackenzie Jahnke (performer), and we've come together for the latest iteration of Lighthouse Triptych, to be performed as part of The Brick Theater's Sound Scape Festival this June in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.  

Lighthouse Triptych is a dance, theater, and music collaboration inspired by Virginia Woolf's modernist novel, To the Lighthouse.  

To make this show, we're working together in the unique space where sound, dance, and acting overlap.  Stephanie's script takes place in three acts.  Under Jamie's direction, each act is stylistically distinct.  Mark Van Hare's sound design and score create a rich aural environment, which, along with Stephanie's choreography, communicate the complextity of Woolf's ideas non-verbally.   We're digging into to the gnarly themes in the novel - the passage of time, chaos versus control, and familial love.  

Where did it begin, where is it going?

The show began back in 2009 as Part I, "The Dinner Scene," Stephanie Lane's senior thesis at Barnard College.  After performing it in New York, Brooklyn, and Shanghai, Stephanie worked with actress Devon Werden, dancer Kyle Gerry, and composer Mark Van Hare to develop the show into a three-part, evening-length work which had its workshop premiere at Dixon Place in downtown Manhattan in January, 2013.  

Happily for all of us, Williamsburg's The Brick Theater has recently chosen Lighthouse Triptych for their sound-design focused festival, Sound Scape, for five performances in June (see below).  We've been working hard in the rehearsal and editing rooms to get the show ready for its premiere, but we need your help to take us all the way!

As a funder for this project, you make it possible for us to explore the potential of Woolf's writing for the stage, to bring it to audiences, and to continue experimenting in the exciting space where dance, theater, and music overlap.  

Our performance as The Brick will be: 

Saturday 6/8       5pm

Sunday 6/9         6pm

Thursday 6/13     7pm

Sunday 6/16        8pm

Wednesday 6/26   9pm

Our cast is: Mackenzie Jahnke (Lily Briscoe, Mrs. McNab), Kyle Gerry (Mr. Ramsay), and Stephanie Lane (Mrs. Ramsay, Mrs. Bast)

What We Need & What You Get

In order to fully fund the project for this 5-show production, we are aiming to raise $1,500.  This money covers:

  • 30+ hours of rehearsal space in Manhattan and Brooklyn - $450
  • Costumes, props, and set pieces - $250
  • Transportation of set pieces to and from the theater - $100
  • Remuneration for cast and crew - $600
  • Marketing and advertising - $100

Here's what we'll give you in return:

  • $5 gets a thank you email from us. 
  • $10 gets a thank you email including a link to video footage from rehearsal, with a bit of a boogie-down.
  • $25 gets a signed personal postcard from cast & crew.
  • $50 gets a 4x6 hand-painted lighthouse by our adaptation-writer.
  • $100 gets a hand-painted lighthouse plus a post-card from cast & crew.
  • $500 gets a copy of Woolf's To the Lighthouse, inscribed with a thank you from cast and crew.

The Impact

"The themes explored in this show are deep and good and universal: the desire to bring the people you love together; the chaos and unpredictability inherent in living; the need to move forward; the need to make art.  We feel strongly about the work and about putting it out there.  Our past audiences have felt this way too.  Your contribution gets Woolf's words up on stage, and rich collaboration brewing among the cast and crew." - Stephanie Lane

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't give in the form of money, we can still use your help!  Use the Indiegogo share tools to tell your friends about our campaign.  And of course, come see the show!  June 8-26th at The Brick, 579 Metropolitan Avenue in Brooklyn! (See above for show dates and times!)
story_txt:
What is Lighthouse Triptych?
Hi! We are: Stephanie Lane (choreographer, performer, adapter), Mark Van Hare (composer, sound-designer), Jamie Watkins (director), Kyle Gerry (performer), and Mackenzie Jahnke (performer), and we've come together for the latest iteration of Lighthouse Triptych, to be performed as part of The Brick Theater's Sound Scape Festival this June in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.  
Lighthouse Triptych is a dance, theater, and music collaboration inspired by Virginia Woolf's modernist novel, To the Lighthouse.  
To make this show, we're working together in the unique space where sound, dance, and acting overlap.  Stephanie's script takes place in three acts.  Under Jamie's direction, each act is stylistically distinct.  Mark Van Hare's sound design and score create a rich aural environment, which, along with Stephanie's choreography, communicate the complextity of Woolf's ideas non-verbally.   We're digging into to the gnarly themes in the novel - the passage of time, chaos versus control, and familial love.  
Where did it begin, where is it going?
The show began back in 2009 as Part I, "The Dinner Scene," Stephanie Lane's senior thesis at Barnard College.  After performing it in New York, Brooklyn, and Shanghai, Stephanie worked with actress Devon Werden, dancer Kyle Gerry, and composer Mark Van Hare to develop the show into a three-part, evening-length work which had its workshop premiere at Dixon Place in downtown Manhattan in January, 2013.  
Happily for all of us, Williamsburg's The Brick Theater has recently chosen Lighthouse Triptych for their sound-design focused festival, Sound Scape, for five performances in June (see below).  We've been working hard in the rehearsal and editing rooms to get the show ready for its premiere, but we need your help to take us all the way!
As a funder for this project, you make it possible for us to explore the potential of Woolf's writing for the stage, to bring it to audiences, and to continue experimenting in the exciting space where dance, theater, and music overlap.  
Our performance as The Brick will be: 
Saturday 6/8       5pm
Sunday 6/9         6pm
Thursday 6/13     7pm
Sunday 6/16        8pm
Wednesday 6/26   9pm
Our cast is: Mackenzie Jahnke (Lily Briscoe, Mrs. McNab), Kyle Gerry (Mr. Ramsay), and Stephanie Lane (Mrs. Ramsay, Mrs. Bast)
What We Need & What You Get


In order to fully fund the project for this 5-show production, we are aiming to raise $1,500.  This money covers:

30+ hours of rehearsal space in Manhattan and Brooklyn - $450
Costumes, props, and set pieces - $250
Transportation of set pieces to and from the theater - $100
Remuneration for cast and crew - $600
Marketing and advertising - $100

Here's what we'll give you in return:

$5 gets a thank you email from us. 
$10 gets a thank you email including a link to video footage from rehearsal, with a bit of a boogie-down.
$25 gets a signed personal postcard from cast & crew.
$50 gets a 4x6 hand-painted lighthouse by our adaptation-writer.
$100 gets a hand-painted lighthouse plus a post-card from cast & crew.
$500 gets a copy of Woolf's To the Lighthouse, inscribed with a thank you from cast and crew.



The Impact
"The themes explored in this show are deep and good and universal: the desire to bring the people you love together; the chaos and unpredictability inherent in living; the need to move forward; the need to make art.  We feel strongly about the work and about putting it out there.  Our past audiences have felt this way too.  Your contribution gets Woolf's words up on stage, and rich collaboration brewing among the cast and crew." - Stephanie Lane
Other Ways You Can Help


If you can't give in the form of money, we can still use your help!  Use the Indiegogo share tools to tell your friends about our campaign.  And of course, come see the show!  June 8-26th at The Brick, 579 Metropolitan Avenue in Brooklyn! (See above for show dates and times!)

story:
Dance Generators, an intergenerational dance company featuring men and women from their 20s to their 80s, has been a vibrant part of the Pioneer Valley arts scene since 1997.  Help the Dance Generators cope with disappearance of local arts venues and keep sharing their work.  We need your support now to fund our June 2013 concert of new works!

Dance Generators has been lucky to have wonderful performance venues and support from producers throughout their first fifteen years. Originally artists-in-residence at A.P.E. in Thornes Marketplace, Northampton, the Dance Generators were taken in by  Northampton Center for the Arts after the A.P.E. space was sold.   Now that Center for the Arts has lost its space, the DG are on their own to produce their home season this year.  This greatly increases our financial burden as well as our administrative responsibilities. The company has made arrangements to rent the beautiful Kendall Studio Theater at Mt. Holyoke College in South Hadley, MA.  But, in order to deal with the added expenses of self-producing in this space, we need to raise several thousand dollars. 

As local performance venues disappear, we need your support more than ever to keep making our work and making a difference in our community.  Throughout the year, the Dance Generators offer a vigorous community outreach program, performing across the Pioneer Valley in schools, senior homes, libraries and community centers.  Once a year, we return to a traditional theater space to do a fully produced show with lights, costumes, sets, props, etc., allowing us to deepen the artistic integrity of our work. 

The Dance Generators 2013 concert will premier new works by DG Artistic Director Kristin Horrigan and by guest artists Fritha Pengally, Jen Polins, and Maureen Shea.  The company will be joined on stage by the Da Camera Singers, a 40 member adult choir based in Amherst, MA, and the Dolphin Dancers, a children’s dance company based in Cummington, MA. 

See our video above to meet the company, see excerpts of past performances, and hear what working intergenerationally means to the work we create. 

 

How will your money help us?  We are looking to raise:

$2000 for renting a theater space at Mt. Holyoke College

$2000 to pay our crew (light designer, sound designer, stage hands, etc.)

$400 for publicity

$600 to send "perks" to the awesome community of Dance Generators supporters who fund this performance!

 

Help Dance Generators by making a donation and spreading the word about our company, our upcoming show and our fundraising campaign!  Any amount you can contribute is welcome -- we appreciate support in all sizes.   And whether you can donate or not, we hope you'll consider coming to see us in performance June 8 and 9, 2013 at the Mt. Holyoke College Kendall theater.

 

With gratitude,

The members of Dance Generators

www.dancegenerators.org

story:
http://www.vanessakisuule.co.uk/

Vanessa Kisuule is one of the UK's most exciting, and outrageously talented, emerging spoken word artists. She has won several awards for her work, including Slambassadors 2010, Hammer and Tongue Slam, Poetry Rivals 2011 and most recently Sabotage Review's Best Spoken Word Poet. Vanessa has performed at festivals such as Glastonbury and Secret Garden Party and has supported the likes of Kate Tempest, Dizraeli and Linton Kwesi Johnson to name but a few. 

 


‘Kanye West should take... her wit and use it for his live show.’ Charlotte Morgan Nokwenna, Poejazzi

 

‘Vanessa Kisuule is the best performance poet in the UK.' Dan Holloway The Guardian

 


At the beginning of 2013, Vanessa teamed up with Hannah Horan, Elana Binysh and Annie Bell to form Whispers&Shouts. We are a theatre company who create experimental theatre combining spoken word poetry, physical theatre and traditional playwriting. The result is eloquently explosive performance that cuts straight to the core of what it is to feel.

 

Whispers&Shouts was formed in order to produce Vanessa's first full length spoken word play, One Last Thing, which was such a success in it's first run, in Bristol, that we now plan to tour it to Brainchild festival in Canterbury and to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival.

 


"We’re not alone. Not as long as words are coming out of your mouth, and they’re going into people’s ears or maybe even people’s hearts and not falling into the cracks in the pavement or the gaps between the stars."- One Last Thing

 

One Last Thing is an anthology of words you wish you'd said, things you couldn't express and moments that passed you by. It allows its audience momentary insights into the lives of a series of characters: a battered housewife, eternally on the brink of escaping; a little girl saying goodbye forever to her imaginary friends; and two teenagers who find a sort of love over miniature quiches and accidental murder. If you have ever regretted not saying something, or wished you could have said it better, this show is for you. In One Last Thing, the things we cannot say flow from the characters’ mouths as perfectly formed poetry.

 

“In a word, phenomenal...impressive in its ability to 'ring true in all of us'”. (Inter:mission Bristol, Bristol's online arts magazine)

 

"One Last Thing is nothing short of inspirational" Harry Baker, European Slam Champion

 


We believe in the redemptive power of spoken word, and what performing and creating spoken word can do for our society. In a world where we have more mediums than ever to express ourselves, true unvarnished honesty seems to be ever more elusive. One Last Thing hopes to show people that there is no such thing as shame, or isolation; that no, it is ‘not just you’ that feels the way you do, and we believe that spoken word poetry has the power to do this. Spoken word plays especially, have the power to access the raw, complicated humanity of an audience in a way which we believe other forms do not. Thanks to artists such as Kate Tempest, Katie Bonna and Richard Marsh, spoken word plays are becoming recognised as an important and exciting theatrical form. We hope to contribute the growth of this form, while helping one of the most inspirational young artists at the moment access as wide an audience as possible. The Edinburgh Fringe is, we believe, the best platform for this: it attracts attention from audiences and critics alike on a scale unmatched by any other theatrical event in the world.

 

 http://www.whispersandshouts.webuda.com/

 

Our production team, Whispers&Shouts consists of Elana Binysh, Hannah Horan and Annie Bell. Here's a bit about them all:

Annie Bell: Annie is a theatre producer who has worked on a number of productions (eight in the last year!), ranging from a large scale production of King Lear, which was shown in Bristol and London, to smaller scale shows such as The Honeymoon Suite, which was set in a beautifully accurate recreation of a 1950's hotel room. Most recently, she has worked with Bristol-based company MAYK on Mayfest, one of the UK's most exciting theatre festivals. She will continue to work with MAYK later this year. Annie likes theatre. Lots of theatre, but especially theatre that is energetic, experimental, honest, and leaves her breathless. (She also likes tea, bikes, and videos of baby sloths).

 

Elana Binysh: Elana is a theatre producer and costume designer with a passion for collaborative theatre. After having worked extensively in costume- large scale productions of Honeymoon Suite, The Tempest, Festen and Metamorphosis as highlights- she has moved on to focus on producing. In the past three months she has worked on a Bristol based production of Look Back in Anger, as well as a new piece of Verbatim Theatre in association with the charity STAR, discussing the case for Asylum Seekers in Britain. In the past year she has volunteered for You Me Bum Bum Train and Mayfest, as well as working at C Venues in Edinburgh, cemementing her love of immersive, vibrant productions. These experiences have left her convinced that anyone who says theatre is a dying art form is an idiot- they clearly just haven't been to the right play yet.

 

Hannah Horan: Hannah is a theatre-type who has dabbled in the art of directing, producing and even stage managing; most notably directing small-scale Bristol-based productions, producing shows for sketch comedy troupe Bristol Revunions and a large-scale Theatre Uncut, plus stage managing for a hugely successful production of ‘The Cracks in My Skin’. She has also had much experience in organising open mic nights and encouraging new talent, whilst trying her hand (arguably successfully) at stand up and compering. Hannah believes that theatre should get noises out of you that nothing else ever will. 

Everything we raise here will go towards the Edinburgh run of One Last Thing,for which our budget breakdown looks like this:

 

Props & Costume: £95.20

 

Insurance: £123.00

 

Posters: £120.00

 

Flyers: £217.50

 

Other marketing: £300

 

Edfringe fee: £393.60

 

Sweet Venues (venue hire): £537.60

 

Sweet Venues (marketing): £140

 

Total: £1926.90

 

As well as our online campaign, we will be raising the money we need through a variety of means, including the proceeds of another of our shows, Flesh, a one woman spoken word play which is currently on at Smoke and Mirrors in Bristol. It is incredibly good, if we say so ourselves, so if you are in the Bristol area, check it out! 

 

If you can't contribute right now, then do not fear! There are other ways you can help. Simply getting the word out and making as many people as possible aware of the project would be hugely appreciated. Let's get everyone on board the spoken word bus. Please make use of the Indiegogo sharing tools, there is literally nothing easier.

 

 

If you'd like to get in touch to find out more about the show, our other projects, or just for a chat (we are really good listeners) then feel free to email us at whispersandshouts13@gmail.com.

story:
Summary

seat of your pants Productions has been producing low budget, high quality plays since 1997 in the southern California area. We have staged original and established works. We have helped new actors, designers, directors, and playwrights get a chance to show their talents.

In 2002, we staged a production of Irvine Welsh's TRAINSPOTTING which garnered rave reviews from such periodicals as the LA Weekly, Backstage, Entertainment Today, the Ventura Star, the Hollywood Reporter, and the Los Angeles Times, which also gave us a top ten pick of the year.

The show, which revolves around a group of Scottish heroin addicts, isn't just about drugs, but about the choices people make in their lives to escape their misery and the consequences of those actions. The play is filled with humor and drama and is not for the faint of heart. 

This show was one of the most impactful that seat of your pants Productions has done, affecting most everyone who saw it. We received praise from the likes of KEVIN SPACEY, who saw it three times, Academy Award winning screenwriter and director STEPHEN GAGHAN called it an amazing piece of theatre. 

But the biggest praise I feel we received came from an older couple who read a review of it and drove an hour and a half to see it. After the show they thanked us for staging the show. Their son had died of a drug overdose a few years earlier and they never understood why, as he was taken care of, educated, and loved. The show helped give them some answers and some closure.

We know the power the show has and want to spread that message again and with your help, we will be able to do that.

We tried for several years to get this show to a New York venue, but for a number of reasons, (including a previously staged production of TRAINSPOTTING that was not well-received) we had no luck in finding the backing that would get us into the Big Apple (we found it would cost us anywhere between $100,000 - $800,000 to do it in an Off-Off Broadway theater).

Several of the cast wanted to do a revival and take another stab at seeing if we could move this show to bigger and better things. They are coming back to help with this production and knowing our resources in Los Angeles can allow us to do this at a much more reasonable $20,000 budget for a six week run that we hope to entice producers into seeing.

Your help with our play can get a little show onto a larger market and see a small show reach the big lights of Broadway. 

seat of your pants Productions also recently was granted its 501(c)(3) status as a non-profit and so your contribution is also tax deductible!

What We Need & What You Get

We have raised $10,000 on our own and we are looking to raise another $10,000 through IndieGoGo.

Most of the money that is used for a theatre production goes into the cost of the theater (around $9000 for the venue we found for a six week run). But a show has som many more expenses to make it work: the rights for the play, rehearsal space, lights, sets, costumes, props... and to take it to the next level takes money. So, we need help, 

On top of getting the chance to be part of an award winning show looking to go to Broadway, we will be offering a number of other perks:

* Free tickets to see the show!

* Name in the program!

* Autographed posters from the show!

* Trainspotting t-shirts!

* Trainspotting Gift packages!

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute, maybe you can share this link on your social networks or maybe you know people who would be interested in helping us and you can pass this along to them.

story:
The Who:

We are Infinite Jest Theatre Company, Los Angeles' only all comedic theatre company and we are brand new! Founded in late 2012, our members are all talented artists, primarily with theatre backgrounds. We believe that theatre should be accessible to all and is an integral part of a well-rounded society and, whatsmore, we believe that making people laugh is good, noble work that will make the world a better place, so putting our skills to work cracking jokes, making faces, talking in funny voices, and pratfalling while taking pies to the face seemed the way to go.

We are planning our inaugural season for 2014 and we want to do it right! This campaign is to help us fund that key first season and lay the foundation for Infinite Jest to make people giggle, chuckle, guffaw, and cackle for years to come and by donating even just a dollar, you will be helping us do just that.

The What:

We are looking for your help producing our inaugural 2 show season. Our plan is to produce the hilarious new whodunnit, HAPPY NO YEAR, by company member Jon Christie as well as John Cariani's quirky collection of romantic comedy one acts set in the fictitious town of ALMOST, MAINE.

Making theatre is expensive and we're poor. Making great theatre is even more expensive and we are still poor. Your contribution will be going towards helping us produce a successful first season. Things like rental fees, marketing expenses, obtaining our 501(c)3 non-profit status, paying our artists (directors, designers, even actors!), costumes, props, sets, performance rights, etc. A sample of the fees we're looking at: $75/performance (rights) = $900/show for 12 performances; $75-100/night for rehearsal = $1875-2500 for 25 rehearsals per show; $850 for 501(c)3 filing; $250 marketing expenses per show, average $300/night for performance (theater rental) = $3600/show for 12 performances, etc, etc. You see how it all adds up? And every fiver, ducat, greenback, sawbuck, and tenner you can afford to contribute will help us immensely!

But nobody wants something for nothing, right? Which is why we are planning some fun and fabulous perks for our donors. First, you'll get the heartwarming knowledge that YOU are a patron of the arts! A case of the warm fuzzies not enough? Don't worry! We'll also be giving shout outs on Facebook and Twitter, so the world can hear of your good deeds. We'll be sending out personalized thank you letters, magnets, t-shirts, tickets to one of our shows or all three, exclusive invites to post-show receptions with company and cast members, reserved seating at performances, and more! It is important to us that you know we appreciate you and what you are doing for us, so thank you, thank you, thank you!!! And if you are not local to LA, don't worry, we will make substitutions to your perks so even if you can't come join us for a performance you can still share in the laughs.

One teeny, tiny little thing...As wonderful as Indiegogo is, if we don't meet our fundraising goal, they'll take more money out of our pocket. That's right! Their cut goes from 4% to 9%, so keep that in mind. We need as much money in our pocket as possible in order to make Infinite Jest a success and we know you want as much of your money as possible to do as much good as possible, so let's make that goal!

The Bang:

Your contribution is incredibly important to us. You will be helping Infinite Jest Theatre Company lay a foundation which will enable us to produce quality theatre in LA for years to come. Additionallly, you will be helping to support many talented artists as they realize their dreams of creating great art in a collaborative and supportive environment. You will also be funding a strong start which will allow us to grow into a company that can give back to the community by creating a playwrite development program and by working with underprivileged children to bring theatre and laughter into their neighborhoods and schools. We have big plans and it all starts with your contribution.

The Other:

Maybe you can't afford to help us in a monetary way. That is okay! If we have sparked your interest and curiousity just a little you can help us a lot by following us on Facebook and Twitter, signing up for our email list so we can tell you when tickets to our shows go on sale and keep you updated as new and exciting developments take place, sharing the link with friends and family who might take a shine to our comedic genius, or if you are local to LA, contact us about volunteering time or donating costumes, sets, or props.

story:
Summing It Up 

After ten years of working as an actor, theatre teacher and director in the Chicago area, I am thrilled to announce I have been accepted into the graduate program at the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland. 

This program will provide training and experience, which will form me into a better practitioner of my art.  In addition,  this training will provide the resources I need to build the theatre company I have always dreamed of creating.

I seek your support to lay the groundwork for my new company and make this year of graduate school in Scotland possible.

What Your Funding Provides

By lending me your support, you will be ensuring I have the funding to cover the following: 

  • Tuition
  • Living Expenses
  • Student Visa
  • Travel Expenses
  • Health Insurance
  • Moving costs                                                                         

About RCS

Formerly known as the Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama, the Conservatoire can trace its roots back to 1845. It is a fully functional art conservatoire located in the heart of Glasgow, offering degree programs in Theatre, Music, Dance, Opera, and Digital Film Production (just to name a few). 

The degree I will be earning is a MA in Classic and Contemporary Text along the acting track. Basically, this program is the equivalent of an American 3-year MFA in one year.

During the first term, there is focus on new work performance text creation and ensemble building. Scenes by Chekhov will be a particular focus with regard to approaches to realism. I will also be given the opportunity to work with direction and writing students on the development of new scripts.

Term two brings with it a special highlight of the RCS program, as I will be studying at the Globe Theatre in London for a month. (I will even be granted the opportunity to perform on the Globe's stage!)  After returning to Glasgow, we will mount full length Shakespeare and Renaissance performances with professional directors.

Additionally, I will have the privilege of studying at the only program in the world with permission to teach the Jacques Lecoq movement technique. To complete my training I will be undertaking a research project of my own design and will have the opportunity to arrange for a professional placement in the theatre of my choice. 

In the last term of my study at RCS, I will be taking in and participating with Edinburgh International Festival and Fringe and collaborating with professional playwrights on new work pieces. The year-end performances will be held in Glasgow, Edinburgh, London, and New York City. 

RCS also makes it a priority to incorporate business, entrepreneurship, and industry etiquette training throughout the year to ensure I graduate as a versatile and enabled practitioner. 

After RCS 

My dream is to build a theatre company dedicated to partnering with non-profit organizations and charities to help make their missions known. It is my hope to inspire audiences, in regard to the worlds most challenging social justice issues, to deeper thought and greater action. 

I hope to build a theatre company whose commitment to education is evident and fully integrated into every project we undertake. I also hope to build a work environment which strives to bring international artists of all disciples together and nurtures them as educators while inspiring them to their best work. 

As an actor, teacher and director, my mission will be to inspire empathy, resilience and joy through disciplined work in theatre film.  My goal will remain to strive for work that is surprising, daring.  I hope to consistently grow as an artist in both excellence and versatility. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to offer financial assistance but still have the desire to support me, here are some other ways you can help:

  • Help spread the word in person and online. Just by posting this link to your facebook page or emailing the link to a friend would be of such help to me.
  • PRAY!  There are so many needs and details that go into planning a year abroad.  Keeping my endeavors in your prayers is the greatest gift you can give me. Email me at jessthigpen@gmail.com to be added to my prayer list if you would like to receive regular prayer request emails.

story:
UPDATE: We got our first funders!!! Thank you very much, this is really amazing!

Please, do not donate without asking for perks! We would love to give you something back! Again, thank you very much for sharing our campain!!! 

World Cup 2014 - Our biggest dream!

Try this memory exercise: - What were you doing at age of 22?

What memories, results, or experience did you remember from that period of time? Perhaps finishing school, a new girlfriend, a specific journey, a Christmas or a exotic vacation.  

Me,  and my dance partner - Bianca both have 22 years old. We are Romania's dance champions at Standard(Ballroom) category. We earned our right to compete for the World Cup. We won a lot of different competitions since we dance together, but none of them can race with our final goal: WORLD CUP!



Our awards and results below:

1st place in 2013 at: National Championship, European Youth Cup, DanceMasters Cup, Varadinum Cup, Alassio Dance Festival, Transilavia Dance Cup, National Cup, Salzburg Open, Krosovice Open, Herrmanstadt Championship, Regional Championship, Bistrita National Contest and many others.


Facts:

  • The competition is being held in 21 September this year.
  • Best two couples from every country in the world have the right to compete.
  • Organizers pay only 1,000$  for every athlete.(only the plane ticket Romania-China is about 1200$)
  • Our federation gives us nothing.(for example, USA gives to every attending athlete about 8,000$ for tickets food, costumes, and as a payment for their contribution) 
  • The total cost for us is about 6,000$ including flight ticket, land transport, food and other expenses. 

I recently get employed at PizzaHut in the city where i study coreography, Cluj-Napoca, trying to raise money for our goal. I earn 100$ per month working as a part-time, 4hrs/day courier.

My dance partner Bianca, is also a student like me, she studies medicine and in weekend works as a saleswoman in a local shop. She earns about 80$ in a month. 

We wouldn't ask for your help if we've had better earnings. Actually, we are just two talented teenagers, champions in our country, a very poor country, with almost zero interest for sports, and zero for dance.

 If we don't have the flight tickets money(2400$) until the confirmation date - 1st of March, we will miss the chance of our life! 


Believe in us!

Our latest results give us confidence that we can enter the finals, we only need your help to get there!

We worked a lot to win the National Championship and we will be working more than ever to achieve our goal. 

With tears in my eyes i really ask for your help, this means everything for us. A life without a normal childhood, filled with training and a lot of hard work may have a happy ending. I sincerely pray to God for this miracle, this is the last chance for us to participate at a World Cup Event.


Here are some sheets of our results in the past year:

  • If you don't want to contribute you can still help us out spreading the word, telling our story to the world, share this page, sending us a mail, leave a message or simply giving us a telepathic good thought. 
  • I am very sorry for the possible writing mistakes, i'm still learning english.
  • You can send us a mail at paulbucur92@yahoo.com expressing your thoughts.(this would be very nice)

Thank you very much and believe in us!

Regarding to perks, the greatest perk from making a contribution here will be the happy knowledge that you are enabling an opportunity to a young boy and girl to dream big and work hard to realize it, and make the dance community proud, both in Romania and abroad! 


Even if we give away some medals and trophies, don't worry, we still have a lot of them remaining for us! (Since 2008 we won more than 70 contests, therefore we would be actually very happy knowing someone has our trophy on their desk or wall.)

story:
What is The Horror!?

The Horror! is an ensemble created, immersive horror piece that explores the ideas of fear and audience choice. It began as a lab production at The Theatre School at DePaul University in March of 2014. It was very well received, but due to the size of the space could only cater to audiences of fifteen for a five performance run. 

Recently, the team was offered the opportunity to give the show new life in a remount at Chicago's Free Street Theatre. This partnership provides a larger and more versatile space as well as the resources necessary to rediscover and expand the show. 

Our hope for The Horror! is that it will provide an alternative to haunted houses that is grounded in the idea of creating an exciting, engaging, thought-provoking, theatrical experience for our audience.

What We Need 

Free Street is providing a space for our production free of cost, however there are many expenses that go into building a production, particularly one that attempts to create the most immersive environment possible. Your generous contributions will be put towards:

  • Set/Props
  • Costumes
  • Chalk and fake blood
  • Marketing/Advertising materials
  • Audience goodies
This production has become a labor of love. The team hopes to continue exploring this project simply because we are excited about making new discoveries and working together once more to create a bigger and better production for a wider audience. No one involved is being paid from these funds. All contributions will go toward creating a higher quality experience for our audience.

    Spreading the Fever

    As a part of Free Street's mission, the team behind The Horror! will host a free workshop for the community about ensemble creation, Horror theatre, and building scares. We aim to train the next generation of fear-mongers.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      We understand that most of our supporters are not high rollers. If you can contribute please do. This could be as little as $1-5 or as much as you have in your bank account. If you are unable to contribute financially, please spread the word to your friends and any theatre or horror fans you may know. This production will only be possible with your help, and whatever form that takes is greatly appreciated.

story:
Who we are
Around Movement Project

A thought, a hint, an introspective need, three structurally different artists in search of a path that represents a creative project, an artistic idea between other trails. The meeting is the empathetic fusion of three persons artistically different but well defined: Elisa Bartoli performer, Paolo Cavallin music composer and maker, Massimiliano Del Testa texts, images, videos.


Project
Viva Dentro
"Viva Dentro" (Alive inside) is the brainchild of Elisa Bartoli, inspired and freely adapted from the text of "Corrispondenza negata" (Denied mail), a book of collected letters of inmates of the Psychiatric Hospital of Volterra (Tuscany - Italy), written to loved ones, that the hospital administration has never sent to the recipient and has stored in the medical records of membership




Theatrical performance in five movements of theater-dance with the insections of a speaker (Cledy Tancredi) who read the original letters from "Corrispondenza negata" and set in the beginning of 1910. In this reading emerges as not all internees in the psychiatric hospital of Volterra (1888-1978) were really suffering for a psychiatric illness, but a good part of them represented a diversity, a non-conformity to the socio-cultural standard.

We found that the documents for the internment were politically or socio-cultural motivated: just being eccentric or deeply shy, first female child to be born in a noble or rich family (where the noble title belonged to the eldest male son), be suffering from disease not well framed (then) as epilepsy, having some functional impairment such as blindness, deafness, infertility (which of course was recognized as a female disease) or, finally, be poor, gay or illegitimate child.

When the society did not recognize one of its members, for fear or simply for easy management, it close him/her in its structure for a long time or forever, without  any respect for the individual.

This dark and impenetrable universe in Volterra was generated in 1888 and went on for 90 years.

It 's astonishing that in a century has not changed anything yet!

Inspired by a so important book we decided to create a theatrical performance in five movements through a fusion of theater, dance, original music and the reading of letters taken from authentic Mail Denied, which depicts how human diversity  was violated and marked for life.

The five movements are:
  • The violence.
  • Youth.
  • Internment.
  • Living in asylum.
  • Towards the abyss.

The performance with the help of www.esplorazioneurbane.it which helps us logistically, will go to the cities with psychiatric hospitals now closed.

The donations we ask we will need to physically set up the hardware system of organization and the logistics base, to be able to replicate the performance.

Costs include:

  • Isadora Software
  • Two rear projection
  • Motion Detector
  • Stage Costumes
  • Reconstruction of the original dresses
  • Props
  • Theatrical setting
  • Supports for rear projection
  • System Time-Code WIFI to the stage (Arduino)

If you can not support us financially, we understand, then we ask if you can help us to raise our demand for sustainability through FB, twitter, email and so on.

simply for easy management, it close him/her in its structure for a long time or
forever, without  any respect for the
individual. 
This dark and impenetrable universe in Volterra was generated in
1888 and went on for 90 years. 
It 's astonishing that in a century has not changed anything yet! 
Inspired by a so important book we decided to create a theatrical
performance in five movements through a fusion of theater, dance, original
music and the reading of letters taken from authentic Mail Denied, which
depicts how human diversity  was violated
and marked for life.
The five movements are: 

The violence.
Youth.
Internment. 
Living in asylum.
Towards the abyss. 

The performance with the help of www.esplorazioneurbane.it which
helps us logistically, will go to the cities with psychiatric hospitals now
closed.
The donations we ask we will need to physically set up
the hardware system of organization and the logistics base, to be able to
replicate the performance.Costs include:
Isadora Software
Two rear projection
Motion Detector
Stage Costumes
Reconstruction of the original dresses
Props
Theatrical setting
Supports for rear projection
System Time-Code WIFI to the stage (Arduino) 

If you can not support us financially, we understand, then we ask
if you can help us to raise our demand for sustainability through FB, twitter,
email and so on.

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Matt Wagner. I am a student at Oakland University in Michigan. I am a dancer, gymnast, choreographer, coach, teacher, martial artist, costume designer. :) As part of finishing my BFA in Dance, I will be doing a study abroad in Berlin, Germany this May.
  • This campaign is designed to help raise the necessary funds to get me to Berlin. I will be creating a new piece over the next couple months and wish to present it in a student run show at the Free University of Berlin.
  • Without you, non of this would be possible. Your contributions will not only help with the expenses of traveling to Berlin, but will also go to cover things like space rental, costuming, music/light design, and dancers.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $6,000 for this trip. This covers airfare (~$1,200), tuition through the university (~$1,600), passport (~$200), room/board/travel/etc. (~$3,000).
  • Perks: Don't think you get nothing in return! For a $5 donation you will receive exclusive access to behind the scenes footage of the creation/rehearsal process. For $15 you will receive the behind the scenes access and 1 complimentary ticket to our premier showing at Oakland University. For $30 you get behind the scenes access, 1 complimentary ticket, and free admittance to our "Dessert With the Dancers" after-party!
  • Not meeting our goal is not an option. We are looking into grants and scholarships and the like, so one way or another we plan on going to Berlin. It is, however, an added bonus if we can do so with the help of people like you. That way we also get to share our craft with even more amazing people.

The Impact

  • I believe art always makes the world a better place. Whether it brings beauty, allows self expression, or makes people think. Our project is an artistic endeavor we wish to share far and wide. For me this venture is an attempt to further explore what dance is and what it means.
  • As a choreographer, I have set works on the student company at Oakland University three times. I am about to start working on another one for them along with the piece for Berlin and the piece for my Senior Showcase.
  • I cannot promise that you will like or enjoy what we create. The nature of the process I will be using with this piece is one that is a little unpredictable. That means even I don't know exactly how it will turn out. Regardless, I hope you will join us on this adventure. When all is said and done we will have a dance. What form it will take................ well, you'll just have to wait and see.

Risks & Challenges

  • As dancers we are trained to understand that nothing will ever go exactly the way you think it should. It' not about getting something right, it's about enjoying what you do and how you work with what you're given.
  • With a project this big I know there will be issues. Someone could get sick, a passport might not come in time, a dancer gets injured, the space we perform in isn't the same as where we rehearsed, etc, etc, etc. I choose not to dwell on all the things that might be. There is equal probability that any given scenario will happen or will not happen. We will deal with those as they arise and do our best to eliminate the possibility of as many issues as we can.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people will not be able to contribute, and that's fine. That doesn't mean they can't help:

  • If you cannot contribute monetarily to our project, please pass the word along to everyone you know.
  • If 1,000 people give only $6, we will have reached our goal! Share on Facebook, twitter, or any other social media you may use. Send a couple quick emails or a text or two. Maybe a few phone calls. Indiegogo also has some share tools. Your support, in whatever form it comes, will make all the difference.


Thank you in advance,

Matt Wagner

story:
What is Theatre 68?

Theatre 68 and the 68 Cent Crew Theatre Company is a community dedicated to assisting actors, writers, directors, and producers in the realization of their creative and professional identity through the interpretation of the written word.

The theatre company is committed to building character, cultivating high self-esteem, and facilitating positive social change through artistic excellence and professional transformation. 

Our Story

After leaving New York, our artistic director, Ronnie Marmo, had some initial success in Hollywood.  But he quickly found himself lonely, lost and wishing he had a community of people who shared the same values and passion. Thus, the 68 Cent Crew Theatre Company began, with five members rehearsing scenes in a living room. 

Other theatre companies focus mainly on putting up productions.  But the 68 Cent Crew Theatre Company is about nurturing artists and exposing them to all aspects of the business so they can find their voice and discover who they are as an artist.  We believe that if you feel loved, supported and respected you will do your best work.  And we have done some amazing work! 

Over the past 15 years, Theatre 68 has produced over ninety plays between the Los Angeles and the New York City chapters including:

·  The critically acclaimed Bill W. and Dr. Bob, which has enjoyed 350+ sold out performances.

·  World Premiere of the musical Serial Killer Barbie

·  World Premiere of 86’d

·  First-ever 13 by Shanley Festival (John Patrick Shanley)

·  World Premiere of John Patrick Shanley's Last Night In The Garden I Saw You and the Los Angeles Premiere of Shanley’s Storefront Church.

·  Los Angeles Premiere of Sam Shepard's The Late Henry Moss

·  40th Anniversary production of Lovers and Other Strangers,

·  Nominated by the NAACP Awards for the productions of The Knights of Mary Phagan and Subway Series and, most recently

·  Won BEST PLAY 2015 – Connect – Valley Theatre Awards.

All this magic took place at Theatre 68, a carpet warehouse converted into a beautiful 99 seat theatre, where we resided for ten years.  Unfortunately, the building was sold, and we have been looking for a new, permanent home for the past three years.

We're happy to announce that we've finally found a new space, and we're moving in August!  Once again, we plan to put our blood, sweat and tears into building a place where our company can continue to grow and support each other, while also bringing amazing art to the community.

Theatre 68’s New Home

If you've ever seen a show at the Antaeus Theatre (formerly Deaf West Theatre) in North Hollywood, you'll know what a beautiful theatre it is.  And we are incredibly grateful to be able to say that it is to be the new home of Theatre 68.  Located a mere block from the Noho Arts Center, we will continue to be in the hustle and bustle of the Noho Arts District, only now we'll be in a bigger and more beautiful space of our very own.

Of course, that's not enough for our visionary Artistic Director Ronnie Marmo. Ronnie has some big ideas, which will make the space even better! The plans include new bathrooms, dressing rooms, a master lobby, and (this is the best part) a SECOND THEATRE SPACE where we can foster more creativity, create and produce more art, and contribute more nightlife and commerce to the surrounding community. 

Unfortunately, we can’t possibly do this alone. We, the members of the 68 Cent Crew, have time, energy, and initiative; what we don't have is MOOLAH, which we have to have to build a brand new shiny Theatre 68.

What We Need

Listen... we know we need a lot.  Our total goal is to raise $40,000 through a three-tiered fundraising campaign:  Indiegogo, and Opening Gala.

The $40,000 will cover the following expenses:

Demolition & Removal:    $4000.00

Framing:  $3500.00

Plumbing:  $5000.00

Electrical:  $5000.00

Drywall   $4000.00

Soundproofing:      $6000.00

Paint:  $3000.00

Marquee:  $5000.00

Contingency Fund:  $4500.00

In order to succeed, we need to meet our first fundraising goalof $17,500.00 with this INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN!

This amount will get us all the way through finishing the electrical, and well on our way to completion!

What We Give

Theatre 68 has so much to offer, not just to our members, but also to the local community and beyond. 

Theatre 68 is committed to exposing our members to all aspects of the entertainment world.  Through our productions, our members not only get to act, but they also get opportunities to work on their writing, directing and producing.  Our members enjoy two writing assignments every year where they write a one-act play that is ultimately produced.  Many of our members who had never written before have gone on to be prolific and successful writers!  We participate in monologue jams, directing workshops, and have a weekly “gym” where everybody gets to work on improv, cold reading, audition techniques and prepared scenes, and they receive constructive feedback from their peers. In this new space, with two theatres and a rehearsal space, we will have even more opportunities for our members!

In addition, the new space is set to have a Play/Book Store where the community can come to purchase plays, and a trained employee will be on site to help people select scenes and monologues. 

Our company is dedicated to producing socially conscious material, such as the current run of “Bill W and Dr. Bob.”  We also are involved with various philanthropies including Habitat For Humanity, Fans In The Stands for the Special Olympics, and the Sharing The Spirit Holiday Party with the Festival of Children. 

The Impact

In addition to everything we just mentioned, our company offers something else to our members, which is not as tangible, but is possibly even more important.  Theatre 68 has, from it’s inception, provided a safe place for people, and has given a community, a home, and a family to people who are otherwise trudging through this often difficult business alone.  We work on our craft and grow and learn together, which is something that is hard to come by in this crazy business.  Our members who have made the theatre their home and family, the theatre-goers who have enjoyed our productions for the past fifteen years, and the greater community that has benefited from our contributions to the arts and humanities, ALL will all be positively impacted by this new theatre space.  By helping us build our new home, you are really helping artists, supporting live theatre in L.A., and helping our community!

Now isn’t that something you can feel good about?

Other Ways You Can Help-

Talk about us on social media! 

Facebook:  facebook.com/68centcrew/

Twitter:  @theatre68

Instagram:  @68CentCrew
