story:
What Is Zombie Asian Moms?

This campaign is for Zombie Asian Moms: the newest project by Slanty Eyed Mama aka. Asian American artists Kate Siahaan-Rigg and Lyris Hung. We are conducting oral history interviews with real Asian moms to expand the discussion on how cultural ideas and identities can get passed down through generations and live forever, sometimes consuming your brain- like zombies. 

First, we will premiere the show live from Nov. 29-Dec 9, 2018  in New York at the Tony Award Winning Theater La MaMa ETC.  (where we premiered Happy Lucky Golden Tofu Panda Dragon Good Time Fun Fun Show two years ago to great acclaim.) Then, it will be documented and expanded to become a documentary/concert film for festivals, online release and as a teaching tool.

We started Slanty Eyed Mama while studying at the Juilliard School in New York City to create works that speak to a new generAsian of North Americans by using the language of pop culture: comedy, rap, rock, spoken-word poetry. We have played the Smithsonian Institute (with Birth of a nASIAN and Americasiana), The Comedy Central Theater, LOGO television, PBS, many Asian Heritage Celebrations, Comedy festivals, Music festivals, Contemporary Art Museums and Universities. Our work combines cultural identity politics and a discussion of racial politics with a mashup of music, comedy and improvisation. 

If we reach our goal of 10K, it will fund the bulk of  the live shows at La MaMa and the audio visual recording of those shows. But the budget for the whole project is around 45K (see breakdown below.) We are undertaking this more ambitious project because our shows are often used as teaching tools for younger people, and we want to have a shareable, easily accessible document of the work that can be used to fight racism, promote understanding, empathy and compassion while providing Asian Americans a voice in the conversation about what makes an "American" family.

We have always self-funded, self-propelled, paid from touring, paid from our other gigs and side hustle. We play in big venues for thousands of people as well as in small college dorm rooms. The message is the media and we are devoted to giving voice to those American Asians who don't have a prominent place in popular media. But normally, our reach is limited to our touring time. We are seeking funding to help us to continue to record our work and be able to send it out to colleges and communities who are seeking to expand their discourse on diversity and inclusion, two critical initiatives that these times demand. 

What We Need

We need help this time to make our work happen. Self-funded tours cleaned us out a little this year, and our grant money fell through. We are tapping savings, but let's face it we are artists-- it isn't enough.  We need funds mostly to pay the artists and technicians we need to bring their expertise to the project. We don't pay ourselves out of this campaign, Lyris and Kate both put in their own savings to allot time, costumes, rehearsal and equipment to create the work. But we need people to help us put up the live show in New York: lighting, design, sound, projections.  For the film version, we need help for photogtaphy, edit, sound mix and design and animation.  We are keeping this indie, nimble and bare bones, but an infusion of funds will help us launch the live show and start filming while we go out and earn more money by hustling and touring to finish the project.  Our total preliminary budget looks like this:

Barebones Breakdown:

-Live show production costs  include space rental, hiring a designer and lighting designer, costumes, props, some video editing, equipment, front of house costs, printing: 8K

-Recording and sound mixing the live shows: 5K

-Additional filming with Asian moms and location shoots: 7K

-Post production costs including sound mix, edit: 10K

-Fees for director, publicist,  art design, after effects: 10K

-Insurance, Tax, Admin, Fire proofing, Festival applications: 5K

= 45K 

What you Get

Because we have never done a fundraiser campaign we have LOTS of great prizes and rewards to for you to select. We have separated them out into affordable a la carte style offerings so you can pick more than one or buy a bundle!  From live concerts in your house, to Slanty Eyed Mama CD's, T-Shirts, tickets to premieres, digital downloads, original songs and haiku art created for you, and a lucky surprise perk where we send you a hand selected gift from our treasure trove of Amerasian pop culture artifacts. 

The Impact

When people are exposed to stories about diverse communities, it breeds empathy, understanding and compassion. And when a minority group sees itself reflected in a popular form of media like comedy or contemporary art, it builds bridges and strengthens community. Through our work,  Asians who are still treated like "foreigners" in their own country get to see reflections of other Amerasians who share their experience as daughters and grand daughters of immigrants. And particularly for young people:  when you don't see images of yourself out there in the world, there is no success paradigm, there is nothing to shoot for and you are caught between the impossible demands of your Asian Ancestors and the racially biased America that sees you as "not really american". We are all in this together.  A show about crazy, beautiful, intense, cute, sassy, lenient, strict moms who happen to be Asian can deepen our connections to each other and combat racism, depression, social dysfunction and other ills that come from seeing minority groups as "other".

We are making a movie of the live shows so we can reach audiences all over North America who can't make it to see us in person.

Other Ways You Can Help

An easy way to help is to follow us on Instagram Twitter and Facebook @slantyeyedmama.  It's free, we are not spammers and it will automatically help us by showing the world that voices from diverse artists are valuable. So if nothing else, please add us on social. 

You can also: come to see our show, spread this campaign around social media,  invite us to play a concert at your school or venue, and check out our website.
story_txt:
What Is Zombie Asian Moms?
This campaign is for Zombie Asian Moms: the newest project by Slanty Eyed Mama aka. Asian American artists Kate Siahaan-Rigg and Lyris Hung. We are conducting oral history interviews with real Asian moms to expand the discussion on how cultural ideas and identities can get passed down through generations and live forever, sometimes consuming your brain- like zombies. 
First, we will premiere the show live from Nov. 29-Dec 9, 2018  in New York at the Tony Award Winning Theater La MaMa ETC.  (where we premiered Happy Lucky Golden Tofu Panda Dragon Good Time Fun Fun Show two years ago to great acclaim.) Then, it will be documented and expanded to become a documentary/concert film for festivals, online release and as a teaching tool.
We started Slanty Eyed Mama while studying at the Juilliard School in New York City to create works that speak to a new generAsian of North Americans by using the language of pop culture: comedy, rap, rock, spoken-word poetry. We have played the Smithsonian Institute (with Birth of a nASIAN and Americasiana), The Comedy Central Theater, LOGO television, PBS, many Asian Heritage Celebrations, Comedy festivals, Music festivals, Contemporary Art Museums and Universities. Our work combines cultural identity politics and a discussion of racial politics with a mashup of music, comedy and improvisation. 
If we reach our goal of 10K, it will fund the bulk of  the live shows at La MaMa and the audio visual recording of those shows. But the budget for the whole project is around 45K (see breakdown below.) We are undertaking this more ambitious project because our shows are often used as teaching tools for younger people, and we want to have a shareable, easily accessible document of the work that can be used to fight racism, promote understanding, empathy and compassion while providing Asian Americans a voice in the conversation about what makes an "American" family.
We have always self-funded, self-propelled, paid from touring, paid from our other gigs and side hustle. We play in big venues for thousands of people as well as in small college dorm rooms. The message is the media and we are devoted to giving voice to those American Asians who don't have a prominent place in popular media. But normally, our reach is limited to our touring time. We are seeking funding to help us to continue to record our work and be able to send it out to colleges and communities who are seeking to expand their discourse on diversity and inclusion, two critical initiatives that these times demand. 

What We Need
We need help this time to make our work happen. Self-funded tours cleaned us out a little this year, and our grant money fell through. We are tapping savings, but let's face it we are artists-- it isn't enough.  We need funds mostly to pay the artists and technicians we need to bring their expertise to the project. -Live show production costs  include space rental, hiring a designer and lighting designer, costumes, props, some video editing, equipment, front of house costs, printing: 8K
-Recording and sound mixing the live shows: 5K
-Additional filming with Asian moms and location shoots: 7K
-Post production costs including sound mix, edit: 10K
-Fees for director, publicist,  art design, after effects: 10K
-Insurance, Tax, Admin, Fire proofing, Festival applications: 5K
= 45K 
What you Get
Because we have never done a fundraiser campaign we have LOTS of great prizes and rewards to for you to select. We have separated them out into affordable a la carte style offerings so you can pick more than one or buy a bundle!  From live concerts in your house, to Slanty Eyed Mama CD's, T-Shirts, tickets to premieres, digital downloads, original songs and haiku art created for you, and a lucky surprise perk where we send you a hand selected gift from our treasure trove of Amerasian pop culture artifacts. 

The Impact

And when a minority group sees itself reflected in a popular form of media like comedy or contemporary art, it builds bridges and strengthens community. Through our work,  Asians who are still treated like "foreigners" in their own country get to see reflections of other Amerasians who share their experience as daughters and grand daughters of immigrants. And particularly for young people:  when you don't see images of yourself out there in the world, there is no success paradigm, there is nothing to shoot for and you are caught between the impossible demands of your Asian Ancestors and the racially biased America that sees you as "not really american". An easy way to help is to follow us on Instagram Twitter and Facebook @slantyeyedmama.  It's free, we are not spammers and it will automatically help us by showing the world that voices from diverse artists are valuable. So if nothing else, please add us on social. 
You can also: come to see our show, spread this campaign around social media,  invite us to play a concert at your school or venue, and check out our website.

story:
What is Who Rowed Across Oceans?

Who Rowed Across Oceans "is an obituary play. It’s just like every other play about life, or, in other words, it’s like every other play, except we know who dies. And that's not the suspense, the suspense is the how -- how does a life get lived?"

Lost Compass Collective was founded in 2013 to produce Danielle Littman's new play "Who Rowed Across Oceans." Inspired by Margalit Fox's New York Times obituary of John Fairfax -- a poetic account of a man who rowed across the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans 'because [they were] there' -- the piece will explore this question of how a life is lived. The collaboration between playwright Danielle Littman, director Jeremy Ohringer and producers Dylan Pickus and Kelley Abell will culminate in a Chicago production in late July 2014. The collective's ultimate goal is to take the production across the Atlantic to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in August 2014. If there is a play that must travel across an ocean, this is it.

John Fairfax's life is an example that asks us to be bold and fearless in our own. With "Who Rowed Across Oceans," Lost Compass Collective will explore the joys and risks of such a life.

Fundraising for Edinburgh

We are using our Indiegogo campaign to raise money for our August production of Who Rowed Across Oceans at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. Below you'll find our breakdown of projected expenditures.

Airfare
 $9,000 for travel from Chicago to Edinburgh in August
Application Fee    $500 for us to apply to the official Edinburgh Fringe Festival   
Space Rental $1,600 for our one week run in our Edinburgh venue  
Lodgings $1,600 for actor and creative team accommodations in Edinburgh  
Shipping $300 for transporting our minimal set and costumes  
Total $13,000

All donations will be used toward these ends and are TAX-DEDUCTABLE. Lost Compass Collective is fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization. You can view our page on the Fractured Atlas website here.

Team and Cast

CAST

Will Kiley

Amelia Hefferon

Claire Saxe

Mandy Modic

Garrett Lutz

Kelley Abell

TEAM

Playwright - Danielle Littman

Director - Jeremy Ohringer

Artistic Producer - Kelley Abell

Business Producer - Dylan Pickus

Designer - Daphne Kim

Composer - Patrick Budde

Chicago Space Coordinator - Elsa Gay

Videographer - Will Sonheim

Website - Louis Schermerhorn

Curious about Who Rowed Across Oceans?

If you have any questions about the production or have any other ideas about how you can help, please contact us at lostcompasscollective@gmail.com.

story:
Introduction

Konnichiwa, I'm Stefhen Bryan, coming to you with my latest work, Doodu Boy, as I move into exciting new territory: the theater. Doodu Boy is an autobiographical story of my struggle across three continents to find unconditional love in the face of an abusive mother and absent father.

The play is written/performed by me and dramaturged/directed by Jared Scheib.

Synopsis: The story begins with my frightening childhood in a Jamaican ghetto on a church commune, where I fall into the neighborhood cesspool and earn my nickname: Doodu Boy. I soon escape to America where I've long dreamt of roadtrips with my dad, but life never seems to fulfill those hopes. After multiple attempts on my own life, learning the shocking truth of my origins, and a show-down with an NYPD armada as I attempt to reconnect with my father, I ultimately leave the West to begin a rebirth in Japan. There, in the midst of a sexual rampage, I meet a girl who promises the beginnings of the deep connection that I've always wanted.


Why 'Doodu Boy' Matters

'Doodu Boy' is a testament to perseverance. If 'Doodu Boy' can be an inspiration to anyone who has been rejected and spurned by a parent, or parents, then my work is done. Know that you're not alone. I stand with you in solidarity.


The Plan

We plan to do a 4-week run in both Los Angeles and San Francisco, and this campaign will cover the costs for the first 2 weeks of each of those. Our ultimate goal is to perform this play in cities large and small around the United States and the globe, including New York City, where we've already got an off-Broadway run in the works.

Now, with your help, I'll be able to share my story on stage. This is a universal story of the search for love in the face of rejection, about the universal drive to unconditional love. Each performance is an opportunity for you to experience that powerful journey and triumph.


Supporting the Campaign

In order to launch a successful first run of Doodu Boy, your help is needed to raise $7,500 to cover the cost of:

  • Theater rentals
  • Advertising and marketing expenses
  • Producer's fee
  • Director's fee
  • Transportation
  • Hoses, water, Lysol, Pine-Sol, Dettol and Jeyes disinfectant, to wash the doodu off of me

Apart from supporting financially, you can most definitely help by spreading the word and sharing the news and link to this campaign via email and all social media.


Thank You

Infinite thanks for making this all possible. I look forward to performing Doodu Boy for you.


About the Team

Stefhen Bryan is the author of the critically acclaimed Black Passenger Yellow Cabs: A Memoir of Exille and Excess in Japan and the recently publishing novel Only Begotten. He currently lives in Kobe and Los Angeles with his wife, who is translating Doodu Boy to Japanese, for performance in Japan. After a monumentally successful two weeks of previews at the Santa Monica Playhouse, he's excited to finally take Doodu Boy "on the road."

Jared Scheib is the dramaturge and director of Doodu Boy, his second play after Wrestles With Machista.  He recently completed the festival run for his first feature documentary film, The Mayor, and is in post-production on his second, tentatively titled Love Potatoes.  His commercial, Do You Believe in a Secular America?, won the Richard Dawkins Foundation for Reason and Science’s social media contest.  His films have been exhibited at the Directors Guild of America (Hollywood), Dallas Museum of Art, Tel Aviv Cinematheque, Auckland Art Gallery, and Roxie Theater (San Francisco), broadcast on television in Texas (PBS) and Israel (Channel 8), and distributed online via iTunes, Amazon, and SnagFilms.  In addition to film and theater, Jared manages friend and artist, Cecelia Webber, whose human bodies artwork has gone viral worldwide.  Jared is an artist-entrepreneur from Dallas, Texas with a B.A. from the University of Southern California, where he studied film production in the School of Cinematic Arts and neuroscience as an inaugural member of the Brain and Creativity Institute.  Jared believes that content is king, and to that end he imbues his works with universality, authenticity, and intensity, striving to emphasize what makes art meaningful: honest emotion. See more at http://jaredscheib.com.

story:
Short Summary

Aerial Dance is really new in South Africa. We are far away from Europe and America and our access to good training material and teachers is limited. And more importantly, we have NO-ONE to tell us if our rigging is safe!

What We Need & What You Get

We are bringing Brett Copes to South Africa in April 2014 to teach his 'Rigging for Aerialists' workshop in both Johannesburg and Cape Town. To do this, we need to pay for his flights to and from Las Vegas, USA; we need to pay his expenses while he is here (including transport between Cape Town and Johannesburg) and we need to cover his costs for the workshops. While we will be charging for the workshops, with the Rand:Dollar exchange being about R10:$1, we cannot cover all the costs through workshop fees alone.

We NEED your help! And we want to give you something to reward you for your donations.

The Impact

By contributing to this project, you will be directly impacting the cost of the workshop tickets. The workshops are being hosted by Sky Dance Studio, but we are not planning to make a proft from the workshops, but to make them as affordable as possible so as many members of the community as possible can attend.

Please share this campaign with your friends in and outside the aerial community and help us make our local community safer!

story:
Join us in supporting our new work Falling into Here or The Importance of Normal!

Thank you in advance for your crucial support of The Naked Stark’s new work Falling into Here or The Importance of Normal presented by First Person Arts RAW in the First Person Arts Festival next month at Christ Church Neighborhood House in Philadelphia, November 8 & 9 @ 7pm

What is normal?  Choreographer and director Katherine Kiefer Stark explores self and sanity in this haunting new autobiographical/biographical work, Falling into Here or The Importance of Normal.  Set within a complex of ever-shifting floors and walls, dancers spiral, build, and unravel as imagined and actual realities collapse around them.  Grappling with these alternative planes and trying to ignore gravity, they confront the undeniable presence of normal. 

We are thrilled to be a part of this incredible one-of-a-kind festival featuring powerful personal stories from leading national artists and everyday people.  Since 2010, First Person Arts RAW has put the spotlight on artists who are pushing the boundaries of traditional memoir and documentary art.  The program showcases work that is recent, innovative, and inspired by real life experiences across all genres. 

Being presented by First Person Arts RAW is an incredible opportunity to perform our work in a beautiful venue with technical support and to work with Artistic Advisor Ed Sobel. 

We need your help to meet our end of the budget for this performance!

Your contributions will directly support:

  • Four Fabulous Dancers Eleanor Goudie-Averill, Beau Hancock, Katherine Kiefer Stark, Megan Wilson Stern
  • Original music & sound design by Paul Stern
  • Live performance by a pianist and cellist
  • Project Manager Lora Allen
  • Set/props including a ladder, building supplies for our portable walls, markers, masking tape, large rolls of paper
  • Costumes
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Printing Design and Costs
  • Documentation


We greatly appreciate contributions of all sizes! 

THANK YOU!

Katherine, Lora, & Megan

Katherine Kiefer Stark, Artistic Director
Lora Allen, Managing Director
Megan Wilson Stern, Development Director


The Naked Stark is a Philadelphia-based contemporary dance company.  Company founder and artistic director, Katherine Kiefer Stark's interest in investigating and deconstructing our everyday relationships with social norms and the US political system fuels our work.  Dedicated to the philosophy that works of art can stimulate social change, The Naked Stark is committed to movement as expression, movement as re-invention, and movement as power.  We strive to move people through our performances, as part of community projects, and in workshops and classes. 

Learn more about us at thenakedstark.com

story:
Hi! My name is Nikolaos Hartnett, and I love to dance! View the video by clicking 'Gallery' and the video will be right there!

Under the direction of Tammy Kanode, my ballet instructor in Lynchburg, my solo entitled “Sail” received first place at Dance Machine’s regional competition in March, and in April I was awarded a partial scholarship from Celebration Talent’s regional competition to attend master classes in Los Angeles, California. It is the best opportunity to take master classes, meet with choreographers who are in the industry, and attend a taping of “So You Think You Can Dance” among other scheduled events. Celebration Talent awards only two scholarships at each of their 28 regional competitions, usually resulting in 20–30 dancers from their venue attending program in the summer. 

My dad works two jobs and my mom home schools me and my younger sister.  We live an hour from my dance studio so a lot of time is taken up traveling.  My mother helps sew some of the costumes to pay for dance classes so there are not many funds left over to fuel a dream.

This is where your contribution will make a difference. California is a long way from Virginia. Classes are very expensive. The full week of master classes and hotel for a chaperone and I costs $4,700. Airfare, food, shuttle services, and other traveling expenses are also needed. That is why I could really use your help and support. I will take my solo to Shenandoah University in the coming year as my audition piece to their BFA program in dance. If accepted, I plan to major in dance and also pursue their Masters in Arts Management degree. The classes in California will help me to hone my technique and broaden who I am creatively. I know it will increase my chances for a future, a successful future in dance!

I can assure you that by contributing to this fund you are investing in hard work, resolve in adversity, but most importantly in the art of dance that translates personal experience into a form to speak to others that transforms the spirit, encourages and excites that part in all of us that dares us to live fully, to dream, to persevere.

I am thankful to my Creator who graced me with a desire to dance. I am grateful to my family, the families of my studios who have encouraged me with their kindness and support. I am thankful for the encouragement of Rodney Williams and the Longwood Company of Dancers, Tammy Kanode, my ballet teacher and Marquis Mapp, my hip-hop, jazz and modern teacher. They have been with me on this journey of growth and without them I would have not realized the dancer within. 

I encourage you all to dream, to take a risk - for we only fail when we fail to try.

Should I not reach my goal, I will use the funds to further my dance education with Master classes that are not in California. Although, California would be an incredible experience, it is a joy to dance and I will pursue excellence in any form it is presented to me!

To each who have taken the time to read this, thank you very much. If you can donate, your contributions are greatly appreciated! Thank you for supporting my dream!
story_txt:
Hi!
My name is Nikolaos Hartnett, and I love to dance! View the video by clicking
'Gallery' and the video will be right there!
Under
the direction of Tammy Kanode, my ballet instructor in Lynchburg, my solo
entitled “Sail” received first place at Dance Machine’s regional competition in
March, and in April I was awarded a partial scholarship from Celebration
Talent’s regional competition to attend master classes in Los Angeles,
California. It is the best opportunity to take master classes, meet with
choreographers who are in the industry, and attend a taping of “So You Think
You Can Dance” among other scheduled events. Celebration Talent awards only two
scholarships at each of their 28 regional competitions, usually resulting in
20–30 dancers from their venue attending program in the summer. 
My
dad works two jobs and my mom home schools me and my younger sister.  We
live an hour from my dance studio so a lot of time is taken up traveling.
 My mother helps sew some of the costumes to pay for dance classes so
there are not many funds left over to fuel a dream.
This
is where your contribution will make a difference. California is a long way
from Virginia. Classes are very expensive. The full week of master classes and
hotel for a chaperone and I costs $4,700. Airfare, food, shuttle services, and
other traveling expenses are also needed. That is why I could really use your
help and support. I will take my solo to Shenandoah University in the coming
year as my audition piece to their BFA program in dance. If accepted, I plan to
major in dance and also pursue their Masters in Arts Management degree. The
classes in California will help me to hone my technique and broaden who I am
creatively. I know it will increase my chances for a future, a successful
future in dance!
I can assure you that by contributing
to this fund you are investing in hard work, resolve in adversity, but most
importantly in the art of dance that translates personal experience into a form
to speak to others that transforms the spirit, encourages and excites that part

story:
Our Current State

Since 2005, Plainfield North has been putting on great stage shows for our audiences.  In order to continue these performances we need to update our systems to the current day’s equipment.  We have not updated any equipment in our theatre since the school opened back in 2005 and the new equipment from those years is now falling out of date and causing problems.

A Plan of Action

With the contributions you provide we will improve our theatre in many ways. Some of which include:

  • Purchase a digital soundboard, which will aid the live sound of all productions held in the theatre
  • Permanently hang microphones from the ceiling to record concerts
  • Purchase new intercom headsets so the crew can communicate with each other throughout the theatre
  • Purchase an air compressor and tools for our shop

The Big Picture

With your help, we can make this high school theatre into a high-end, professional theatre.  We can put on shows that will entice new people from around the area.  This theatre means a lot to everyone who works in it and with it and we would all love to see this dream become a reality.

Other Ways To Make A Difference

Even if you can't directly support us, we still ask that you share this Indiegogo page and pass it along to you family, friends, coworkers, and anyone you pass walking on the sidewalk.  We greatly appreciate all the support you can give us, whether monetary or just spreading the word, everyone can make a difference.

story:
The Journey of Bravo: a new musical... 

Three years ago, three dewey eyed and optimistic aspiring writers began working on what would become Bravo: a new musical. Meet the writers! 

  • CRISTIAN GUERRERO (Book and Lyrics) 
  • ANDREW MOORHEAD (Book and Lyrics) 
  • STEVEN SCHMIDT (Music and Lyrics) 

The first production of BRAVO premiered in Los Angeles in July 2014. Recently, selections from BRAVO were selected as finalists for the 2017 New Voices Project produced by New Musicals Inc. and Walt Disney Imagineering, a workshop showcase for new musical theater from emerging writers. Help us make a staged reading of the newest incarnation of BRAVO a reality. New story, new songs, and new characters. 

What is Bravo about? 

At the height of the Nazi Invasion of Italy during World War II, a young Italian man hides six Jews and refugees to spare them from extermination. When their secret hiding place is discovered by an adolescent Fascist soldier, an unlikely bond is formed. 

Why now? 

At it's heart, Bravo is a heartfelt story about a group of people who are hated and discriminated against. The three writers can agree that the social issues and depictions of minorities presented in Bravo are incredibly relevant today. Being that the show's protagonists are adolescents and young adults, we hope to give a voice to those alive during World War II that might not have lived long enough to tell their story. We are compelled to share Bravo with audiences because it explores empathy, acceptance, love, and what it is to be a human to another human. 

What we need...

Even though this is not a full production, there are still many production costs. Your donation will go towards...

  • Live musicians 
  • The venue 
  • And snacks and tea for our wonderful cast of actors who are lending their talents to us for free!

story:
Who am I and Why am I Doing This Project: 

My name is Casey Marie, and I am an emerging theatre artist based out of the Twin Cities. Although I am early in my career, I am driven and self-motivated. I have always believed that theatre can be used in more ways then just to entertain an audience.  Which brings me to:

February 14th, 2018; a day that was suppose to be filled with love was instead filled will tears and dismay. I remember refreshing my web page, as more and more information about the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School came in. By the end of the day, 17 students and teachers had died; by the end of the week, a movement was started. 

I supported the movement, joined in the marches, called my representatives, and yes, posted crazily on Facebook. I thought there had to be more I could do, but, with my limited skill set and resources, what? That's when this project started. 

I found a number of short scenes and monologues through Protest Plays Project that I hope will give an audience a perspective on mass shootings that they haven't thought about before. After each performance we will have talkback discussions with our audience, our artists, and members of non profit organizations who are already fighting for gun control.  Through these discussions, we hope to not only have impactful conversations, but we also to connect passionate audience members with groups in their neighborhoods to help the cause.

Where Does the Money Go:

Even though this project is being independently produced I still fully believe in paying artists for their work and contribution to the project. That is why

$1,300 is for artists stipends. Many passionate artists will be working on this project, including eight actors, a full production team, as well as others such as graphic designers and photographers.

$500 is for production needs such as costumes, set pieces, and props. Although we plan on being as minimalist as possible, we know there will be somethings we need to rent, such as a police uniform and prop guns, that will cost us some money. 

The last $200 is for advertising. We have someone working hard on marketing and our goal is to get the news about this production out to as many people as we can. The more people that we can get into the theatre the bigger the impact we can have on our community. 

This brings our goal to $2,000.

So what happens if the production comes in under budget or we raise more than our goal!?

If we have amazing backers like you, we will donate any remaining funds to Everytown for Gun Safety, an American nonprofit organization which advocates for gun control and against gun violence. 

How Am I Making this Happen?

Although I am an individual producer, I have an amazing team who all have professional experience in their fields. 

This project is also backed by Arts Nest's Fledgling Program through a grant from the Minnesota Regional Arts Council. Arts Nest's mission is to nurture and support emerging artists and arts professionals – through creating access and opportunities for learning, connections, and visibility. With the help and guidance from their experienced professionals  and vast connections and resources, we have been able to make this project a reality.

If You Can't Donate, How Else Can You Help?

  • First, share this campaign with other people who you thing could help!
  • Second, follow us on facebook and share our page as well! Lets get the buzz going about this production!  https://www.facebook.com/enoughisenoughMN/
  • Third, COME SEE OUR SHOW! Support us through being a part of our conversations!

IF you can't do any of that, help by getting involved in your communities! And most importantly make sure to vote during the mid-term elections in November!  Vote Out those who accept money from the NRA, in exchange to do their dirty work; as well as those who value guns more than human life!

Together we can make a change!

story:
Introduction.

Hi, my name is Ben Wright, I am the Artistic Director of bgroup – a UK based Project Company, which I formed in 2008. I am an independent choreographer and director and I work across the board, in Contemporary Dance, Theatre and Opera. Recent freelance choreographic collaborations have included work for The Metropolitan Opera, The Michael Grandage Company, The Glyndebourne Opera Festival and The English National Opera among others.

You can learn more about me and my work at my new website benwright.info or watch my showreel.

I have just returned to the UK from Sweden where I have been working as the Associate Artistic Director of  Skånes Dansteater (2014 – 2017) Whilst there, I made some pretty sizable work for the company, performed mainly at Malmo Opera. My present project however, see's me cooking up something a little more compact for UK audiences.... 

Point of Echoes is bgroup’s fifth work and marks a new collaboration between myself and the Brighton based writer and musician Stuart Warwick, it'll be our most theatrical work to date. This campaign will help us significantly extend the reach of our tour, enabling us to share the piece with a whole host of small theatre venues. Do read on and watch the film above. Thanks for your time.

The Show

It’s a real privilege to have been awarded the first commission from The Rural Touring Dance Initiative (RTDI) which is going to assist bgroup create and tour this brand new piece of dance-theatre to rural settings around the UK. We are conceiving and designing the work for a range of spaces with minimal resources but in true bgroup style we are promising to turn up with some pretty high production values. 

Point of Echoes is a tale of love, death and mystical creatures based entirely on a newly written play, told through dance and original music. I have found myself referring to it as akin to a ghost tale around a campfire or an uncanny tale at bedtime. It’s going to be creepy and up close.

I'm thrilled to be bringing together an excellent Creative Team for the project; Writer and Composer Stuart Warwick, Stage & Costume Designer Will Holt, Lighting Designer Lucy Hansom and performers Dom Czapski, Carl Harrison and Marta Masiero. 

The Impact

Our aim is to tour Point of Echoes far and wide, offering many communities the opportunity to experience something rather different, cozy and compelling.  

The show is designed to be flexible enough to work in both theatre spaces and village halls, which is a really exciting prospect. We will be transforming each performance space into an intimate setting, with audience located on four sides, surrounded by an immersive seascape around the edge of the space. That, in combination with a lavish acoustic sound score will transport viewers into the heart of the bleak and watery landscape in which our story is set.

With my highly experienced Creative Team behind it, this piece will be of a quality rarely seen on the rural circuit.

Your Help

Any contribution large or small will be greatly appreciated to help advance the creation and initial touring of this ambitious piece of dance theatre. In return we’d love to thank you with a bunch of excellent rewards especially designed for our Point of Echoes backers – we hope you enjoy them!

story:
Who we are:
 
The Playwright: 
I am Tom Block, a playwright, author and painter whose work concerns issues of contemporary prophecy, activism, hope, nihilism, mysticism and insanity.  And how they can all exist within the same person or event.  I had my first two plays produced (in Washington D.C.) this past year, about which reviewers said that I offered a "a fascinating and rewarding look at the multiple dimensions of faith, theory, and inspiration" and "If you’d like to explore where theater will be ten years from now it is probably worth a look."  White Noise is my first full-length New York production..  
I have also had two books published ("Shalom/Salaam: A Story of a Mystical Fraternity" in both the United States and Turkey in 2010 and "A Fatal Addiction: War in the Name of God" by Algora Publishers, NY, in 2012) and I have two more moving toward publication in the next year or so. 
I have exhibited my artwork around the United States and Europe. And I have spoken about my ideas at universities and conferences in Egypt, Turkey, Spain, Ireland, Canada and throughout the United States.  I was a Research Fellow at DePaul University's International Human Rights Law Institute (as an artist in residence) in 2010, as well as the founding producer of the Amnesty International Human Rights Art Festival, 2010 (MD). Most recently, I was awarded a Maryland State Arts Council Individual Artist Award (2013) for my painting Jiwar, which is part of theWhite Noise set.  www.tomblock.com

 
The director: 
I am Moema Umann, a Brooklyn-based director. I started my career in Brazil and since 2006 I have been working in theater and movies produced in United States also. I hold a Bachelor degree from the University of Brasilia in performing arts and a Masters Degree in directing from the Actors Studio Drama School. In the summer of 2010 I was selected to be part of the Directors Lab at the Lincoln Center and to be part of the Actors Studio Playwrights and Directors Workshop. I received an award as Best Female Director at the 2010 American International Film Festival for the movie Before Breakfast, which was also accepted at the 2011 Short Film Corner in Cannes, the Big Apple Film Festival, New Filmmakers 2012, among others. Recently the film Noemia got an award at Hollyshorts Festival in Los Angeles. My last film productions Moth and Strawberry are currently in postproduction. I am delighted and very grateful to be now directing White Noise by Tom Block at The Theater For The New City. 
 
 
Description of the campaign:
 

White Noise follows an African-American painter whose work is based on spiritual themes, as he travels to Detroit for an art exhibit of his work. At first calm, mature and erudite, Tim meets a seemingly normal cast of characters, who are volunteers with the church arts committee where Tim is to exhibit his paintings.  However, all of them from the hidden poet Lilac, cultural ambassador and psychically injured Sally and ex-Northrup Grumman Vice President Dick to the oversexed marriage therapist Joan, tweak at his interior demons. Tim struggles with and then succumbs to his own fixations, as an increasingly bizarre exterior reality and a scantily-clad Simone Weil, a historical figure that metastasizes as a figment of his own imagination, close in on him.

Having abandoned true faith, Tim grasps for "faith in faith," and in the end finds dubious understanding, alone in a bathroom.  The review of the Washington DC production IN DC THEATER SCENE (JUNE 9, 2012) stated that it was “a fascinating and rewarding look at the multiple dimensions of faith, theory, and inspiration.” Also:

Tim arrives in the midst of a heated squabble. Little is said about his art, but what follows is an extended discussion of his struggle, his own chosen Muse, Simon Weil, and spiritual self-realization. If that sounds dry, it’s not: as the play progresses, it disintegrates into a mélange of Jungian motifs, sexual hang-ups, racial prejudices and other demons of the modern age . . . it’s a crazy mélange of process and imagination. . . a fascinating peek at the side most artists don’t want us to see: the creation (and deconstruction) of the persona. Tim arrives as a selfmade guru of eastern wisdom; by the end of the play, he’s a hypocritical addict of Internet Porn.

Producing a New York theater piece is a massive undertaking, especially as I live in Washington D.C.  Director, Assistant Director, Stage Manager, Set Designer, Costume Designer, Media Specialist, Musician and Choreographer, as well as the actors, must all be paid!  These dedicated professionals work their magic for far less than they deserve, yet must still be remunerated.  With a tough play of this sort, which picks at the scab of the human experience, the monetary payback is not secured, while the emotional and spiritual reward is high.  Is this not the realm of true art?  Therefore, we would love your help in paying this incredible cast and crew that Moema Umann (herself an award winning Director) has pulled together for the production.
 
Your Contribution:
 
You will be helping to bring to life a unique piece of theater, my first play, which, as the review of the Washington D.C. premier (June 2012), noted: "explores the artist's thought process, as he works in the lonely world between spiritual, theoretical, and artistic.   As the play progresses, it disintegrates into a mélange of Jungian motifs, sexual hang-ups, racial prejudices and other demons of the modern age. It’s a crazy mélange of process and imagination. The production is a fascinating peek at the side most artists don’t want us to see: the creation (and deconstruction) of the persona. It’s a  fascinating and rewarding look at the multiple dimensions of faith, theory, and inspiration."  Perhaps even more telling is the excitement that the cast has expressed in working on such a tough, unusual theater piece. 
 
We are asking for $3000 for the cast and crew of the production.  This includes payment for Director, Assistant Director, Stage Manager, Set Designer, Costume Designer, Media Specialist, Musician and Choreographer, as well as the actors.
 
Our unique perks:
 
We want you to be happy, as well!  So we are offering a series of enticements that allow you to become part of Tom Block's creative world, as well as the world that Director Moema Umann is building with White Noise at Theater for the New City:
 
$25 -- one ticket to the opening night show. 
 
$50 -- two tickets to the opening night (Thursday, June 27) show.  
 
$100 -- an original line-drawing by Tom Block of anything the donator would like, either in person (a portrait for instance) or from a photo.  
 
$175 -- the set of both books published by Tom Block, "Shalom/Salaam: A Story of a Mystical Fraternity" (https://www.fonsvitae.com/OnlineStore/tabid/58/pid/361/0784-ShalomSalaam-A-Story-of-a-Mystical-Fraternity.aspx) and "A Fatal Addiction: War in the Name of God" (http://www.algora.com/391/book/details.html), both signed by the author
 
$250 -- an original drawing from the series that is exhibited behind the play (these are 10" x 8" on paper, and are titled "Illustrations from an Unpublished Novel.")  
 
$500 -- Tickets for two to any night's performance, a backstage pass to the show and drinks and conversation with the playwright and director after the show.
 
$1000 and above -- a 50 cents-on-the-dollar gift certificate for the purchase of a single work of art from the studio of Tom Block.  
 
Where the funds go:  
 
All monies raised will go to defray costs of the production, if it is more or less than the stated amount.  
 
Why this project is valuable to the contributor and to the world:
 
White Noise is part of a continuing exploration of central human spiritual issues, the consideration of which has waned in recent centuries.  Spiritual concerns were once at the center of human social life, yet now are shunted into religious institutions and New Age magazines.  
I have taken a 360 degree look at these issues through my writing and artwork.  I have received numerous grants and awards -- from such places as the Norman Lear Family Foundation (for theAmnesty International Human Rights Art Festival), Mary Greve Foundation (for my bookShalom/Salaam: A Story of a Mystical Fraternity), the Ludwig Vogelstein Foundation, Maryland State Arts Council, Puffin Foundation (for my art) and many other institutional funders.  However, we decided that for this project, we wanted to expand the funding base, involving more people in supporting and considering issues that we feel should be at the center of the human search, yet too often are not.
story_txt:
Who we are:
 
The Playwright: 


I am Tom Block, a playwright, author and painter whose work concerns issues of contemporary prophecy, activism, hope, nihilism, mysticism and insanity.  And how they can all exist within the same person or event.  I had my first two plays produced (in Washington D.C.) this past year, about which reviewers said that I offered a "a fascinating and rewarding look at the multiple dimensions of faith, theory, and inspiration" and "If you’d like to explore where theater will be ten years from now it is probably worth a look."  White Noise is my first full-length New York production..  


I have also had two books published ("Shalom/Salaam: A Story of a Mystical Fraternity" in both the United States and Turkey in 2010 and "A Fatal Addiction: War in the Name of God" by Algora Publishers, NY, in 2012) and I have two more moving toward publication in the next year or so. 


I have exhibited my artwork around the United States and Europe. And I have spoken about my ideas at universities and conferences in Egypt, Turkey, Spain, Ireland, Canada and throughout the United States.  I was a Research Fellow at DePaul University's International Human Rights Law Institute (as an artist in residence) in 2010, as well as the founding producer of the Amnesty International Human Rights Art Festival, 2010 (MD). Most recently, I was awarded a Maryland State Arts Council Individual Artist Award (2013) for my painting Jiwar, which is part of theWhite Noise set.  www.tomblock.com



 
The director: 
I am Moema Umann, a Brooklyn-based director. I started my career in Brazil and since 2006 I have been working in theater and movies produced in United States also. I hold a Bachelor degree from the University of Brasilia in performing arts and a Masters Degree in directing from the Actors Studio Drama School. In the summer of 2010 I was selected to be part of the Directors Lab at the Lincoln Center and to be part of the Actors Studio Playwrights and Directors Workshop. I received an award as Best Female Director at the 2010 American International Film Festival for the movie Before Breakfast, which was also accepted at the 2011 Short Film Corner in Cannes, the Big Apple Film Festival, New Filmmakers 2012, among others. Recently the film Noemia got an award at Hollyshorts Festival in Los Angeles. My last film productions Moth and Strawberry are currently in postproduction. I am delighted and very grateful to be now directing White Noise by Tom Block at The Theater For The New City. 
 
 
Description of the campaign:
 

White Noise follows an African-American painter whose work is based on spiritual themes, as he travels to Detroit for an art exhibit of his work. At first calm, mature and erudite, Tim meets a seemingly normal cast of characters, who are volunteers with the church arts committee where Tim is to exhibit his paintings.  However, all of them from the hidden poet Lilac, cultural ambassador and psychically injured Sally and ex-Northrup Grumman Vice President Dick to the oversexed marriage therapist Joan, tweak at his interior demons. Tim struggles with and then succumbs to his own fixations, as an increasingly bizarre exterior reality and a scantily-clad Simone Weil, a historical figure that metastasizes as a figment of his own imagination, close in on him.
Having abandoned true faith, Tim grasps for "faith in faith," and in the end finds dubious understanding, alone in a bathroom.  The review of the Washington DC production IN DC THEATER SCENE (JUNE 9, 2012) stated that it was “a fascinating and rewarding look at the multiple dimensions of faith, theory, and inspiration.” Also:
Tim arrives in the midst of a heated squabble. Little is said about his art, but what follows is an extended discussion of his struggle, his own chosen Muse, Simon Weil, and spiritual self-realization. If that sounds dry, it’s not: as the play progresses, it disintegrates into a mélange of Jungian motifs, sexual hang-ups, racial prejudices and other demons of the modern age . . . it’s a crazy mélange of process and imagination. . . a fascinating peek at the side most artists don’t want us to see: the creation (and deconstruction) of the persona. Tim arrives as a selfmade guru of eastern wisdom; by the end of the play, he’s a hypocritical addict of Internet Porn.

Producing a New York theater piece is a massive undertaking, especially as I live in Washington D.C.  Director, Assistant Director, Stage Manager, Set Designer, Costume Designer, Media Specialist, Musician and Choreographer, as well as the actors, must all be paid!  These dedicated professionals work their magic for far less than they deserve, yet must still be remunerated.  With a tough play of this sort, which picks at the scab of the human experience, the monetary payback is not secured, while the emotional and spiritual reward is high.  Is this not the realm of true art?  Therefore, we would love your help in paying this incredible cast and crew that Moema Umann (herself an award winning Director) has pulled together for the production.
 
Your Contribution:
 
You will be helping to bring to life a unique piece of theater, my first play, which, as the review of the Washington D.C. premier (June 2012), noted: "explores the artist's thought process, as he works in the lonely world between spiritual, theoretical, and artistic.   As the play progresses, it disintegrates into a mélange of Jungian motifs, sexual hang-ups, racial prejudices and other demons of the modern age. It’s a crazy mélange of process and imagination. The production is a fascinating peek at the side most artists don’t want us to see: the creation (and deconstruction) of the persona. It’s a  fascinating and rewarding look at the multiple dimensions of faith, theory, and inspiration."  Perhaps even more telling is the excitement that the cast has expressed in working on such a tough, unusual theater piece. 
 

We are asking for $3000 for the cast and crew of the production.  This includes payment for Director, Assistant Director, Stage Manager, Set Designer, Costume Designer, Media Specialist, Musician and Choreographer, as well as the actors.

 
Our unique perks:
 
We want you to be happy, as well!  So we are offering a series of enticements that allow you to become part of Tom Block's creative world, as well as the world that Director Moema Umann is building with White Noise at Theater for the New City:
 
$25 -- one ticket to the opening night show. 
 

$50 -- two tickets to the opening night (Thursday, June 27) show.  
 
$100 -- an original line-drawing by Tom Block of anything the donator would like, either in person (a portrait for instance) or from a photo.  
 
$175 -- the set of both books published by Tom Block, "Shalom/Salaam: A Story of a Mystical Fraternity" (https://www.fonsvitae.com/OnlineStore/tabid/58/pid/361/0784-ShalomSalaam-A-Story-of-a-Mystical-Fraternity.aspx) and "A Fatal Addiction: War in the Name of God" (http://www.algora.com/391/book/details.html), both signed by the author
 
$250 -- an original drawing from the series that is exhibited behind the play (these are 10" x 8" on paper, and are titled "Illustrations from an Unpublished Novel.")  
 
$500 -- Tickets for two to any night's performance, a backstage pass to the show and drinks and conversation with the playwright and director after the show.
 
$1000 and above -- a 50 cents-on-the-dollar gift certificate for the purchase of a single work of art from the studio of Tom Block.  
 
Where the funds go:  
 
All monies raised will go to defray costs of the production, if it is more or less than the stated amount.  
 

Why this project is valuable to the contributor and to the world:
 
White Noise is part of a continuing exploration of central human spiritual issues, the consideration of which has waned in recent centuries.  Spiritual concerns were once at the center of human social life, yet now are shunted into religious institutions and New Age magazines.  
I have taken a 360 degree look at these issues through my writing and artwork.  I have received numerous grants and awards -- from such places as the Norman Lear Family Foundation (for theAmnesty International Human Rights Art Festival), Mary Greve Foundation (for my bookShalom/Salaam: A Story of a Mystical Fraternity), the Ludwig Vogelstein Foundation, Maryland State Arts Council, Puffin Foundation (for my art) and many other institutional funders.  However, we decided that for this project, we wanted to expand the funding base, involving more people in supporting and considering issues that we feel should be at the center of the human search, yet too often are not.

story:
My plan is to present this concert reading pay-what-you-can. Certainly, that is the spirit of the Occupy Movement but also, I’ve watched so many wonderful productions in NYC close because their audience couldn’t afford to see them. Hopefully, I can reach a larger audience pay-what-you-can, perhaps people who wouldn’t normally budget the time or resources to see live theatre.

I’ve been a member the BMI advanced musical theatre writers workshop since 2006. I received their award for artistic accomplishments in my first year. My full bio and resume and credits are on my website (carldanielsen.com) - I’ve worked extensively as an actor in NYC and across the country doing everything from Greek Tragedy to musicals to Law and Order. My writing and compositions have been presented in various theatrical venues across the country. Bringing Fire (Prometheus of Wall Street) was first presented as a part of the Golden Fleece New Works series in 2011 and received a Tyrone Guthrie award from the Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Canada which I used to record the score.

The White Box theatre at 440 Broadway is $50 an hour, so the total for 4 hours on 2 days is $400. I’d also love to guarantee the 7 actors and djembe player $100 each for their long rehearsal hours to present this piece. Grand total: $1200

Paul Pontrelli, Prometheus; Shauna Goodgold Io/Hermes/Bia; Steven Hajar, Hephaestus; Kelly Morris, Ebonee Noel, Rebecca Odorisio, Oceanids; Arthur Rowan, Kratos/Oceanus. Steele Kratt (djembe)

Can you help me spread the word about this event? It will be May 30 and June 6 at 7. Rowan and the Rose will begin the program with 3 songs of social unrest and someone from the Occupy Movement will lead a discussion afterwards. My long term goal is to present this concert on a regular basis, moving towards a full production meanwhile inspiring discussion and actual change. All in the pay-what-you-can format...

 Addendum (4/30/2013) If you notice, we've reached our goal. If you still want to give, go right ahead. Whatever we get over the $1200 will go straight to the amazing actors and musicians. Your name will go in the program, or whatever the perk is. Go right on giving.

story:
Two Roads Educational Arts and Theater (TREAT) is a professional theater company in Fairfield, Iowa that produces plays and musicals aimed at young audiences and their families.  As part of the initial start up, families or individuals can purchase the opportunity to paint their very own seat for the theater!  Since TREAT is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas (www.fracturedatlas.org), a non-profit arts service organization, your donations will be TAX-DEDUCTIBLE to the extent permitted by law, and a receipt for your contributions will be provided by Fractured Atlas.

Your greatly appreciated TAX-DEDUCTIBLE donation will not only help provide the children of Fairfield and surrounding communities with an enjoyable theater experience, but will also give them the opportunity to create a lasting piece of the actual theater.  What a TREAT!

Larger, separate donations are also being accepted by individuals and families for temporary or permanent recognition in displays in the theater.  In addition, donations of $10 or more will be recognized on the theater website www.fairfieldtreat.com and donations of $50 or more will also be listed in the program insert for the first season.

Help us exceed our fundraising goal to provide a solid financial foundation for this new theater opportunity.  All funds will be utilized to cover costs associated with obtaining rights or actual production costs; your donation will directly support the shows and theater, not an administrative salary.

 

Thank you!

 

"Two roads diverged in a wood, and I, I took the one less traveled by, and that has made all the difference." --Robert Frost

story:
Short Summary

Book of Dreams is a new production company in Portland, OR, started in 2011. Costa Rehab is our second show, performed in a small, intimate setting in Southeast Portland. It is written by local playwright Rich Rubin. In fitting with our vision for our company, it is timely and thought-provoking, while at the same time infused with much humor. 

We will run from May 24 through June 23, Thursdays through Sundays at 8 PM at the Backdoor Theater, 4319 SE Hawthorne Blvd. Portland OR. 

What We Need & What You Get

The $4000 that we are asking for pays for the 5-week rental of the theater space where we will perform. It also pays for original music, photography, publicity, costumes, props, and a stipend for the actors and technicians. What we offer mainly has to do with chances to interact with us, and learn more about the project and our company first hand. 

The Impact

We are donating 5% of the total proceeds during the run and 100% of a single performance to the Wounded Warrior Project, which benefits returning soldiers in various different ways. However, our main goal in this project is to draw attention to a subject that is all but forgotten by many. Those who serve our country need to be recognized and honored, and we will attempt to do just that. 

Other Ways You Can Help

See the show. Talk about the show. Spread the word about this campaign.

story:
Small Wooden Shoe has been asked to bring Perhaps in a Hundred Years to Montreal and we need your help to get there.  

We're going to Montreal to be part of OFFTA  - a great curated program that happens alongside the Festival TransAmériques.   It's an amazing opportunity. There will be tons of artists and presenters there from around the world. It's a chance to have our work seen by a bunch of people who otherwise we can't reach which can lead to good things in the future for not only this show but for Small Wooden Shoe and Jacob, Chad and Ame. It will also be a chance for our Montreal friends to see this show that we love and think is pretty special (and others agree - see the reviews below)

While OFFTA provides us with space and an incredible, unique context, they don't have anything in the way of money for us. 

We need $3,000 to cover the time, travel and expenses for us to get ourselves and the show to Montreal and take advantage of this rare chance.

Any amount helps and we've got some nice, homemade show appropriate perks to go along with the charitable tax receipt you'll get.

 

Perhaps in a Hundred Years is a tender science fiction story about three friends stuck in outer space, waiting for the future to arrive. They tell stories, sing songs, pass notes, and try to answer some questions about communism, candy bars and parties. Dancing, lip syncs and quiet beauty fill the space. Our heroes are surprisingly optimistic, given the conditions outside, armed as they are with cheerful pop songs and over a millennium worth of utopias.  Despite an almost overwhelming pessimism for the long term future, which many of us share, Perhaps in a Hundred Years endeavors to keep it upbeat, or at least tenderly, militantly, hopeful. Mixing space-rock show with confessional; talk show with theatre to create performance for the future from the past (or at least from 2005.)  

Six years ago Ame Henderson (Public Recordings), Chad Dembski (surprise performance) and Jacob Zimmer (Small Wooden Shoe) in collaboration with dramaturge Kilby Smith-McGregor, came together to make a show. Isolated in an oxygen deprived studio during a Toronto heat wave they made a show about three friends stuck in outer space. Later that year they rented a van and played galleries in Halifax and Saint John and the back room of a Montreal cafe.

"Perhaps In A Hundred Years is not a conventional theatrical narrative. It is a wonderful insight into this group of artists’ struggle with the issues that concern us all: why we are here, where we are going, why we do what we do, how we relate to each other, and what the hell is wrong with the world?" - Dorianne Emmerton (Mooney on Theatre) 

"It’s a meditation on isolation (the three are ostensibly lost in space), friendship and ways of thinking about the future. The trio’s understated, ultra-casual style is still refreshing and thought-provoking" - Jordan Bim (NOW Magazine) 

"Endearingly simple and painstakingly casual, Small Wooden Shoe’s Perhaps In a Hundred Years is less a play than an experiment to recreate that unique feeling of being contently bored with people you like." - Robert LaRonde (Swimming with Shut-Ins)

story:
BORDERLINE REMIX: A Hip HOpera for Border-jumpers and Stowaways

The 2012 Borderline Remix unites Israeli, Palestinian, German, and African youth musicians, filmmakers and dancers (ages 16-21) to explore and voice experiences of migration and the quest for home.

Working together over the course of six months from their home countries (meeting in Jericho, Tel Aviv, Jerusalem and Manheim) participants are exploring their diverse personal and communal narratives of forced migration, learning about the human right of asylum, and feeding their understanding, struggles, and hopes into their original music, film, and dance creations.

In August 2012, the full group will unite for the first time in Jerusalem, to weave their works together into the first ever Hip HOpera of its kind.  After one week of rehearsals and debut performances in Jerusalem and Jaffa/Tel Aviv, the group flies to Manheim, Germany where they will officially launch their performance tour and will film a promotional DVD.  With enough funding the group can also perform in Berlin this August.  New performance dates will be added throughout 2012 and 2013.

Our goal is to inspire change by building understanding, awareness, and trust between project participants and across society. 

The project is led by Heartbeat, ActiveVision, The Willy Brandt Center in Jerusalem, Addiktz e.V., and Teater Kapija.

In 2010, Heartbeat, the Willy Brandt Center in Jerusalem, and ActiveVision produced the precursor to Borderline Remix, the Hip Hop Hudna, which won the Europeans for Peace 2010 award for project of the year.  The Hip Hop Hudna brought together sixteen Israeli, Palestinian and German rappers and musicians to explore the power of music to impact society, giving concerts in Jerusalem, Tel Aviv and Berlin, and producing True Love, a full length album of the participant's original music.  The album can be heard here: http://heartbeatmusic.bandcamp.com

With the addition of Addiktz eV from Manheim and Teater Kapija from Sweden, the Borderline Remix takes cross-cultural, cross-conflict exchange beyond all borders, fusing artistic styles and addressing deep cross-cutting social issues facing every community in every country.

This project is 100% free for participants.

A bit more about the project leaders:

ActiveVision, a legally registered non-governmental association in Israel, was established in 2006 by a group of creators who believe in the power of the visual image to create awareness and social change. www.active-vision.org

HEARTBEAT is an international community of musicians, educators, and students using music to build mutual understanding and transform conflict.  Founded in 2007 under a Fulbright-MTVu Award, Heartbeat’s programs seek to empower Israeli and Palestinian musicians by creating opportunities and spaces for musicians from both sides to work together, hear each other, and amplify their voices to influence the world around them. www.heartbeat.fm

www.willybrandtcenter.org

 

What We Need & What You Get

80% of the project is already funded by Europeans for Peace and the Foundation for Remembrance, Responsibility and Future, based in Berlin.  So we are doing this project!  The question is: will we be able to include everyone and do the project as well as possible if we don't have enough money?

To make the project happen in full, we just need another $7000.  

This money would cover

  • Making sure all of our participants and staff get there! Right now we need another $3000 just to bring all of the people who are able to come and to pay our staff a very minimal stipend for their time.
  • Professionally producing and distributing the recorded soundtrack for the Hip HOpera, to be sold as a CD at performances, and online. ($3000)  The music is going to be breathtaking. We really want the recording to be done properly.
  • We would like to be able to properly spread the word about what we're doing.  $1000 would go towards marketing, printing posters for the shows, and PR.
  • If we have even more money we can:
    • Perform this August in Berlin ($3000)
    • Film a music video Hip HOpera trailer ($2000).
    • Pay our staff members what they actually deserve...
  • Please check out our cool rewards.  If you have other ideas of things we can offer, please let us know!  We are open to any idea!

The Impact

We want this project to become a self-sustaining production capable of touring the world, building understanding, awareness and inspiring change.  We appreciate the connection with wonderful people like you around the world, and want to bring awesome, meaningful productions to you, without having to fundraise beforehand. We truly believe that this project can support itself once we get started.  This is why we need your help.

Our vision for the Borderline Remix is to very soon appear in a community near you, hold workshops with local artists and youth, and add each community's voices to our existing format.  The possibilities are endless.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you'd to like to support the project but can't spare the cash at this very moment, we certainly understand. There are plenty of other ways to help.  We need lots of help sharing the link to this campaign.  If you use facebook or twitter please share, tweet, post post post. Every bit helps.

In fact, a very powerful and easy way to help is to share the campaign with at least 5 people on FB/Twitter/word-of-mouth. 

We also have some very cool projects starting up for interns and volunteers around the world. If you'd like to sign up to volunteer or intern with us, please email amitai@heartbeatjerusalem.org

 

Thank You!!!

This project is 100% free for participants.
A bit more about the project leaders:
ActiveVision, a legally registered non-governmental association in Israel, was established in 2006 by a group of creators who believe in the power of the visual image to create awareness and social change. www.active-vision.org
HEARTBEAT is an international community of musicians, educators, and students using music to build mutual understanding and transform conflict.  Founded in 2007 under a Fulbright-MTVu Award, Heartbeat’s programs seek to empower Israeli and Palestinian musicians by creating opportunities and spaces for musicians from both sides to work together, hear each other, and amplify their voices to influence the world around them. www.heartbeat.fm
www.willybrandtcenter.org
 


What We Need & What You Get
80% of the project is already funded by Europeans for Peace and the Foundation for Remembrance, Responsibility and Future, based in Berlin.  So we are doing this project!  The question is: will we be able to include everyone and do the project as well as possible if we don't have enough money?
To make the project happen in full, we just need another $7000.  
This money would cover

Making sure all of our participants and staff get there! Right now we need another $3000 just to bring all of the people who are able to come and to pay our staff a very minimal stipend for their time.
Professionally producing and distributing the recorded soundtrack for the Hip HOpera, to be sold as a CD at performances, and online. ($3000)  The music is going to be breathtaking. We really want the recording to be done properly.
We would like to be able to properly spread the word about what we're doing.  $1000 would go towards marketing, printing posters for the shows, and PR.
If we have even more money we can:

Perform this August in Berlin ($3000)
Film a music video Hip HOpera trailer ($2000).
Pay our staff members what they actually deserve...

Please check out our cool rewards.  If you have other ideas of things we can offer, please let us know!  We are open to any idea!



The Impact
We want this project to become a self-sustaining production capable of touring the world, building understanding, awareness and inspiring change.  We appreciate the connection with wonderful people like you around the world, and want to bring awesome, meaningful productions to you, without having to fundraise beforehand. We truly believe that this project can support itself once we get started.  This is why we need your help.
Our vision for the Borderline Remix is to very soon appear in a community near you, hold workshops with local artists and youth, and add each community's voices to our existing format.  The possibilities are endless.


Other Ways You Can Help
If you'd to like to support the project but can't spare the cash at this very moment, we certainly understand. There are plenty of other ways to help.  We need lots of help sharing the link to this campaign.  If you use facebook or twitter please share, tweet, post post post. Every bit helps.
In fact, a very powerful and easy way to help is to share the campaign with at least 5 people on FB/Twitter/word-of-mouth. 
We also have some very cool projects starting up for interns and volunteers around the world. If you'd like to sign up to volunteer or intern with us, please email amitai@heartbeatjerusalem.org
 
Thank You!!!

story:
Our Story

The mission of The Annie is to foster and support the development of original, theatrical projects and productions that are born of the historic and modern folklore of Cape Ann. We welcome people of all ages and life experiences to participate in our programs.

Fiercely local, we are a true Community Theatre that values and promotes freedom and diversity, and nurtures the creative spirit that exists in all human beings. We offer a safe, inclusive, sacred space to explore, risk, and dream.


The Impact

We are looking to build a new modular stage for our theatre space to replace the former stage which was poorly built and unsafe.  We run many programs for the youth of Cape Ann, and we are striving to give them a safe nurturing space to learn and express themselves.  A new modular stage would mean new opportunities for our resident theatre company, made up of locals, as well as our youth conservatory, which aims to give guidance and training to the next generation of Cape Ann artists.


What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming to raise $3000 to acquire the lumber, hardware, and tool rentals to build a new modular stage for our space.  We have a wonderful team of volunteers standing by, ready to build, now we just need the materials!  We are a small, new, non-profit theatre.  We are not able to go forward with this project without your help.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help financially, please help us spread the word to as many people as you can!

story:
Summary: (YEMD) is a youth project that will provide a low to no cost comprehensive dance and fitness program to youth who might not have access to a program like this if there were a significant charge.

My name is Beatrix and I am a registered nurse in Anaheim.  5 yrs ago i opened a dance studio in Garden Grove to bring the joy of dance to the kids in the community.  My daughter and I have been involved in dance since she was 6 and it has had an extremely positive effect on the entire family.  She is 14 now and a straight A student.  No problems with drugs or alcohol and lives an active, involved, lifestyle.

My passion is to be able to bring this magic to all the kids in the community.  Our public schools are removing much of the arts as well as fitness from their programs and many children are resorting to other activities that lead to personal destruction such as drugs and alcohol, early sexual promiscuity, tobacco use and much much more.

Our children are our future.  We need to take care of them, nurture them and bring them up in a positive loving environment. These children will be our future teachers, nurses, senators, business owners and even our presidents.  It is a proven fact that youth involved in dance are much less likely to become involved with drugs and alcohol, start smoking, drop out of school or get arrested for criminal activity.  Dancers will develop increased self esteem and self worth, learn to live healthy lifestyles and become physically fit.

YEMD’s goals are a) to empower youth to feel confident in their bodies and increase overall self-esteem, b) to build artistic development, c) to prevent alcohol, tobacco, and other drug use/experimentation, d) to increase community bonding by engaging youth in community activities, and e) to provide nutritional education to youth and their parents to help prevent obesity.

Your contribution will help us maintain a professional school of dance and fitness that is run by professional, dedicated people that will focus solely on our kids. At this point our project budget is short about 25 thousand dollars and that is with 50 kids paying a minimum monthly due.  We NEED a full time program director to keep the program running smoothly and make sure all the kids get the most benefit from our program.  We also need a place to have our classes.  Please help us raise enough to offer a solid dance and fitness education that is otherwise unavailable to low income kids.

What We Need & What You Get

We are attempting to raise 25,000 dollars as part of a start up fund for our Fall kids project.  The funds will be used for:
1. 9000 dollars will pay our instructors for 6 months,
2. 7200 dollars will pay a professional director for 6 months.
3. 5000 dollars will pay our rent for 6 months
4. 3800 dollars will pay a scholarship for 4 children that are accepted into our program and in need of financial assistance.  Please see http://youthempowermentthroughdance.blogspot.com/p/scholarship-program.html to view our scholarship program that is in desperate need of funding.
 
 All funds will be dispursed by Fractured Atlas for specific YEMD expenses.  The Bea Hive has been generous enough to let us use their beautiful venue for the purpose of this project at a minimum cost.  There is a giant, gorgeous dance floor with mirrors and a ballet bar.  They will post YOUR name prominently as a sponsor for any donations.  See following perks for details.
 
 For businesses and corporations you will get exposure to thousands of new people a year for your own business.

The Impact

This is our first campaign and our project starts in September 2012.  We are attempting to raise enough funds to maintain a professional staff of instructors. Your contributions will help our community to grow and prosper by supporting our kids and keeping them drug free and healthy.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is able to make a monetary donation due to our depressed economy but there are other ways you can help.

  • Get the message to as many people as you know that would be able to help.
  • Offer services in other areas - we need costumes, equipment, floor mats and marketing help to get the word out.
  • You can use any of the Indiegogo share tools to help market.

Thank you for your contribution and remember that all donations are fully tax deductible to the extent of the law.
